messages.content: I have a final exam next week and I just know I'm going to fail.
It makes perfect sense to feel anxious with a big exam approaching. What specific thought comes up when you imagine taking the exam?
That I'm not smart enough and I'll fail everything.
Is there any evidence from past exams or assignments that challenges the idea that you're not smart enough?
Well, I did pass my midterms and assignments, even if they were tough.
Given that, could a more balanced thought be: “This exam is challenging, but I have succeeded on exams before and I can focus on the key topics I know”?
I keep putting off my thesis work and now I'm panicking.
It’s understandable to feel overwhelmed by a large project. What specific thought comes to mind when you think about your thesis?
That I’ll never finish it and it will be a disaster.
Have there been times when you completed big tasks step by step, even if it felt daunting at first?
Yes, I managed a long paper last semester by breaking it into smaller parts.
So, could a balanced thought be: “I can work on my thesis in stages; completing it step by step is realistic and achievable”?
Everyone seems to understand the material except me. I don’t belong here.
Feeling like you don’t belong can be very stressful, and that makes sense. What is the exact thought that makes you feel this way?
That I’m not capable and I’ll fail eventually.
What evidence suggests that you are capable and earned your place in the program?
I passed the entrance exams and have completed prior coursework successfully.
Could a more balanced thought be: “I earned my place here, and while I’m still learning, I am capable of keeping up with my studies”?
I’m terrified about presenting in class tomorrow.
It’s completely natural to feel nervous about presentations. What is the specific fear that comes to mind?
That I’ll embarrass myself and everyone will think I’m incompetent.
Have you ever given a presentation before that went better than you expected?
Yes, I presented in a smaller group last term and it went well.
So a balanced thought could be: “I may feel nervous, but I have successfully presented before, and I can handle this presentation too”?
My workload is insane and I can’t keep up.
It’s understandable to feel stressed with so many tasks. What thought makes you feel like you can’t manage?
That if I don’t do everything perfectly, I’m failing.
Is it realistic to expect anyone to do everything perfectly all the time?
No, not really.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but doing my best is enough; I don’t need to be perfect at everything”?
I failed one quiz, so my grade is ruined.
Failing a quiz can feel discouraging. What specific thought makes it feel like your whole grade is ruined?
That one mistake means I can’t get a good grade in the class.
Is it true that one quiz determines your entire grade?
No, it’s just a small portion.
Could a balanced thought be: “This quiz didn’t go well, but it’s only part of my grade and I can improve on the next ones”?
I got a B on my assignment. I’m a failure.
It’s natural to feel disappointed. What thought leads you from a B to believing you’re a failure?
That if it’s not perfect, I’m not good enough.
If a friend got a B and felt that way, what would you tell them?
I’d tell them a B is still good and doesn’t define their ability.
Could a balanced thought be: “A B isn’t perfect, but it doesn’t define my capability or worth”?
I’ll never be as good as the top students in my class.
It’s understandable to feel discouraged when comparing yourself to others. What thought comes up specifically?
That no matter how hard I try, I’ll always fall behind.
Have there been times you improved at something with practice?
Yes, my writing improved a lot after feedback.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may not be the top student, but I can grow and make progress through effort”?
I can’t finish this project. I’m too far behind.
Feeling behind can be stressful. What thought leads you to feel you can’t finish?
That if I’m behind, it’s pointless to try.
Is there a middle ground between giving up and catching up fully?
Maybe completing part of it instead of all at once.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’m behind, but doing part of the work is still progress and worth trying”?
My group members say I’m useless at our project.
That sounds upsetting. My focus is on academic stress, so can we focus on how you perceive your contribution rather than interpersonal conflict?
Okay, I feel like I’m not doing enough for the project.
What evidence do you have that shows you are contributing meaningfully?
I completed my assigned tasks and helped others when asked.
Could a balanced thought be: “I am contributing to the project and completing my responsibilities, even if it’s not perfect”?
I procrastinated on my lab report and now it’s due tomorrow.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought comes to mind about the lab report?
That I’ll never finish it on time.
Have you completed assignments in a short time successfully before?
Yes, I’ve managed tight deadlines before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I can focus on finishing the lab report step by step; I’ve met deadlines before”?
I always mess up presentations in class.
Feeling that way is understandable. What thought comes to mind when you say you mess up?
That I’ll embarrass myself again.
Have there been times when a presentation went better than you expected?
Yes, some presentations went fine even though I was nervous.
Could a balanced thought be: “I might feel nervous, but I’ve given successful presentations before and can handle this one”?
I didn’t understand the lecture, so I’m terrible at the subject.
It’s normal to feel frustrated. What specific thought leads you from one lecture to believing you’re terrible?
That missing some material means I can’t learn the subject.
Is it true that struggling with some material makes you incapable overall?
No, I can still study and understand later.
Could a balanced thought be: “I didn’t get everything today, but I can review and improve my understanding”?
I’m behind on reading and I’ll never catch up.
It’s understandable to feel stressed about reading load. What thought makes you believe you can’t catch up?
That it’s too much and I’ll fail to understand everything.
Have you managed heavy reading loads successfully in the past?
Yes, I handled last semester’s readings by scheduling them.
Could a balanced thought be: “The reading is heavy, but I can organize and work through it gradually”?
I keep comparing my grades to my classmates and I feel worthless.
It’s understandable to feel down when comparing yourself to others. What thought comes to mind when that happens?
That I’m not as smart or capable as them.
Is there evidence that shows your own progress and achievements?
Yes, I improved my grades from last semester and completed difficult assignments.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’m making progress and achieving my goals, even if I’m not the top student”?
I’m scared of my thesis defense. What if I get asked something I can’t answer?
It’s natural to feel anxious about defenses. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’ll look incompetent and fail.
Have there been times when you answered difficult questions successfully in smaller settings?
Yes, during my proposal review I handled tough questions well.
Could a balanced thought be: “I might face difficult questions, but I’ve handled them before and can prepare for this defense”?
I procrastinated on preparing for the midterm and now I feel doomed.
Feeling overwhelmed is understandable. What thought leads you to feel doomed?
That I’ll fail and ruin my grade.
Is there evidence that shows you can still recover or do your best despite procrastination?
Yes, last semester I crammed and passed difficult exams.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be behind, but I can focus now and do my best; one setback doesn’t define my grade”?
I feel like I can’t write a good introduction for my essay.
It’s normal to feel stuck sometimes. What thought comes up when you think you can’t write it?
That it will be terrible and I’ll get a low grade.
Have you written strong introductions before?
Yes, I’ve had good essays in previous courses.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’ve written good introductions before, and I can draft and improve this one too”?
I didn’t participate in class discussion today, so I must be bad at this course.
It’s normal to feel self-critical. What thought leads you from not participating to believing you’re bad at the course?
That if I’m quiet once, it shows I’m not capable.
Is it realistic that one moment defines your overall ability?
No, I participate sometimes and get feedback.
Could a balanced thought be: “Missing one discussion doesn’t define me; I can contribute in future sessions”?
I’m so behind on homework; I’ll never catch up.
Feeling behind can be stressful. What specific thought makes you feel you can’t catch up?
That no matter what I do, I’ll fail everything.
Have you ever caught up successfully after falling behind before?
Yes, I managed last semester when I had multiple assignments.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’m behind, but I’ve managed similar situations before and can tackle these assignments step by step”?
I feel like I’m not smart enough for this major.
It’s understandable to feel that way sometimes. What thought specifically makes you feel you’re not smart enough?
That I’ll never understand the material fully.
Have you been able to learn difficult material in the past?
Yes, I’ve learned tough subjects in previous courses.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may find this challenging, but I’ve learned difficult topics before and I can work through this too”?
I always panic when I get called on in class.
It makes sense that being called on triggers anxiety. What thought comes up when that happens?
That I’ll say something stupid and everyone will judge me.
Have there been times when you spoke up and it went okay?
Yes, sometimes I contribute useful points without issue.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve contributed successfully before and can do it again”?
I can’t write this essay well; it will be terrible.
Feeling unsure about an essay is normal. What thought makes you believe it will be terrible?
That I’ll get a low grade no matter what I do.
Have you received good grades on essays in the past?
Yes, I’ve had positive feedback before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel unsure, but I have written good essays before and can improve this one too”?
I keep putting off studying for my exams, and now I’m stressed.
It makes sense to feel stressed about procrastination. What thought comes up when you think about your exams?
That I’ll fail because I waited too long.
Have you ever studied under pressure and still done well?
Yes, I managed a difficult test last semester at the last minute.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even though I procrastinated, I can focus now and still perform well on the exams”?
I feel like I’m terrible at group work.
It’s understandable to feel anxious about collaboration. What thought makes you feel terrible at it?
That I’m slowing everyone down and they’ll think I’m useless.
Have there been times when your contributions helped the group?
Yes, I’ve done my part and sometimes helped others.
Could a balanced thought be: “I contribute to the group and can continue to improve, even if I’m not perfect”?
I get so nervous presenting that I freeze.
Feeling nervous before presentations is common. What thought comes up when you freeze?
That everyone will think I’m incompetent.
Have there been times you presented and it went okay despite nerves?
Yes, a few presentations went fine even though I was anxious.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve presented successfully before and can do it again”?
I didn’t understand the lecture, so I’ll fail the course.
It’s understandable to worry after missing content. What specific thought makes you believe you’ll fail?
That missing this material means I can’t succeed.
Have you caught up or learned material after not understanding something before?
Yes, I’ve reviewed lectures and improved my understanding.
Could a balanced thought be: “I didn’t get everything today, but I can review and improve my understanding”?
I feel like I can’t handle my workload.
It’s normal to feel overwhelmed. What thought leads you to believe you can’t handle it?
That I’ll fail if I don’t do everything perfectly.
Is it realistic to do everything perfectly all the time?
No, that’s impossible.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but doing my best is sufficient; I don’t need to be perfect at everything”?
I keep comparing myself to classmates and I feel inferior.
It’s understandable to feel that way. What specific thought comes up when comparing yourself?
That I’m not as good as they are.
Have you improved or achieved your own goals despite comparisons?
Yes, my grades improved this semester and I completed hard assignments.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’m making progress and achieving goals, even if I’m not the top student”?
I’m scared to ask questions in class because I’ll look stupid.
Feeling nervous about speaking up is normal. What thought makes you fear looking stupid?
That I’ll ask a bad question and everyone will judge me.
Have you asked questions before and received helpful responses?
Yes, sometimes questions led to good discussions.
Could a balanced thought be: “Asking questions helps me learn, and it’s okay if not every question is perfect”?
I feel like I’ll never finish my thesis on time.
It’s understandable to feel pressured. What thought leads you to believe you won’t finish?
That there’s too much work and I’ll fail.
Have you managed large projects successfully before?
Yes, I completed my previous research project on schedule.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I’ve handled big projects before and can manage my thesis step by step”?
I can’t understand this topic; I’m probably failing.
Feeling stuck is normal. What specific thought makes you think you’re failing?
That not understanding this material means I can’t succeed.
Have you learned difficult topics successfully in the past?
Yes, I managed tough chapters before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I don’t understand this yet, but I can study and learn it like I have with other topics”?
I didn’t answer a question in class and now I feel stupid.
It’s normal to feel self-conscious. What thought leads you to feel stupid?
That missing one answer means I’m not capable.
Is it realistic that one moment defines your overall ability?
No, I’ve answered correctly other times.
Could a balanced thought be: “Missing one answer doesn’t define me; I can still participate successfully”?
I feel like I’ll never get an A in this class.
It’s understandable to feel discouraged. What thought leads you to believe that?
That I’m not capable enough to earn top grades.
Have you achieved good grades in other courses with effort?
Yes, I got A’s in a couple of previous classes.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have earned top grades before, and with effort, I can perform well in this class too”?
I haven’t started my research paper and I’m panicking.
It’s understandable to feel panicked. What thought comes up when you think about not starting?
That I’ll fail if I don’t start immediately.
Have you ever completed assignments starting later than planned?
Yes, I’ve finished projects even with delayed starts.
Could a balanced thought be: “I haven’t started yet, but I can plan and work steadily to complete it successfully”?
I’m worried my professor will think I’m stupid.
It’s normal to worry about impressions. What thought leads you to feel that way?
That asking questions or making mistakes will make them judge me.
Have you had positive interactions with your professor before?
Yes, I received helpful feedback and encouragement.
Could a balanced thought be: “My professor is supportive; asking questions or making mistakes is part of learning”?
I always start assignments late and panic at the last minute.
It’s understandable to feel anxious about procrastination. What thought comes up when this happens?
That I’ll fail if I don’t start earlier.
Have you ever completed assignments successfully despite starting late?
Yes, I’ve managed to submit projects on time before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may start late sometimes, but I’ve still completed tasks successfully and can do so again”?
I’m afraid to speak up in seminar because I’ll sound dumb.
Feeling nervous about speaking is normal. What thought comes to mind when you fear sounding dumb?
That whatever I say will be wrong and everyone will judge me.
Have you ever contributed useful points even when unsure?
Yes, sometimes my comments sparked discussion.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even if I’m unsure, my contributions can be valuable and it’s okay to participate”?
I feel like my essays are never good enough.
It’s understandable to feel that way. What thought makes you feel your essays aren’t good enough?
That if it’s not perfect, it’s a failure.
Is it realistic to expect perfection every time?
No, nobody can be perfect all the time.
Could a balanced thought be: “My essays don’t need to be perfect to be valuable; I can improve them over time”?
I’m overwhelmed with multiple deadlines coming up.
It makes sense to feel stressed with many deadlines. What thought leads you to feel overwhelmed?
That I won’t be able to complete everything and will fail.
Have you handled multiple deadlines successfully before?
Yes, last semester I managed three major assignments at once.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have several tasks, but I’ve managed busy periods before and can organize my time to complete them”?
I can’t understand the readings and I’m falling behind.
It’s understandable to feel behind. What thought comes up when you struggle with readings?
That I’m not capable of keeping up with the class.
Have you successfully caught up with difficult material in the past?
Yes, I’ve reviewed notes and understood complex topics before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be behind now, but I have strategies to catch up and understand the material”?
I’m afraid my presentation will be boring.
It’s normal to worry about audience engagement. What thought makes you feel your presentation will be boring?
That people won’t pay attention and I’ll fail to communicate effectively.
Have there been times your presentations were interesting even when you were nervous?
Yes, my group presentations were well received before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be nervous, but I can make my presentation engaging as I have successfully done before”?
I didn’t study for a pop quiz and now I’m panicking.
It’s understandable to feel panicked. What thought comes up about the quiz?
That I’ll fail and ruin my grade.
Have you taken quizzes with little preparation before and still managed?
Yes, sometimes I did okay under pressure.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be unprepared, but I can do my best and it won’t ruin my grade entirely”?
I feel incompetent when I compare my grades to others.
It’s understandable to feel that way. What thought arises when you compare yourself?
That I’m not as capable as my classmates.
Have you achieved personal goals or improved despite comparisons?
Yes, I improved my test scores this semester.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’m making progress and achieving goals, and comparisons don’t define my abilities”?
I can’t seem to start my research paper.
It’s normal to feel stuck. What thought makes it hard to start?
That it’ll be terrible if I begin and I’ll fail.
Have you begun big assignments before and improved as you went?
Yes, drafting first and revising helped me succeed previously.
Could a balanced thought be: “Starting my paper may feel daunting, but I can draft and improve it step by step”?
I feel like I’ll never do well in this class.
It’s understandable to feel discouraged. What thought makes you feel you won’t do well?
That no matter how much I try, I’ll fail.
Have you succeeded in similar courses in the past?
Yes, I’ve passed other challenging courses.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’ve succeeded in difficult courses before, and with effort, I can do well in this class too”?
I feel anxious about asking questions in class.
It’s normal to feel anxious. What thought makes asking questions stressful?
That I’ll ask something dumb and everyone will judge me.
Have you asked questions before and benefited from it?
Yes, sometimes questions led to better understanding.
Could a balanced thought be: “Asking questions helps me learn, and it’s okay if they’re not perfect”?
I haven’t started studying for the final and I feel doomed.
Feeling overwhelmed is understandable. What thought makes you feel doomed?
That I’ll fail because I didn’t start sooner.
Have you studied under pressure before and still done okay?
Yes, I’ve managed last-minute exam prep successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even though I started late, I can focus and do my best on the final”?
I feel like I can’t improve my writing skills.
It’s normal to feel discouraged. What thought leads you to believe you can’t improve?
That I’m not talented enough to get better.
Have you seen improvement with practice before?
Yes, my writing has improved with feedback over time.
Could a balanced thought be: “I can improve my writing through practice and feedback, just as I have before”?
I didn’t participate today and I feel like I’m failing the class.
It’s normal to feel self-critical. What thought makes you feel that way?
That missing one participation opportunity shows I’m not capable.
Is it realistic that one absence defines your ability?
No, I usually participate regularly.
Could a balanced thought be: “Missing one participation doesn’t define me; I can engage in future sessions”?
I’m nervous about defending my thesis.
It’s natural to feel nervous about the defense. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’ll be asked something I don’t know and look incompetent.
Have you handled challenging questions in smaller presentations before?
Yes, during my proposal review I answered tough questions.
Could a balanced thought be: “I might face difficult questions, but I’ve handled them before and can prepare for this defense”?
I feel like I’ll never get a high grade on this assignment.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes you believe you won’t get a high grade?
That I’m not good enough to do well.
Have you received good grades on similar work before?
Yes, previous assignments got high marks.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’ve done well before and can put in effort to get a strong grade on this assignment too”?
I keep thinking I’m going to fail the final exam.
It’s understandable to feel worried about a big exam. What specific thought makes you feel like you’ll fail?
That I don’t know enough and I’ll freeze during the test.
Have you handled difficult exams successfully in the past?
Yes, I’ve passed other exams even when I was nervous.
Could a balanced thought be: “This exam is challenging, but I’ve succeeded on exams before and can focus on preparing effectively”?
I procrastinated on my project and now it feels impossible.
It’s normal to feel stressed about deadlines. What thought makes it feel impossible?
That I won’t finish in time and it will be a disaster.
Have you completed tasks under pressure before?
Yes, last semester I managed to finish a big assignment on time.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be behind, but I’ve handled tight deadlines before and can work step by step to finish”?
I’m afraid I’ll embarrass myself during my presentation.
It’s natural to feel nervous about public speaking. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’ll forget everything and look stupid.
Have you ever presented successfully despite feeling nervous?
Yes, in class presentations I managed to communicate well even when anxious.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I have presented successfully before and can do it again”?
I didn’t understand today’s lecture, so I’m probably failing.
It’s understandable to feel worried after struggling with a lecture. What thought leads you to feel you’re failing?
That if I didn’t get it now, I’ll never understand it.
Have you ever caught up on material after not understanding it initially?
Yes, I reviewed notes and learned tough topics before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I didn’t understand today, but I can review and learn it like I’ve done with other material”?
I feel like I’m not smart enough for this course.
It’s natural to feel inadequate sometimes. What thought makes you feel that way?
That I’ll never grasp the concepts and I’ll fail.
Have you learned difficult concepts successfully in the past?
Yes, previous subjects were challenging but I understood them eventually.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may struggle now, but I’ve learned difficult material before and can do it again”?
I always procrastinate and it makes me panic.
It’s understandable to feel anxious when procrastinating. What thought comes to mind in that situation?
That I’ll fail if I don’t start immediately.
Have you successfully completed tasks despite procrastinating before?
Yes, I’ve finished assignments under time pressure.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even if I start late, I can focus and complete my tasks successfully”?
I feel like my grades are never good enough.
It’s understandable to feel stressed about grades. What thought makes you feel they’re not good enough?
That anything less than an A is a failure.
Is it realistic to consider only perfect grades as acceptable?
No, that’s too extreme.
Could a balanced thought be: “My grades reflect my effort, and achieving less than perfect doesn’t mean failure”?
I feel like I’ll never finish my thesis on time.
Feeling pressured is normal. What thought makes you feel you won’t finish?
That there’s too much work and I’ll fail.
Have you handled large projects successfully before?
Yes, previous projects were completed on time.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I’ve handled big projects before and can manage my thesis step by step”?
I’m terrified of being called on in class.
It’s normal to feel anxious. What thought comes up when you’re called on?
That I’ll say something wrong and embarrass myself.
Have you answered questions correctly in class before?
Yes, sometimes I contributed helpful answers.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be nervous, but I’ve successfully answered questions before and can do it again”?
I didn’t start my essay yet, and I’m panicking.
It’s normal to feel stressed about deadlines. What thought leads to panic?
That I’ll fail if I don’t start now.
Have you completed assignments after starting late before?
Yes, I’ve submitted essays on time even when starting late.
Could a balanced thought be: “I haven’t started yet, but I can organize my time and complete the essay successfully”?
I feel like I’m terrible at group projects.
It’s understandable to feel anxious about collaboration. What thought makes you feel terrible at it?
That I’m slowing everyone down.
Have you contributed effectively to groups in the past?
Yes, I’ve completed my parts and helped teammates.
Could a balanced thought be: “I am contributing meaningfully to the group and can continue to improve”?
I didn’t understand the last lecture and feel lost.
It’s normal to feel that way. What thought comes up when you feel lost?
That I’ll never catch up and I’m falling behind.
Have you caught up after missing material before?
Yes, reviewing notes helped me understand past topics.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be behind now, but I can review and catch up with the material”?
I’m worried I’ll get a low grade on this test.
It’s natural to feel anxious about tests. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’m not prepared enough and will fail.
Have you done well on tests even when nervous or underprepared before?
Yes, I’ve managed similar situations successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel unprepared, but I can focus and do my best, and one test won’t define me”?
I haven’t done enough studying, so I’ll fail.
It’s understandable to feel anxious. What thought makes you believe you’ll fail?
That my effort so far isn’t sufficient.
Have you achieved good results even with limited preparation before?
Yes, sometimes studying efficiently worked well.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may have started late, but I can focus now and improve my performance”?
I feel anxious presenting in front of the class.
It’s normal to feel nervous. What thought comes up about presenting?
That I’ll make a mistake and everyone will judge me.
Have you presented successfully before despite nervousness?
Yes, my previous presentations went well.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel anxious, but I’ve presented successfully before and can do it again”?
I feel like my writing will never improve.
It’s normal to feel frustrated. What thought makes you believe your writing won’t improve?
That I’m not talented enough to get better.
Have you improved your writing skills in the past with practice?
Yes, I’ve improved essays over time with feedback.
Could a balanced thought be: “I can improve my writing through practice and feedback, as I have done before”?
I feel like I’ll never understand this subject.
It’s understandable to feel frustrated. What specific thought makes you feel that way?
That I’m not smart enough to grasp the concepts.
Have you successfully learned challenging material in the past?
Yes, I’ve managed difficult courses before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may struggle now, but I’ve learned difficult material before and can work through this subject too”?
I keep procrastinating and now I’m overwhelmed.
It’s normal to feel stressed when behind. What thought comes up when you procrastinate?
That I’ll fail because I didn’t start earlier.
Have you completed assignments successfully even when starting late?
Yes, I’ve managed deadlines under pressure before.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even if I started late, I can focus and complete tasks successfully”?
I feel anxious about participating in class.
It’s understandable to feel nervous. What thought arises when you consider participating?
That I’ll say something wrong and everyone will judge me.
Have you contributed successfully before even when nervous?
Yes, sometimes my input was appreciated.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but my contributions are valuable and it’s okay to participate”?
I’m scared I’ll fail my presentation.
It’s natural to feel anxious. What thought makes you feel you’ll fail?
That I’ll forget everything and embarrass myself.
Have you presented successfully before despite nerves?
Yes, I managed previous presentations well.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve handled presentations successfully before and can do it again”?
I didn’t do well on the last quiz, so I’m failing.
It’s normal to feel discouraged. What thought makes you believe you’re failing?
That one poor score means I can’t recover.
Have you improved your grades after low scores before?
Yes, I’ve raised my grades after bad quizzes.
Could a balanced thought be: “One quiz doesn’t define me; I can focus on upcoming work to improve my grade”?
I feel like I’m not cut out for university.
It’s understandable to have that thought sometimes. What specific thought makes you feel that way?
That everyone else is smarter and I don’t belong here.
Have you successfully handled university-level work before?
Yes, I’ve passed courses and met deadlines.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel unsure, but I’ve succeeded before and I belong here just like my peers”?
I feel like I can’t manage all my assignments.
It’s natural to feel stressed. What thought makes it feel unmanageable?
That I’ll fail if I don’t do everything perfectly.
Is it realistic to do everything perfectly all the time?
No, that’s impossible.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but doing my best is enough; I don’t need to be perfect at everything”?
I’m worried I’ll mess up my thesis defense.
Feeling nervous is normal. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’ll get a question I can’t answer and look incompetent.
Have you handled tough questions in presentations before?
Yes, during my proposal defense I answered challenging questions.
Could a balanced thought be: “I might face difficult questions, but I’ve handled them before and can prepare for this defense”?
I feel like I’ll never get a high grade in this class.
It’s normal to feel discouraged. What thought makes you think you won’t get a high grade?
That I’m not capable enough to achieve top grades.
Have you earned high grades in other courses before?
Yes, I’ve had A’s in previous classes.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’ve earned top grades before, and with effort, I can do well in this class too”?
I feel guilty for procrastinating on my research paper.
It’s understandable to feel guilty. What thought makes you feel that way?
That I’ll fail because I didn’t start earlier.
Have you completed large assignments after starting late before?
Yes, I’ve finished projects successfully under pressure.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may have procrastinated, but I can organize my time and complete the research paper successfully”?
I didn’t understand the last lecture and feel behind.
It’s normal to feel behind sometimes. What thought comes up when you feel lost?
That I’ll never catch up and will fail.
Have you caught up after struggling before?
Yes, reviewing notes and asking questions helped me understand past material.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be behind now, but I can review and catch up on the material”?
I feel like my writing is never good enough.
It’s understandable to feel frustrated. What thought makes you feel your writing isn’t good enough?
That if it’s not perfect, it’s a failure.
Is it realistic to expect perfection every time?
No, nobody is perfect.
Could a balanced thought be: “My writing doesn’t need to be perfect to be valuable; I can improve over time”?
I’m nervous about speaking in front of the class.
It’s normal to feel anxious about public speaking. What thought makes you nervous?
That I’ll say something wrong and everyone will judge me.
Have you spoken successfully in class before?
Yes, sometimes I communicated my points well despite nerves.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even if I feel nervous, I’ve spoken successfully before and can do it again”?
I feel like I can’t handle all my deadlines.
It’s natural to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes it seem unmanageable?
That I’ll fail if I don’t finish everything perfectly.
Is it realistic to do everything perfectly all the time?
No, that’s impossible.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have many tasks, but I can prioritize and doing my best is enough”?
I haven’t started studying for the exam and I’m panicking.
Feeling anxious is understandable. What thought makes you panic?
That I’ll fail because I didn’t prepare sooner.
Have you done well on exams even when starting late?
Yes, I’ve managed last-minute preparation successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may have started late, but I can focus now and do my best on the exam”?
I feel like I’ll never finish my assignments on time.
It’s normal to feel stressed. What thought makes you feel you can’t finish?
That there’s too much work and I’ll fail.
Have you handled heavy workloads before successfully?
Yes, I’ve managed multiple assignments before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I’ve handled heavy workloads before and can plan to finish on time”?
I feel anxious about asking questions in class. What if it's a stupid question?

That's a very common fear, and it's brave of you to articulate it. It sounds like you're worried about how others will perceive you. The specific thought is, 'What if it's a stupid question?' Let's explore that. What's the function of a question in a learning environment?
To clarify something you don't understand.
Exactly. Its purpose is to help you learn. Is it also possible that if you have a question, at least five other students are wondering the exact same thing but are too afraid to ask?
Yeah, I've heard that before. It could be true.

So, asking could be helping others as well. Let's try to reframe the thought. Instead of fearing a 'stupid question,' maybe it could be: 'My question is a tool for my learning. By asking it, I'm taking charge of my education and might even be helping my classmates.'?
I didn't participate in the discussion today and I feel like I'm failing the class.

It's easy to be hard on ourselves when we don't meet our own expectations for participation. I can understand why you'd feel that way. Let's look at the link you're making: 'not participating today' leads to 'failing the class'. Is participation the only factor in your final grade?
No, there are also essays and a final exam.
And how are you doing in those other areas? Have you completed the essays and are you preparing for the exam?
Yes, I'm on track with those.

That's great. So you have strong evidence that you are not failing. A more balanced thought might be: 'I'm disappointed I didn't participate today, and I'll aim to contribute next time. However, my grade also depends on essays and exams, where I am putting in the effort.'
I feel like I'll never get a high grade on this assignment. I'm just not good at this.

That sounds really discouraging, and it's valid to feel hopeless when you believe success is out of reach. The thought 'I'll never get a high grade' is a prediction that sounds very definite. Has there been any time in the past where you were surprised by a grade that was better than you expected?
Maybe on a smaller homework assignment once.

That's an important piece of evidence. It shows that your predictions aren't always 100% accurate. Instead of focusing on the final grade, what is one specific action you can take to improve one small part of the assignment?
I could read over the rubric again carefully.

That's a fantastic, concrete step. So, let's reframe the thought from 'I'll never get a high grade' to 'I'm feeling pessimistic, but I can't be certain of the outcome. I will focus on the process by carefully reviewing the rubric and doing the best I can on each section.'
I have to email my professor about an extension, but I'm too scared. They'll think I'm lazy and irresponsible.

It takes a lot of courage to ask for help, and it's completely understandable to worry about being judged. This is a classic 'mind-reading' thought—assuming you know what someone else will think. Can we brainstorm some alternative reasons why a student might need an extension?
They might have had a family emergency, or got sick, or have three other deadlines in the same week.

Exactly. There are many valid reasons that have nothing to do with being lazy. Professors handle these requests all the time. A more balanced thought could be: 'I have a valid reason for needing an extension. I will write a polite and professional email to explain my situation. How my professor responds is up to them, but asking for what I need is a responsible action.'
I feel like I’m not good enough to pass this class.
It’s understandable to feel that way. What thought comes up that makes you feel not good enough?
That I’ll fail no matter how hard I try.
Have you succeeded in challenging courses before?
Yes, I’ve passed difficult classes before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’ve succeeded before, and with effort, I can do well in this class too”?
I keep putting off my term paper and now I’m panicking.
It’s natural to feel stressed when behind. What thought comes up when you procrastinate?
That I won’t finish on time and it will be terrible.
Have you completed assignments successfully under pressure before?
Yes, last semester I finished a big paper on time.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be behind, but I’ve managed deadlines before and can organize to finish”?
I feel anxious about speaking in front of the class.
It’s normal to feel nervous. What thought comes up when you think about speaking?
That I’ll say something wrong and everyone will judge me.
Have you spoken in class successfully before?
Yes, I’ve shared my thoughts before and it went well.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be nervous, but my contributions are valuable and I can speak confidently”?
I didn’t do well on my last assignment, so I’m doomed.
It’s understandable to feel discouraged. What thought makes you feel doomed?
That one poor grade means I’ll fail the class.
Have you recovered from low grades before?
Yes, I improved in subsequent assignments.
Could a balanced thought be: “One low grade doesn’t define me; I can focus on future work to improve”?
I feel like I’m not smart enough for this program.
It’s natural to feel insecure sometimes. What thought leads you to feel that way?
That I’ll never understand the material and I’ll fail.
Have you learned difficult material before successfully?
Yes, I’ve mastered tough topics in other courses.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may struggle, but I’ve learned difficult concepts before and can do it again”?
I feel overwhelmed by my workload.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes it overwhelming?
That I won’t be able to finish everything on time.
Have you managed heavy workloads successfully before?
Yes, I’ve handled multiple deadlines before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I can prioritize and complete tasks effectively”?
I’m nervous about my final exam.
Feeling nervous is normal. What thought comes up that increases your anxiety?
That I’ll fail because the exam is too hard.
Have you succeeded in difficult exams before?
Yes, I’ve done well on challenging tests.
Could a balanced thought be: “The exam is difficult, but I’ve succeeded before and can prepare to do my best”?
I feel like my essays are never good enough.
It’s normal to feel self-critical. What thought makes you feel your essays aren’t good enough?
That if it’s not perfect, it’s a failure.
Is it realistic to expect perfection every time?
No, nobody can be perfect all the time.
Could a balanced thought be: “My essays don’t need to be perfect to be valuable; I can improve them over time”?
I haven’t started my term paper and I’m panicking.
It’s natural to feel stressed. What thought makes you panic?
That I won’t finish and will fail the course.
Have you completed major assignments after starting late before?
Yes, I’ve managed to finish projects on time.
Could a balanced thought be: “I haven’t started yet, but I can plan and complete the term paper successfully”?
I feel like I’ll embarrass myself during presentations.
It’s understandable to feel anxious. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’ll forget my points and everyone will judge me.
Have you handled presentations successfully before?
Yes, previous presentations went well despite nerves.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve presented successfully before and can do it again”?
I feel incompetent when comparing my grades to others.
It’s normal to feel that way sometimes. What thought comes up when you compare yourself?
That I’m not as smart as my classmates.
Have you achieved personal progress despite comparisons?
Yes, I’ve improved my scores and learned new topics.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’m making progress and comparisons don’t define my abilities”?
I haven’t started studying for my exam and I feel doomed.
It’s natural to feel stressed. What thought makes you feel doomed?
That I’ll fail because I didn’t prepare sooner.
Have you done well on exams even when starting late?
Yes, I’ve managed last-minute preparation before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may have started late, but I can focus now and do my best on the exam”?
I feel like my writing will never improve.
It’s normal to feel frustrated. What thought leads you to believe your writing won’t improve?
That I’m not talented enough to get better.
Have you improved your writing skills through practice before?
Yes, I’ve improved essays over time with feedback.
Could a balanced thought be: “I can improve my writing through practice and feedback, just as I have done before”?
I feel like I’ll never finish my thesis on time.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes you feel that way?
That there’s too much work and I won’t finish.
Have you completed large projects under pressure before?
Yes, I’ve successfully finished big projects before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I’ve handled large projects before and can manage my thesis step by step”?
I feel like I’ll embarrass myself in the seminar tomorrow.
It’s normal to feel nervous about speaking in front of others. What specific thought makes you feel you’ll embarrass yourself?
That I’ll forget what I want to say and everyone will notice.
Have you ever spoken in public successfully despite being nervous?
Yes, I’ve done class presentations and handled questions well.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be nervous, but I’ve presented successfully before and can prepare to do well again”?
I haven’t started my essay and now I’m panicking.
It’s natural to feel stressed when behind. What thought makes you panic?
That I’ll fail if I don’t start immediately.
Have you completed assignments under tight deadlines before?
Yes, I’ve managed essays under pressure before.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even though I started late, I can focus and complete the essay successfully”?
I feel like I’m not good enough for this course.
It’s normal to feel insecure sometimes. What thought makes you feel not good enough?
That everyone else is smarter and I’ll fail.
Have you succeeded in difficult courses before?
Yes, I’ve passed challenging subjects before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’ve succeeded before, and I can continue to do well in this course with effort”?
I feel anxious about my final exam.
Feeling anxious is normal. What thought makes you particularly worried about the exam?
That I haven’t studied enough and I’ll fail.
Have you succeeded on exams even when nervous or underprepared before?
Yes, I’ve done well under pressure in the past.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel anxious, but I’ve handled exams successfully before and can focus on preparing now”?
I feel like I’ll never finish my assignments on time.
It’s understandable to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes it seem impossible?
That there’s too much work and I can’t keep up.
Have you managed heavy workloads successfully before?
Yes, I’ve handled multiple deadlines in previous semesters.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I can prioritize and complete tasks step by step”?
I feel like I’m terrible at presentations.
It’s normal to feel anxious. What thought makes you feel terrible at presenting?
That I’ll forget everything and embarrass myself.
Have you presented successfully in the past despite nerves?
Yes, I’ve managed previous presentations well.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve presented successfully before and can do it again”?
I feel like I’ll never get a good grade on this project.
It’s understandable to feel anxious about grades. What thought leads you to feel you’ll get a bad grade?
That my work is not good enough.
Have you received positive feedback or good grades on similar work before?
Yes, I’ve done well on other projects.
Could a balanced thought be: “My previous work has been good, and with effort, I can do well on this project too”?
I haven’t started studying for the exam yet and I’m panicking.
Feeling stressed is natural. What thought comes up that makes you panic?
That I’ll fail because I haven’t prepared.
Have you succeeded on exams even when starting late before?
Yes, sometimes I managed last-minute preparation successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be behind, but I can focus now and do my best on the exam”?
I feel like my writing will never improve.
It’s normal to feel frustrated. What thought makes you feel that way?
That I’m not talented enough to get better.
Have you improved your writing skills in the past with practice?
Yes, with feedback and practice I’ve gotten better.
Could a balanced thought be: “I can improve my writing over time through practice and feedback, as I’ve done before”?
I feel like I’m not smart enough for this program.
It’s natural to feel insecure sometimes. What thought leads you to feel that way?
That I won’t understand the material and I’ll fail.
Have you learned difficult material successfully before?
Yes, I’ve mastered challenging subjects before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may struggle, but I’ve handled difficult material before and can do it again”?
I feel overwhelmed by my workload.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes it overwhelming?
That I won’t be able to finish everything on time.
Have you managed heavy workloads successfully before?
Yes, I’ve met deadlines and completed multiple assignments.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I can prioritize and complete tasks effectively”?
I feel anxious about my thesis defense.
Feeling nervous is normal. What thought makes you anxious about the defense?
That I’ll get a question I can’t answer and embarrass myself.
Have you handled tough questions in academic settings before?
Yes, I’ve answered challenging questions successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “I might face difficult questions, but I’ve handled them before and can prepare to do well”?
I feel like my grades are never good enough.
It’s normal to feel stressed about grades. What thought makes you feel that way?
That anything less than an A is a failure.
Is it realistic to expect perfection in every grade?
No, that’s too extreme.
Could a balanced thought be: “My grades reflect my effort, and achieving less than perfect doesn’t mean failure”?
I feel like I’ll never finish my thesis on time.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes you feel that way?
That the workload is too big and I won’t finish.
Have you completed large projects successfully before?
Yes, I’ve finished big projects under deadlines before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I’ve handled large projects before and can manage my thesis step by step”?
I feel like I’ll embarrass myself in class.
It’s normal to feel nervous. What thought makes you feel that way?
That I’ll say something wrong and everyone will notice.
Have you spoken successfully in class before?
Yes, I’ve shared answers and ideas successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve spoken successfully before and can participate confidently”?
I missed a lecture because I was sick, and now I feel like I'll never catch up. It's hopeless.

It's completely understandable to feel overwhelmed and a bit hopeless after missing a class. That feeling of being permanently behind is very stressful. The thought is 'I'll never catch up'. Is that a fact, or a feeling?
It feels like a fact. So much was covered.
I hear that. But what's one small, concrete action you could take to start bridging the gap? Not to close it completely, but just to start.
I could get the notes from a friend.

That's a perfect first step. So instead of 'I'll never catch up,' a more manageable thought is: 'I feel behind, but I can take the first step by getting the notes. From there, I'll identify what I don't understand and make a plan.'
My professor's feedback on my draft was so critical. I feel like they think I'm a terrible writer.

Receiving critical feedback can sting, even when it's meant to be helpful. It's valid to feel hurt by it. You're thinking 'they think I'm a terrible writer'. Is there another purpose for a professor giving detailed, critical feedback?
To help me make the paper better, I suppose.

Exactly. They are investing their time in your development. Someone who thought you were a lost cause might just give a grade and move on. So, a reframe could be: 'This feedback is tough, but it's a sign my professor is engaged with my work and sees potential for improvement. This is a tool for growth, not a judgment of my worth.'
I just feel empty. School, everything... what's the point? I don't think I can do this anymore.

Thank you for telling me this. It sounds like you are carrying an immense weight and are in a great deal of pain. My purpose is limited to academic stress, and what you're describing sounds like it needs more support than I can offer. For your safety and well-being, please reach out to a crisis support line or a mental health professional right away. You deserve immediate, real-world help.
I have to write a 10-page paper and I've been staring at a blank screen for an hour. I have no ideas.

The blank page can be incredibly intimidating. Feeling blocked and frustrated is a very common part of the writing process. The thought 'I have no ideas' feels very absolute. What if you lowered the stakes? Instead of writing the paper, what if you just wrote down 5 bad ideas about the topic?
Five bad ideas?

Yes. Sometimes the pressure to find a 'good' idea is what blocks us. Giving yourself permission to be 'bad' can unlock creativity. Instead of 'I have no ideas,' the reframe is: 'I'm feeling blocked by the need for a perfect idea. I will spend 10 minutes writing down any ideas that come to mind, no matter how silly, just to get started.'
My friend got an internship I was rejected from. They're so much more successful than me.

That's a tough situation, and it's completely normal to feel a mix of disappointment for yourself and complex feelings about your friend's success. The thought 'They're so much more successful' comes from comparing one specific outcome. Is this one internship the only measure of success in your life or career?
No, but it feels like a big one.

It's a big one, for sure. But your path is your own. If you were advising a friend, would you tell them their entire worth is based on one job application? Instead of comparing, could the thought be: 'I'm disappointed about this specific outcome, but I congratulate my friend. My journey is different, and I will focus on finding the next opportunity that aligns with my own path.'
I have to take this required statistics course, but I'm an art major. I'm going to fail because I'm just not a 'math person'.

It's really common to feel anxious about courses outside of your main field. That identity of not being a 'math person' can feel very real. Let's challenge that fixed mindset. Have you ever successfully learned something difficult that was new to you before, even outside of school?
I learned how to use a complicated new photo editing software.

That's perfect evidence! You can learn complex, logical systems. You have that skill. So, instead of 'I'm not a math person, so I'll fail,' a more helpful mindset is: 'This subject is new and challenging for me, but I have a track record of learning difficult new skills. I will approach this class with a beginner's mind and use resources like tutoring to succeed.'
I did well on the midterm, but I think it was just a fluke. I'll probably bomb the final.

It's interesting how our minds can sometimes discount our own successes. It's called 'disqualifying the positive.' You're feeling like your success was due to luck, not ability. What actual evidence do you have that it was a 'fluke'?
The questions just happened to be on the topics I studied most.

Is it possible that you made a smart, strategic choice to study those topics? Instead of luck, could it have been good judgment? A reframe might be: 'I feel like my success was lucky, but the evidence is that I studied and performed well. I can use the same judgment and work ethic to prepare for the final. My success was earned.'
My parents are so worried about my grades. I feel like I'm letting my whole family down.

That sounds like an immense amount of pressure. It's one thing to worry about your own grades, but feeling the weight of your family's expectations is another level of stress. My focus is on academic thoughts, and the one here is 'I'm letting my family down'. Can we explore that part?
Yeah, if I don't get a good job, I'll have wasted their investment.

That's a big leap from today's grades to your entire future career. Let's stay with the present. Is your worth as a son or daughter solely defined by your grade-point average? What else do you bring to your family?
I help out at home, I listen to them...

Exactly. Your relationship is much bigger than a transcript. A reframe could be: 'I feel pressure to meet my parents' academic expectations, and I'll do my best. However, my worth to my family is based on our entire relationship, not just my grades.'
I just submitted a huge assignment and now I'm completely convinced I missed a major requirement.

Ah, the post-submission panic. It's so common to feel a wave of anxiety right after you can no longer change anything. Your mind is replaying every possible mistake. The thought is 'I missed something major'. Let's be a detective. Did you check the rubric before submitting?
Yes, like, three times.

Okay, so you performed due diligence. You have evidence that you were careful. Instead of trusting the feeling of panic, can we trust the actions you took? A reframe could be: 'My anxiety is telling me I made a mistake, but the evidence is that I checked the rubric carefully multiple times. The task is done, and I will let go of worrying about what I can no longer control.'
I feel like I have to understand everything instantly in the lecture, and when I don't, I get lost and give up.

That's a huge amount of pressure to put on yourself. The expectation to understand complex topics instantly is unrealistic. It's completely normal for learning to be a process. The thought is 'I must understand this now'. What is the actual purpose of a lecture?
To introduce the material?

Precisely. It's the first exposure, not the final mastery. Mastery comes from reviewing, practicing, and asking questions later. Instead of 'I have to get this now,' can you reframe it as: 'My goal in this lecture is to listen for the main ideas and jot down things I don't understand. My understanding will be built later, during my own study time.'?
I chose my major but now I'm taking a class in it and it's so hard. I think I made a terrible mistake.

It's really unsettling to question such a big decision. It makes perfect sense to feel anxious if you're thinking 'I made a terrible mistake'. But is a single difficult class definitive proof that the entire field is wrong for you?
It feels like it. If I can't handle this, how can I do the rest?

That's a fair question. Let's look at it differently. Could this difficult class be a 'gatekeeper' course, designed to be challenging to build foundational skills? Or could it just be one particularly tough aspect of a much broader field? A reframe could be: 'This class is much harder than I expected, and it's making me question things. Instead of deciding I've made a huge mistake, I'll focus on passing this one class and gather more information before judging my entire choice.'
I'm in a group project and one member isn't doing anything. We're going to get a bad grade because of them.

Group projects with unresponsive members are incredibly frustrating. It's totally valid to feel angry and anxious about your grade being in someone else's hands. The thought is 'We're going to get a bad grade because of them'. This assumes you have no power in the situation. What is one thing you *can* control here?
I guess I could talk to the person, or talk to the professor.

Exactly. You have options. You are not powerless. Instead of focusing on the certainty of failure, let's focus on proactive steps. A more empowering thought is: 'This group situation is not ideal and it's causing me stress. I will take control of what I can by communicating directly with my group member and, if that fails, with my professor.'
I'm so tired. I pulled an all-nighter to finish a paper and now I have to go to class. I can't function like this.

That sounds physically and mentally draining. It's completely understandable that you feel you can't function. The thought is 'I can't function like this'. While it feels true, let's think about it in terms of harm reduction. What is the absolute minimum you need to accomplish today, and what can be let go?
I just have to show up to class so I'm marked as present. I don't think I can actually absorb anything.

Okay, so the goal has shifted. It's not 'learn everything in class,' it's 'be physically present.' That's a much more achievable goal. The reframe here is: 'I am exhausted from my choices last night. My goal for today is not peak performance, but survival. I will attend class to be marked present, and then I will prioritize getting rest as soon as I can.'
I feel like I don't have the same 'passion' for my subject as everyone else. Maybe I don't belong here.

It can feel isolating when it seems like everyone else has this deep, burning passion and you don't. That's a valid feeling. You're thinking 'I don't belong here' because your internal feelings don't seem to match others' external displays. Is it possible to be competent, skilled, and successful at something without feeling a constant state of 'passion'?
I guess so. Lots of people do jobs they're good at but not passionate about.

Exactly. Competence, interest, and curiosity are also incredibly valuable. Passion can also grow over time as you gain mastery. Instead of 'I don't belong because I lack passion,' a reframe could be: 'I am interested and capable in this subject. I will focus on building my skills and knowledge, and allow my feelings about it to evolve naturally without judgment.'
I got a 75 on a test. My life is over. I'll never get into grad school.

That's a very strong and painful reaction to a grade, and I can hear the distress in your words. It's called 'catastrophizing,' where our mind jumps to the absolute worst possible conclusion. The thought is 'My life is over'. Let's examine the evidence. Do grad schools look at a single test score, or do they look at an entire transcript, letters of recommendation, and personal statements?
They look at everything.

Correct. This one grade is just one data point among many. It does not have the power to decide your entire future. A more balanced thought would be: 'I am extremely disappointed with this 75, and it's okay to feel that way. However, it is one grade in a long academic career. I will focus on doing well in my other assignments and classes to present a strong overall application.'
I'm trying to network for jobs and I feel like such a fake. I'm just bothering people.

'Networking' can feel very unnatural and anxiety-provoking. It's normal to feel like you're an impostor or a burden. The thought is 'I'm bothering people'. Let's flip that. If a student who was polite and prepared reached out to you for a 15-minute chat about your career path, would you feel 'bothered'?
I'd probably be flattered and happy to help if I had time.

Most professionals feel the same way! They were once students too. Instead of seeing it as bothering them, you can reframe it as: 'I am reaching out to people to learn from their experience. This is a normal and accepted part of professional development. I am offering them a chance to share their wisdom, which many people enjoy doing.'
Everyone in my coding class seems to solve problems in minutes. It takes me hours. I'm just not cut out for this.

It's incredibly intimidating when it feels like everyone is moving faster than you. That comparison can lead right to the thought 'I'm not cut out for this.' But are you seeing their whole process? Or are you just seeing their final, successful result?
I'm just seeing them submit the answer on the class forum.

Right. You're comparing your 'behind-the-scenes' struggle to their 'highlight reel'. You don't see their own hours of confusion or the bugs they fought. A reframe could be: 'I can't know how long it truly took my classmates. I will stop comparing my process to their perceived results and focus on my own learning. The time it takes is less important than the fact that I am grappling with the material and eventually solving the problem.'
My roommate is always going out with friends and I'm always studying. I have no social life and I'm wasting my university experience.

It's really hard to feel like you're missing out, especially when you see a different lifestyle right in your own room. That's a painful comparison. While this touches on social life, let's focus on the academic part of the thought: you feel you are 'always studying'. Is that literally true, 24/7?
No, but it feels like it.

The feeling is powerful. But the reality is that you are making a choice to prioritize your studies. Is there a way to reframe this choice in a more positive light? Instead of 'I'm wasting my experience,' could it be: 'I am currently making a choice to dedicate a lot of time to my academic goals. This is a temporary phase. I can also schedule one small, social break this week to find a bit more balance.'?
I read the instructions for the assignment and I just don't get it. I feel so stupid.
It's frustrating when instructions themselves feel like a puzzle. It's a quick jump to feeling 'stupid', but let's pause on that. Is it possible for instructions to be poorly written or ambiguous?
Yeah, this professor is known for being a bit unclear.

There you go. The problem might be the instructions, not your intelligence. That's a crucial distinction. Instead of 'I'm stupid,' a more accurate thought is: 'These instructions are unclear to me. This is a common issue in this class. I will take the intelligent step of emailing the professor for clarification.' See how that shifts the power back to you?
I'm afraid to check my grades. I'm just going to keep the portal closed.

That feeling of dread is very real. Avoidance feels safer in the short term, doesn't it? It protects you from potential bad news. The thought is 'If I don't see it, it's not real'. But what are the long-term consequences of not knowing where you stand?
I won't know if I need to work harder or get help before it's too late.

Exactly. In the long run, avoidance can be more harmful. Knowledge, even if it's not what you hoped for, is power. A reframe could be: 'I am scared to see my grades, and that's okay. However, seeing them gives me the information I need to make smart choices for the rest of the semester. I will check them, take a deep breath, and then decide on a plan.'
I feel like I’ll never understand this chapter.
It’s normal to feel stuck sometimes. What thought makes you feel like you won’t understand it?
That I’m not smart enough to grasp the concepts.
Have you understood difficult chapters in the past?
Yes, I’ve learned tough material before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may struggle now, but I’ve learned challenging material before and can work through this chapter too”?
I keep procrastinating and now I’m panicking.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought comes up when you procrastinate?
That I’ll fail because I didn’t start earlier.
Have you completed assignments successfully even when starting late?
Yes, I’ve managed deadlines under pressure before.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even if I started late, I can focus and complete tasks successfully”?
I feel anxious about giving my presentation tomorrow.
It’s natural to feel nervous. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’ll forget what I want to say and look foolish.
Have you presented successfully despite nerves before?
Yes, I handled presentations well in the past.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve presented successfully before and can prepare to do well again”?
I feel like I’ll fail the next exam.
It’s normal to feel stressed about exams. What thought leads you to feel you’ll fail?
That the material is too hard for me.
Have you succeeded in difficult exams before?
Yes, I’ve done well on challenging exams before.
Could a balanced thought be: “The exam is difficult, but I’ve succeeded before and can prepare to do my best”?
I feel like I can’t keep up with all my assignments.
It’s understandable to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes it feel impossible?
That I’ll never finish everything on time.
Have you managed heavy workloads successfully before?
Yes, I’ve completed multiple assignments under pressure.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I can prioritize and complete tasks step by step”?
I feel like my essays are always bad.
It’s normal to feel self-critical. What thought makes you feel your essays are bad?
That they’ll never be good enough.
Have you improved your essays with practice before?
Yes, feedback and revisions helped me improve.
Could a balanced thought be: “My essays can improve over time with effort and feedback, as they have before”?
I feel nervous about answering questions in class.
It’s natural to feel anxious. What thought comes up when you think about answering questions?
That I’ll say something wrong and embarrass myself.
Have you answered questions successfully in class before?
Yes, I’ve participated and my answers were helpful.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even if I feel nervous, my answers are valuable and I can participate confidently”?
I feel like I’m not capable of finishing my thesis.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes you feel incapable?
That the work is too much for me.
Have you completed large projects under deadlines before?
Yes, I’ve finished significant projects successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I’ve managed big projects before and can tackle my thesis step by step”?
I feel like I’ll never get an A in this course.
It’s normal to feel stressed about grades. What thought makes you think you can’t get an A?
That I’m not good enough compared to my peers.
Have you achieved high grades in other courses before?
Yes, I’ve gotten A’s in previous classes.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’ve achieved high grades before, and with effort, I can do well in this course too”?
I feel overwhelmed with all my homework.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes it overwhelming?
That I can’t finish everything on time.
Have you managed heavy workloads before successfully?
Yes, I’ve handled multiple deadlines before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I can prioritize and finish my homework step by step”?
I feel like I’ll mess up my presentation.
It’s natural to feel nervous. What thought makes you feel you’ll mess up?
That I’ll forget my points and everyone will notice.
Have you presented successfully in the past despite nerves?
Yes, I’ve managed previous presentations well.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve presented successfully before and can do it again”?
I feel like my grades aren’t good enough.
It’s normal to feel concerned about grades. What thought makes you feel they aren’t good enough?
That anything less than perfect is a failure.
Is it realistic to expect perfection every time?
No, it’s unrealistic.
Could a balanced thought be: “My grades reflect effort, and I can learn and improve even if they aren’t perfect”?
I feel like I’ll never finish my term paper.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes you feel that way?
That the work is too much for me.
Have you completed big assignments successfully before?
Yes, I’ve managed large projects before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I’ve handled big projects before and can complete my term paper step by step”?
I feel like I’ll embarrass myself in class discussions.
It’s natural to feel anxious. What thought makes you feel you’ll embarrass yourself?
That I’ll say something wrong and everyone will notice.
Have you participated successfully in class before?
Yes, my contributions have been appreciated before.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even if I feel nervous, my ideas are valuable and I can participate confidently”?
I have a scholarship interview and I'm sure I'll say the wrong thing and blow it.

Interviews are definitely high-pressure situations, so it's completely normal to feel nervous. You're predicting a negative outcome: 'I'll say the wrong thing.' Let's examine that. Is there a single 'right' thing to say, or are they more interested in getting to know you as a person?
I guess they want to know who I am.

Exactly. So instead of a test with right/wrong answers, it's a conversation. A reframe could be: 'I feel nervous, but my goal is to genuinely share my experiences and goals. I can't control the outcome, but I can control being authentic.'
I'm taking an online class and I feel totally disconnected and lost. I'm not learning anything.

It can be very challenging to feel engaged in an online format. Feeling lost and disconnected is a common and valid experience. The thought is 'I'm not learning anything.' Is it possible that you are learning, but you miss the feedback and validation of an in-person class?
That could be it. I have no idea how I'm doing.

That makes sense. The issue is a lack of feedback, not a lack of learning. A more accurate thought might be: 'I find it hard to gauge my progress in this online class. I will take a proactive step by emailing the professor with a specific question or visiting virtual office hours to get the feedback I need.'
My lab partner is so much faster and more intuitive than me. I'm just slowing them down.

It's so easy to fall into that comparison trap, especially in a hands-on setting. Feeling like you're the slower partner is a tough spot to be in. The thought is 'I'm slowing them down.' Let's challenge that. Do different people bring different skills to a partnership? Maybe you are more methodical or better at documentation?
I am more careful with recording the results.

There you go. That's a vital skill that prevents errors. A partnership isn't a race. A good reframe would be: 'My partner and I have different strengths. They may be faster, but I bring valuable carefulness and accuracy to our work. We complement each other.'
I have to read a whole book in a week. It's impossible. Why do they assign this?

That does sound like a daunting amount of reading in a short time. Feeling that it's 'impossible' is a natural reaction to such a large task. But let's question that thought. Is the expectation to read every single word with deep focus, or could it be to understand the main arguments and themes?
I don't know, the professor just said 'read the book'.

In university, 'reading' can often mean 'skimming strategically'. Instead of 'this is impossible,' can we reframe it to a problem of strategy? The thought could be: 'Reading this entire book word-for-word is not feasible. I will learn how to read strategically by focusing on the introduction, conclusion, and first sentence of each paragraph to grasp the core ideas.'
I'm the first person in my family to go to university and I'm terrified of failing and disappointing everyone.

Being a first-generation student comes with a unique set of pressures, and that fear of letting everyone down is immense. It's completely valid. The thought is 'I'll disappoint everyone if I fail.' What have you already accomplished just by being here?
I got in, which was hard.

Exactly. You've already overcome huge hurdles and made them proud. Your journey here is a success in itself. Instead of focusing on potential failure, a reframe could be: 'I carry the hopes of my family, and that's a lot of pressure. But my being here is already a huge achievement. I will focus on doing my best day-by-day, and that effort is something to be proud of, regardless of the outcome.'
I don't feel motivated to study at all today. I'm just lazy.
Everyone has days with low motivation; that's just part of being human. Labeling yourself as 'lazy' is a harsh judgment. Does that label make you feel more or less likely to get started?
Less. It just makes me feel bad.

Right. Motivation often comes *after* starting, not before. The 'lazy' label is unhelpful. Let's try a more compassionate and practical thought: 'I'm not feeling motivated today, and that's okay. I will commit to doing just 15 minutes of my easiest task. If I still feel bad, I can stop, but I will try for just 15 minutes.'
I have to write a personal statement and I feel like my life is too boring. I have nothing interesting to say.

It's very common to feel that way when asked to write about yourself. We often discount our own experiences. The thought is 'my life is boring'. But 'interesting' is subjective. What is a challenge you have overcome, no matter how small it seems to you?
I learned to balance a part-time job while keeping my grades up.

That's not boring at all! That shows time management, responsibility, and resilience. Those are incredibly valuable qualities. A reframe could be: 'I may think my experiences are ordinary, but they demonstrate valuable skills like resilience and responsibility. I will focus on telling that story authentically.'
I completely blanked during that test. My mind just went empty. There's something wrong with my brain.

Test anxiety can absolutely cause your mind to go blank; it's a very real physiological response to stress, not a sign of a 'broken' brain. It's frustrating and scary when it happens. The thought is 'something is wrong with my brain'. Is it also possible that this was a response to intense pressure?
Yes, I was really panicking.

So, the cause was anxiety, not a fundamental flaw in your brain. That's good news because anxiety is manageable. A reframe could be: 'My anxiety was so high that it interfered with my ability to recall information. This is a common response. I can research and practice strategies for managing test anxiety before the next exam.'
I have so much reading to do, I'll never get through it. I might as well not even start.

That feeling of being completely swamped can be paralyzing. It's understandable to feel like giving up before you even begin. The thought is 'I might as well not start'. Let's challenge that. If you don't start, what is the guaranteed outcome?
That I'll have even more to do tomorrow.

Exactly. So not starting actually makes the situation worse. What if you read just one article? Or even just one page? A more helpful thought would be: 'I feel completely overwhelmed by the volume of reading. However, not starting guarantees I'll fall further behind. I will read for just 25 minutes, and that will be a victory for today.'
I changed my major and now I feel so far behind everyone else my age.
It's really tough to feel like you're on a different timeline than your peers. That feeling of being 'behind' is very real. But is university a race with a single finish line?
No, but it feels like it.

The feeling is valid, but the reality is that everyone has their own unique path. You made a brave choice to find a better fit for you. Instead of 'I'm behind,' could the reframe be: 'I am on my own unique academic path. I took the time to make a decision that was right for me, and that is a sign of maturity, not a delay.'?
My friends are all in serious relationships, and I'm just focused on school. Am I doing something wrong with my life?

It's very easy to compare our lives to others and feel like we're falling short. That sounds like an important concern, but my purpose is specifically to help with academic-related stress. Can we focus on the part of your thought that relates to your academic choices and how you feel about them?
Okay. I guess I feel like maybe I'm *too* focused on school.
