Thank you for clarifying. The thought is 'I'm too focused on school.' Is it possible that this is a season of your life where you are intentionally prioritizing your education to build a foundation for your future?
Yes, that's what I'm trying to do.

Then a reframe could be: 'I see my friends on different paths, and it makes me question my own. However, I am making a conscious and valid choice to dedicate this period of my life to my education. This is a different, but equally valuable, way of building a future.'
I just calculated my GPA and it's not high enough for the honor society. I'm a failure.

It's really disappointing when you miss a goal you've set for yourself. It's okay to feel let down. Labeling yourself a 'failure' over this is a very strong judgment. Is membership in the honor society the only possible measure of success and hard work in university?
No, I guess not. But it was a goal.

It was a goal, and it's okay to mourn that. But it's one goal among many. Have you learned a lot? Have you made good connections? Have you challenged yourself? A more balanced thought could be: 'I am disappointed I didn't qualify for the honor society. However, this one metric doesn't erase all the hard work I've done and everything I've learned. I am still a successful student.'
I hate asking for help. It feels like I'm admitting I'm not smart enough to do it on my own.

That's a very powerful and common belief. It ties asking for help directly to your sense of intelligence. Let's challenge that fundamental link. If you were building a house, would you think it was 'cheating' to hire an electrician, or would you see it as using an expert resource?
I'd see it as using a resource.

Exactly. Professors and TAs are expert resources for learning. Using them is a sign of intelligence and strategy, not weakness. A reframe could be: 'My old belief was that asking for help meant I was dumb. My new belief is that using available resources smartly is one of the most effective ways to learn and succeed.'
I'm afraid to pick a side in a class debate. What if I'm wrong?

That fear of being 'wrong' in a public forum can be really powerful. It makes perfect sense to feel hesitant. But what is the educational purpose of a debate? Is it to find one absolute 'truth' or to practice building and defending an argument?
To practice arguing, I guess.

Right. The skill you're being graded on is the *how*, not the *what*. It's about how well you use evidence and logic, not whether your side is morally 'right' or 'wrong'. A reframe could be: 'The goal of this debate is not to be right, but to practice the skill of argumentation. I will choose a side and focus on finding the best evidence to support it, like an attorney arguing a case.'
I'm trying to study but my mind keeps wandering to a fight I had with my friend. I can't focus at all.

It's incredibly difficult to force your brain to focus on academics when you're emotionally distressed about something else. It's like trying to run with a sprained ankle. What you're experiencing is normal. The thought is 'I can't focus'. What if you made a deal with your brain?
A deal?

Yes. Instead of fighting the distracting thoughts, acknowledge them. Try this thought: 'My mind is justifiably preoccupied with my friend right now. I will set a timer for 10 minutes to write down everything I'm feeling about that. Then, I will set another timer for 20 minutes to focus only on studying. I will give both things their own time.'
I got into my 'safety school,' not my dream school. I feel like a second-rate student.

That's a tough feeling, when reality doesn't match the dream you had. It's completely valid to feel disappointed and even a bit resentful. The thought 'I'm a second-rate student' ties your worth to a single admissions decision. But is it true that a great education and a great future can only happen at one specific place?
Probably not, but it feels that way.

The feeling is strong, but the evidence shows that success is about what you *do* at university, not just *where* you go. A helpful reframe could be: 'I am disappointed about not getting into my dream school. However, I have a fantastic opportunity here. My success will be defined by the effort I put in and the opportunities I seize at this university.'
The professor talks so fast, I can't get all the notes down. I'm going to miss something important and fail the exam.

Trying to take notes from a fast-talking professor is like trying to drink from a firehose. It's a stressful and frustrating experience. You're worried you'll miss a key piece of information. Is the goal of notetaking to create a perfect, word-for-word transcript?
No, it's to have something to study from.

Exactly. So the goal is comprehension, not transcription. What's a different strategy you could use? Could you focus on just writing down key concepts and questions to look up later? A reframe could be: 'I cannot physically write as fast as this professor speaks. Instead of trying to create a perfect transcript, my goal is to capture the main ideas, keywords, and any questions I have.'
My latest essay grade was lower than the last one. I'm going backwards.

It's really discouraging to see a grade drop and feel like you're regressing instead of improving. That's a valid concern. The thought is 'I'm going backwards.' Is academic progress always a straight, upward line?
No, I guess there are ups and downs.

Right. Progress often looks like two steps forward, one step back. Did this essay require different skills than the last one? Could the topic have been more challenging? A reframe could be: 'Seeing this lower grade is disappointing. However, learning isn't a straight line. I will analyze the feedback to understand what was different about this assignment and what new skill I need to work on.'
I have to email a researcher I admire to ask about their work, but I'm terrified. They're a genius and I'm just an undergrad.

It's completely normal to be intimidated when approaching someone you hold in high regard. The feeling is valid. The thought seems to be, 'I am not worthy of their time.' Let's challenge that. Do most successful researchers enjoy talking about their work? And do they remember what it was like to be a curious student?
Probably.

Yes. Your genuine interest is a compliment to them. Instead of focusing on your status versus theirs, focus on your shared interest. A good reframe is: 'I am intimidated, but my interest in this person's research is genuine and respectful. I will write a concise, specific, and polite email to show my curiosity. The worst that can happen is they don't reply.'
I waited too long to start this project and now I have to pull an all-nighter. I'm so irresponsible.

Facing an all-nighter because of procrastination is a tough spot, and it's easy to get into self-criticism. Labeling yourself 'irresponsible' might be true in this instance, but is it a helpful thought right now?
No, it just makes me feel stressed and angry at myself.

Exactly. Berating yourself won't get the project done faster. The situation is what it is. The most practical approach is to accept it and plan. A non-judgmental reframe could be: 'I made choices that led to this all-nighter. That's a fact. Beating myself up now is a waste of energy. My only focus now is to create a strategic plan to get as much quality work done as possible in the time I have left.'
I feel like I’ll fail my midterm no matter what.
It’s understandable to feel that way. What thought makes you feel you’ll fail?
That I haven’t studied enough and can’t catch up.
Have you passed exams before even when underprepared?
Yes, I’ve managed last-minute studying successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be behind, but I’ve handled exams before and can focus on preparing now”?
I keep procrastinating on my project and feel stressed.
It’s natural to feel stressed. What thought comes up when you procrastinate?
That I’ll fail if I don’t start immediately.
Have you completed tasks on time despite starting late before?
Yes, I’ve finished projects successfully even when starting late.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be behind, but I can organize and complete the project successfully”?
I feel like I don’t belong in this course.
It’s normal to feel uncertain sometimes. What thought makes you feel like you don’t belong?
That everyone else is smarter and I’ll fail.
Have you succeeded in challenging courses before?
Yes, I’ve managed difficult subjects before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel out of place, but I’ve succeeded before and can handle this course too”?
I’m anxious about giving a presentation.
It’s normal to feel nervous. What thought comes up that makes you anxious?
That I’ll forget my points and everyone will judge me.
Have you presented successfully before despite nerves?
Yes, previous presentations went fine.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be nervous, but I’ve presented successfully before and can do it again”?
I feel like my workload is too heavy to handle.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes the workload feel unmanageable?
That I won’t finish everything on time.
Have you managed heavy workloads before successfully?
Yes, I’ve completed multiple tasks under pressure.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I can prioritize and complete my tasks effectively”?
I feel like my essays are never good enough.
It’s normal to feel self-critical. What thought makes you feel your essays aren’t good enough?
That if it’s not perfect, it’s a failure.
Is it realistic to expect perfection every time?
No, that’s too extreme.
Could a balanced thought be: “My essays don’t need to be perfect to be valuable; I can improve them over time”?
I haven’t started studying yet and I feel doomed.
It’s natural to feel stressed. What thought makes you feel doomed?
That I’ll fail because I haven’t prepared.
Have you done well on exams even when starting late before?
Yes, sometimes last-minute studying worked for me.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may have started late, but I can focus now and do my best”?
I feel like I’ll never improve my writing.
It’s normal to feel frustrated. What thought leads you to believe you won’t improve?
That I’m not talented enough.
Have you improved with practice before?
Yes, I’ve gotten better with feedback and revisions.
Could a balanced thought be: “I can improve my writing through practice and feedback, as I’ve done before”?
I feel like I’m not smart enough for this program.
It’s natural to feel insecure. What thought makes you feel that way?
That I won’t understand the material and will fail.
Have you learned difficult material successfully before?
Yes, I’ve handled tough subjects before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may struggle, but I’ve handled difficult material before and can learn this too”?
I feel overwhelmed by my workload.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes it feel overwhelming?
That I won’t be able to finish everything on time.
Have you managed heavy workloads successfully before?
Yes, I’ve met deadlines and finished multiple tasks.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I can prioritize and finish each task step by step”?
I feel anxious about my final exam.
It’s natural to feel anxious. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’ll fail because the exam is too hard.
Have you succeeded in challenging exams before?
Yes, I’ve done well under pressure previously.
Could a balanced thought be: “The exam is challenging, but I’ve handled tough tests before and can prepare to do my best”?
I feel like I’ll embarrass myself in class.
It’s normal to feel nervous. What thought makes you feel that way?
That I’ll say something wrong and everyone will notice.
Have you participated successfully in class before?
Yes, I’ve shared answers and ideas successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even if I feel nervous, my contributions are valuable and I can participate confidently”?
I feel like I’ll never finish my thesis on time.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes you feel that way?
That the workload is too big for me.
Have you completed large projects under deadlines before?
Yes, I’ve finished significant projects before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I’ve handled big projects before and can manage my thesis step by step”?

That I haven’t studied enough and can’t catch up.

Yes, I’ve managed last-minute studying successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be behind, but I’ve handled exams before and can focus on preparing now”?

That I’ll fail if I don’t start immediately.

Yes, I’ve finished projects successfully even when starting late.

That everyone else is smarter and I’ll fail.

Yes, I’ve managed difficult subjects before.

That I’ll forget my points and everyone will judge me.
Have you presented successfully before despite nerves?
Yes, previous presentations went fine.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may be nervous, but I’ve presented successfully before and can do it again”?

That I won’t finish everything on time.
Have you managed heavy workloads before successfully?
Yes, I’ve completed multiple tasks under pressure.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I can prioritize and complete my tasks effectively”?

That if it’s not perfect, it’s a failure.
Is it realistic to expect perfection every time?
No, that’s too extreme.
Could a balanced thought be: “My essays don’t need to be perfect to be valuable; I can improve them over time”?

That I’ll fail because I haven’t prepared.
Have you done well on exams even when starting late before?
Yes, sometimes last-minute studying worked for me.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may have started late, but I can focus now and do my best”?

That I’m not talented enough.
Have you improved with practice before?
Yes, I’ve gotten better with feedback and revisions.
Could a balanced thought be: “I can improve my writing through practice and feedback, as I’ve done before”?

That I won’t understand the material and will fail.

Yes, I’ve handled tough subjects before.

That I won’t be able to finish everything on time.

Yes, I’ve met deadlines and finished multiple tasks.

It’s natural to feel anxious. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’ll fail because the exam is too hard.
Have you succeeded in challenging exams before?
Yes, I’ve done well under pressure previously.
Could a balanced thought be: “The exam is challenging, but I’ve handled tough tests before and can prepare to do my best”?

That I’ll say something wrong and everyone will notice.
Have you participated successfully in class before?
Yes, I’ve shared answers and ideas successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even if I feel nervous, my contributions are valuable and I can participate confidently”?
I feel like I’ll never finish my thesis on time.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes you feel that way?
That the workload is too big for me.
Have you completed large projects under deadlines before?
Yes, I’ve finished significant projects before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I’ve handled big projects before and can manage my thesis step by step”?
I feel like I’m going to fail my group project.
It’s natural to feel anxious. What thought comes up that makes you feel you’ll fail?
That I won’t contribute enough and let my team down.
Have you successfully contributed to group projects before?
Yes, I’ve worked well with teams in the past.
Could a balanced thought be: “I’ve successfully contributed before, and I can do my part in this project too”?
I feel like I’ll embarrass myself during my presentation.
It’s normal to feel nervous. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’ll forget my points and everyone will notice.
Have you presented before successfully despite nerves?
Yes, my previous presentations went well.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve presented successfully before and can prepare to do well again”?
I have to choose a topic for my thesis and I'm paralyzed. What if I pick the wrong one and waste a year of my life?

That's a huge decision, and it's completely normal to feel paralyzed by the fear of making the 'wrong' choice. The thought 'I'll waste a year of my life' is a catastrophizing thought. Is a thesis topic a life sentence, or is there room to pivot and adjust as you research?
I guess research can change direction.

Exactly. The goal is to start with a good-enough topic, not a perfect one. A reframe could be: 'Choosing a thesis topic is a big step, but it is not an unchangeable destiny. I will choose the most interesting topic to me right now, knowing that my research path may evolve.'
I have to do a peer review for a classmate's paper. What if I'm too critical and they hate me?

It's very thoughtful of you to be concerned about your classmate's feelings. That's a sign of empathy. The fear is that 'they will hate me' if you are critical. What is the actual, stated purpose of a peer review in an academic setting?
To help them improve their paper.

Precisely. Your role is to provide constructive feedback, not to pass personal judgment. You can be both critical and kind. A helpful reframe might be: 'My role is to offer constructive help. I will frame my feedback by focusing on the writing, not the writer, using phrases like 'This argument could be stronger if...' to be both helpful and kind.'
This class is graded on a curve and it makes me so anxious. I'm not just learning, I'm competing against everyone.

Grading on a curve introduces a layer of competition that can be incredibly stressful. It's completely valid to feel anxious about that. The thought seems to be 'I have to beat others to succeed.' Where can you actually focus your energy: on controlling what others do, or on your own work?
Only on my own work.

That's the key. While the curve is a factor, your primary locus of control is your own effort and understanding. A good reframe could be: 'The curve is a source of my anxiety, and I cannot control it. I will release the need to compete and focus 100% of my energy on producing my own best work and mastering the material. That is the only part I can control.'
I'm a really slow reader. It takes me forever to get through the assigned chapters, I can't keep up.

It's frustrating to feel like you're not keeping pace with the workload. The label 'I'm a slow reader' can feel very permanent. But is reading speed the only measure of a good reader? What about comprehension and retention?
I do tend to remember what I read pretty well.

That's a major strength! So you're not a 'slow' reader, you're a 'deep' reader. Instead of viewing your pace as a weakness, can we reframe it as a different style? The thought could be: 'I read more slowly than others, but I have strong comprehension. I will explore strategies like skimming for main ideas first, so I can dedicate my deep-reading time to the most important sections.'
I got an unexpected 'C' on an assignment I thought I did well on. The professor must be biased or just doesn't like me.

That's a really jarring experience, to have your expectation mismatch reality so much. It's understandable to feel confused and look for a reason. The thought 'the professor doesn't like me' is a form of mind-reading. Before concluding that, what's a more direct way to understand the grade?
I could look at the feedback or ask them about it.

Exactly. Jumping to a conclusion about their feelings is less productive than seeking data. A reframe could be: 'I am surprised and disappointed by this grade. Instead of assuming it's personal, I will take the professional step of carefully reading the feedback and, if it's still unclear, asking the professor for clarification on how I can improve next time.'
I have to cite my sources and I'm terrified I'll make a mistake and be accused of plagiarism.

That's a very serious and valid fear. The consequences of plagiarism are significant, so it makes sense to be anxious about getting it right. The fear is that one mistake equals a major accusation. What is the difference between an accidental citation error and intentional plagiarism?
Intent, I guess. I'm not trying to cheat.

Right. And universities understand that. They see accidental errors all the time. A good reframe is: 'I take academic integrity very seriously. Because of this, I will be extra diligent, use a citation manager, and double-check my sources. I trust that my good-faith effort to cite correctly will be recognized.'
I'm in my final year and I have no idea what I want to do with my life. I feel like a failure already.

The pressure to have your whole life figured out by graduation is immense and unrealistic. It's completely normal to feel lost. The thought 'I'm a failure already' ties your entire self-worth to having a career plan right now. Is that a fair expectation to have of yourself?
Probably not. Most people don't have it all figured out.

Exactly. The next step isn't to have a 'life plan,' it's just to figure out the 'next step.' A reframe could be: 'It's okay that I don't know my entire career path. My only goal right now is to explore one potential next step, like talking to the career center or researching one industry I'm curious about.'
I'm trying to study in the library but it's so quiet I feel like everyone can hear me breathe. I can't focus.

That feeling of being 'on display' in a quiet space is a real form of social anxiety. It's hard to focus on your work when you're focused on yourself. The thought is 'everyone can hear me and is paying attention to me.' Let's challenge that. Realistically, what is every other person in the library focused on?
Their own work, I guess. Their own finals.

Right. They are in their own world, just as you are. You are likely not on their radar at all. A reframe could be: 'My anxiety is telling me I'm the center of attention, but the logical evidence is that everyone is focused on their own tasks. I will gently redirect my focus back to my work each time this thought appears.'
The professor called on me and I didn't know the answer. It was so embarrassing.

That's a classic university anxiety dream come to life! It's completely normal to feel embarrassed in that moment. The feeling is valid. But what is the long-term impact of that one moment? Will anyone, including the professor, remember this by next week?
Probably not.

Correct. It feels huge now, but its actual importance is very small. A reframe could be: 'That moment was embarrassing and I didn't enjoy it. However, it was a low-stakes event that has no bearing on my grade or my intelligence. I will let it go and focus on the next class.'
I have to write an email to a potential supervisor for grad school. I've rewritten it 20 times. It has to be perfect.
The pressure for that email to be perfect is immense, because it feels like so much is riding on it. This is a form of perfectionism. What's the cost of waiting for it to be 'perfect'?
That I'll never actually send it.
Exactly. 'Perfect' becomes the enemy of 'done.' What is a more realistic goal for this email? Could it be 'clear, concise, and respectful'?
Yes, that's more achievable.

So, let's reframe the goal. Instead of 'This must be perfect,' the thought is: 'My goal is to send a clear, concise, and respectful email. I will review it one more time for typos and then send it. Done is better than perfect.'
I feel guilty for taking a break to watch a movie. I should be studying.
That's a common feeling, that any time not spent studying is 'wasted' time. But let's challenge that thought. Is rest a waste of time, or is it a necessary part of being able to study effectively?
I guess I can't study 24/7.

Right. Your brain is like a muscle; it needs recovery time to perform well. Burnout is a much bigger threat to your grades than taking a planned break. A reframe could be: 'This break is not laziness; it is a strategic part of my study plan. By resting my mind now, I am ensuring I can learn more effectively tomorrow.'
I'm struggling because my roommate is always having people over and being loud. I can't study and my grades are suffering.

That sounds like a really difficult and frustrating living situation. It's hard to focus when your environment is disruptive. While that's a very real problem, my purpose here is to focus on the academic-related thoughts. The thought seems to be 'I can't study because of my roommate.' Is it 100% impossible to study?
Well, I can't study in my room.

Thank you for clarifying. The problem is location-specific. This moves the problem from 'impossible' to 'a practical challenge.' A reframe could be: 'My room is not a productive study space right now. I will take control of the situation by finding alternative locations, like the library or an empty classroom, to do my work effectively.'
I'm worried about the cost of tuition and my student loans. The financial pressure is making it hard to focus on my actual classes.

Financial pressure is a huge and very real burden that absolutely impacts your ability to focus. That's not a failure on your part; it's a legitimate and heavy stressor. Acknowledging that is important. Can we focus on what part of this is within your control right now, today?
I don't know, it all feels out of my control.

You can't magically erase the debt, but can you control your next action? For example, could you schedule a 30-minute appointment with the financial aid office to understand your options? A reframe could be: 'This financial stress is real and significant. I will acknowledge the worry, and then channel that energy into one small, controllable action. Today, my only task is to book an appointment to get more information.'
I was accepted to a program, but I didn't get any scholarship money. I feel like they accepted me out of pity.

That's a painful thought, to have a huge success like an acceptance be immediately undermined by a feeling of not being 'good enough' for funding. Let's examine that. Are admissions decisions and funding decisions always made by the same people or from the same budget?
I don't know. Probably not.

They are often separate processes. Admissions decides if you are qualified. Funding decides if they have money available. One is about your merit, the other is about their budget. A reframe could be: 'My acceptance was a validation of my academic merit. The funding decision was a separate, logistical issue related to the university's budget. I will not let a budget decision invalidate my acceptance.'
I don't know how to start this essay. I just don't have a 'thesis'.
The pressure to find that one perfect sentence can be very paralyzing. It feels like you can't start until you have it. But does a thesis statement have to be the first thing you write?
I thought so.

Many writers find their thesis *after* they've done some writing and exploration. It emerges from the mess. Instead of trying to start with the thesis, what if you just started writing about the topic freely for 15 minutes? A reframe could be: 'I don't need a perfect thesis to begin. I will start by 'free-writing' about my topic to explore my ideas. My thesis statement will become clearer once I have something on the page to work with.'
I have a group presentation and I'm scared one of my members will say something wrong and make us all look bad.

That's a common fear in group work—that your grade is vulnerable to someone else's mistake. It's a loss of control that feels very uncomfortable. The thought is 'one person can make us all look bad'. What is a realistic way to minimize that risk?
We could practice together beforehand.

That's a perfect, proactive strategy. You're taking control of the situation. A reframe could be: 'I am anxious about my group members' performance. Instead of just worrying, I will take the lead and suggest one or two full practice run-throughs so we can all give feedback and be on the same page.'
I'm applying for jobs and I feel like a fraud. My GPA is okay but I don't have any 'real world' experience.

'Imposter syndrome' is incredibly common when transitioning from academia to the professional world. It's easy to discount your own experiences. The thought is 'I have no real experience.' But let's challenge that. Have you ever worked on a long-term project? Managed deadlines? Collaborated with a team?
Yes, in my classes.

Then you have experience in project management and teamwork. That is 'real world' experience. A reframe could be: 'I may not have traditional job experience, but I have developed valuable skills like project management, research, and collaboration through my academic work. I will focus on learning how to translate these skills into language that employers understand.'
I have to write a two-page reflection paper, and I don't know what to say. It feels so pointless.
It can be hard to get motivated for an assignment that feels vague or 'pointless'. I understand that. But what might the professor's educational goal be for assigning a reflection paper?
To see if we're thinking about the material, I guess.

Exactly. It's about process, not just facts. So, instead of 'this is pointless,' a reframe could be: 'The goal of this paper is for me to explore my own thinking process. I will start by asking myself one question: What was the most surprising or confusing idea from the recent lectures? And I'll write from there.'
I'm so far in debt, this degree is going to ruin me. The pressure is crushing. It's not worth it.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like you are under an immense amount of pressure and pain, and it's completely overwhelming you. The thought that 'it's not worth it' sounds like you are in a state of despair. My role is limited, and for the level of pain you're describing, you deserve immediate, real-world support. Please consider contacting a crisis hotline or a mental health professional. Your safety is the most important thing.
My parents are both doctors and I'm struggling in biology. I'm clearly not smart enough to carry on the family legacy.

That's an incredible amount of pressure to live up to. It's completely understandable to feel like you're failing if you're comparing yourself to their level of mastery. The thought is 'I'm not smart enough'. Were your parents experts in biology when they were 19 or 20 years old?
No, of course not.

You are comparing your beginning to their end result. It's an unfair comparison. A more balanced thought could be: 'I am at the beginning of my own journey. It is unfair and unhelpful to compare my current struggles to my parents' decades of experience. I will focus on my own learning process.'
I fell asleep in class today. The professor definitely saw me. They must think I'm so disrespectful.

That's an awkward and embarrassing moment for sure. It's easy to jump to the conclusion that the professor thinks you're disrespectful. But let's brainstorm other possible interpretations. What could a professor think when they see a student fall asleep?
That I was up all night studying?

That's a very likely one. They know students are overworked. They might also think you're not feeling well. Assuming disrespect is the worst-case scenario. A reframe could be: 'I'm embarrassed that I fell asleep. While it's possible my professor saw me, I can't know what they thought. It's more likely they assumed I was exhausted than that they made a judgment about my character. I will let it go.'
I just looked at the syllabus for next semester and it looks so hard. I'm already anxious and it hasn't even started.

That's called 'anticipatory anxiety,' and it's very common. Your brain is trying to protect you by predicting future threats. The thought is 'This will be too hard.' What do you actually know about the difficulty, versus what you are imagining?
I'm just imagining it based on the reading list and topic names.

So you're reacting to a story you're telling yourself. The story might be true, but it might not. A reframe for now could be: 'I'm noticing I'm feeling anxious about a future challenge. That's my brain trying to protect me. For now, I will acknowledge the feeling and gently remind myself that I only have to deal with today's challenges. I will cross that bridge when I come to it.'
I was assigned a partner for a project and I don't think they're very smart. We're doomed.

It's stressful to feel like your grade is tied to someone you don't have confidence in. It's a feeling of losing control. The thought 'we're doomed' is a prediction of failure. What is within your control in this situation?
I can try to set clear expectations and divide the work up based on our strengths.

That's a great, proactive leadership strategy. Instead of passively accepting failure, you're actively managing the situation. A reframe could be: 'I have concerns about this partnership. Instead of worrying, I will take a leadership role by proposing a clear work plan. I will give my partner a chance to succeed before assuming failure.'
I just have no creative ideas for this art project. My mind is a blank.

The pressure to be 'creative' on demand can be the biggest enemy of creativity. It's normal to feel blank. The thought is 'I have no ideas.' What if you changed the goal from 'have a creative idea' to 'do a creative exercise'?
What do you mean?

Instead of trying to find the final idea, just play. Spend 20 minutes sketching random shapes, or mixing colors without a goal. A reframe could be: 'I'm trying too hard to find a final idea. I will give myself permission to play without a goal for 30 minutes to see what emerges. The goal is process, not product.'
I have three exams in two days. It's not fair. I can't possibly prepare for all of them.

That schedule is brutal, and it's completely fair to feel that it's unjust and overwhelming. The thought is 'I can't possibly prepare'. This 'all or nothing' thought can be paralyzing. Is there a middle ground between 'perfectly prepared' and 'not prepared at all'?
I could probably be well-prepared for one, and decently prepared for the other two.

That sounds like a strategic and realistic plan. It's triage. A reframe could be: 'This situation is not ideal, but it is what it is. I cannot be perfectly prepared for all three. I will make a strategic 'triage' plan to allocate my time effectively and maximize my potential score across all exams, rather than giving up.'
I'm trying to use the university's research database and it's so confusing. I feel technologically incompetent.

Those academic databases can have a very steep learning curve. They're often not very user-friendly. It's easy to internalize that frustration and feel 'incompetent'. But is it more likely that you're incompetent, or that the software is poorly designed?
Honestly, the interface is terrible.

Then let's place the blame where it belongs: on the bad design, not on you. This is a common problem for all students. A reframe could be: 'This software is confusing and not intuitive. My frustration is a normal response to bad design. I will take the smart step of looking for a tutorial or asking a librarian for help.'
I got into an argument in a class discussion. Now I feel like everyone thinks I'm a jerk.

It's very uncomfortable to feel like a disagreement has turned into a personal conflict. Worrying about how the whole class sees you is understandable. The thought is 'everyone thinks I'm a jerk'. Is it possible to disagree with someone's idea without disliking them as a person?
Yes, I do that all the time.

So it's reasonable to assume your classmates can do the same. They likely interpreted it as a debate about ideas, not a personal attack. A reframe could be: 'I am worried I came off as aggressive. However, the context was an academic debate. I will trust that my classmates are able to separate a disagreement over ideas from a personal judgment.'
I got a grant to do research this summer, but I feel like I don't deserve it. They probably made a mistake.

That's a classic case of 'imposter syndrome,' where a major success is immediately followed by a feeling of being a fraud. It's very common. The thought is 'they made a mistake'. What is the more likely scenario: that a committee of experts all made a mistake, or that they saw genuine potential in your proposal?
I guess it's more likely they saw something they liked.

Exactly. Trust the experts' judgment over your feeling of self-doubt. A reframe could be: 'My anxiety is telling me I'm a fraud, but the evidence is that a panel of experts reviewed my application and decided it was worthy of funding. I will choose to trust their judgment and focus on living up to the opportunity they've given me.'
I have to give a presentation on Zoom and I'm scared of the awkward silences.

Virtual presentations have their own special kind of anxiety, and that fear of 'awkward silence' is at the top of the list. It's a valid concern. But what does silence mean in a virtual setting? Does it always mean people are bored?
It could mean they're thinking, or maybe their mic is muted.

Exactly. There are many technical and neutral reasons for silence. It's not automatically negative. A good reframe could be: 'I will feel nervous if there is silence. I will remind myself that silence is not necessarily negative in a virtual setting. I can even plan for it by saying 'I'll pause for a moment to let you all gather your thoughts' to control the space.'
I keep re-reading the same sentence and not absorbing it. My brain is broken today.
That's a very frustrating feeling, when your brain just won't cooperate. It's easy to jump to 'my brain is broken.' But is it possible your brain is just tired, or under-stimulated?
I am pretty tired.

A tired brain can't form new connections easily. This isn't a permanent state; it's a temporary condition. A more compassionate reframe would be: 'My brain is having trouble focusing right now, likely because it is tired. I will take a 10-minute break to walk around and get a glass of water, and then try again. I will work with my brain's current state, not against it.'
I'm worried about choosing my courses for next year. What if I pick the wrong ones and it messes up my graduation plan?
That's a very valid and practical concern. The fear of making a mistake with administrative requirements is real. But is this a decision you have to make completely alone and without any resources?
No, I could meet with my academic advisor.

That's the key. This isn't a test of your knowledge; it's a planning task. Using your advisor is the 'smart' move. A reframe could be: 'I am anxious about making a mistake in my course planning. Therefore, I will take the responsible and effective step of scheduling a meeting with my academic advisor to review my plan and ensure I'm on track.'
I'm home for the holidays and my family keeps asking about my grades. I feel like I'm under a microscope.

That sounds very stressful. It can feel like your grades are your entire identity when you're home. While family dynamics are complex, let's focus on the academic thought. The thought might be, 'My worth to my family is tied to my grades.' Is that true?
I don't think so, but it's all they ask about.

They might ask about it because it's the main thing they know about your current life, and it's their way of showing they care, even if it feels like pressure. A reframe could be: 'My family's questions come from a place of interest, even if it feels like judgment. My grades are a part of my life, not my entire identity. I can briefly answer and then pivot the conversation to another topic.'
I'm not a 'natural' writer. It takes me so long to write an essay that others do in a few hours.

The myth of the 'natural' writer causes a lot of anxiety. The truth is, for most people, writing is a slow and difficult process. You are comparing your reality to a myth. The thought is 'It takes me too long'. Compared to whom? And do you know for a fact how long it takes others?
No, I'm just assuming.

Right. You're comparing yourself to an imagined standard. The only valid comparison is the quality of the final product. A good reframe is: 'My writing process may be slower than others, and that's okay. What matters is the final essay. I will respect my own process and give myself the time I need to do my best work.'
I have to participate in an online discussion forum, but my ideas feel too simple compared to what others are posting.

It can be really intimidating to post after others have written long, complex comments. It's easy to feel like your contribution isn't valuable. The thought is 'my ideas are too simple.' But can a 'simple' idea be valuable?
Maybe, if it's clear.

Absolutely. Sometimes a clear, concise, or foundational point is exactly what a discussion needs. Not every comment needs to be a mini-dissertation. A reframe could be: 'My goal is to contribute to the conversation. A clear and relevant point is just as valuable as a complex one. I will confidently share my idea.'
I feel like I'm always tired and I don't have the energy to do my schoolwork properly.

Constant fatigue is a huge barrier to academic success. It's valid to feel that you can't perform at your best. This is a very real, physical issue. While I can't give medical advice, we can address the thought. The thought might be 'I am failing because I'm tired.' What is one small thing you could do to address the cause—the fatigue?
I could try to go to bed 30 minutes earlier tonight.

That's a perfect, manageable step. A reframe could be: 'I recognize that my fatigue is impacting my work. Instead of blaming myself for not performing well, I will take one small, kind step to address the root cause by prioritizing a little more sleep tonight.'
I'm trying to study with flashcards, but I keep getting them wrong. This isn't working. I'm just not learning.
That's a frustrating experience. It can feel like you're spinning your wheels. The thought is 'this isn't working'. But what is the actual purpose of getting a flashcard wrong?
To show me what I don't know yet.

Exactly! Getting it wrong is a vital part of the process. It's a signal, not a failure. Each wrong answer tells you exactly where to focus your attention. A reframe could be: 'Getting a flashcard wrong is not a failure; it is a successful identification of a weak spot. Each mistake is a valuable piece of data that guides my studying.'
I have a friend who never seems to study but always gets good grades. It makes me feel stupid.
That can be so frustrating and confusing. It's easy to see that and conclude that they're just 'smarter' and you're not. But are you seeing the full picture of their work?
I don't know. I just don't see them studying.

You are comparing your visible effort to their invisible effort. It's possible they are very efficient, or study at odd hours, or have a strong background in the subject. You can't know. A reframe could be: 'I cannot know what my friend's process truly is. Comparing myself to my perception of them is unhelpful and makes me feel bad. I will focus only on my own process and what works for me.'
I'm worried about graduating. The 'real world' seems terrifying and I don't feel prepared at all.

The transition from the structured world of university to the 'real world' is a major source of anxiety for almost everyone. It's completely normal to feel unprepared. The thought is 'I'm not prepared'. But has your entire university experience taught you nothing?
It's taught me how to learn and solve problems.

Those are the most critical skills of all! You are more prepared than you think. A reframe could be: 'While I don't know exactly what to expect after graduation, my university experience has equipped me with the core skills of learning and problem-solving. I am prepared to figure it out, just as I've figured out every challenge so far.'
My professor has a really thick accent and I'm struggling to understand the lectures. I'm going to fail because I can't even understand them.

That's a legitimate logistical challenge that can be very stressful. It's not a reflection on you. The thought is 'I'm going to fail because I can't understand'. This assumes you only have one resource for learning—the live lecture. What are some other resources available to you?
The textbook, the lecture slides, and maybe a TA.

Excellent. You have multiple backup systems. A reframe could be: 'Understanding this professor's accent is difficult for me, and that is a challenge. However, the lecture is only one resource. I will proactively use the textbook and slides to supplement my understanding and ensure I learn the material.'
I have to work a part-time job to afford school, so I have less time to study than other students. It's an unfair disadvantage.

You are absolutely right, that is a significant challenge and it is an unfair disadvantage compared to students who don't have to work. It's valid to feel frustrated about that. The thought is 'it's an unfair disadvantage.' While true, is this thought helpful or does it just create more stress?
It just makes me angry.
Right. We can acknowledge the unfairness, and then shift focus to what you are gaining. What skills are you learning from your job that other students are not?
Time management, responsibility, dealing with customers.

Those are invaluable 'real-world' skills. A reframe could be: 'While having less study time is a challenge, my job is also providing me with practical skills that will make me a stronger candidate after graduation. I am learning different, but equally important, lessons.'
I'm reading the feedback on my paper and I just feel defensive and angry. I don't want to even look at it.

That's a very normal, human reaction. Criticism, even when constructive, can feel like an attack. It's okay to feel defensive. The key is what you do with that feeling. What is the purpose of the feedback?
To help me get a better grade on the next one.

Exactly. It's a tool for you, even if it's a painful one. A reframe could be: 'I'm feeling defensive right now, and that's my ego trying to protect me. I will acknowledge that feeling, take a few deep breaths, and then try to read the feedback again with a 'growth mindset', looking only for actionable advice I can use.'
I'm trying to decide on a graduate program and I'm overwhelmed by all the options. What if I choose the wrong one?

'Analysis paralysis' is a real phenomenon. When faced with too many choices, it can be impossible to make any. The fear of 'choosing the wrong one' is powerful. But are these choices really a matter of 'right' and 'wrong', or are they just different paths?
Different paths, I guess.

Right. There are likely many programs where you could be happy and successful. Instead of looking for the one 'perfect' path, can you identify your top three priorities? A reframe could be: 'There is no single 'right' choice. I will simplify my decision by identifying my top three criteria (e.g., location, faculty, cost) and then choose the option that best fits those, trusting that it will be a good path for me.'
I feel like I have to be 'on' and productive every single day, and on days I'm not, I feel like a failure.

That expectation of 100% productivity every day is a recipe for burnout. It's an impossible standard. It's normal to have days where you feel 'off'. The thought is 'if I'm not productive, I'm a failure.' Is a professional athlete a failure if they have an off day or take a rest day?
No, it's part of their process.

Your brain is no different. Rest and lower-energy days are part of a sustainable process. A reframe could be: 'My energy and focus will naturally fluctuate. An 'off' day is not a sign of failure; it is a signal from my body and mind that rest is needed. I will honor that need so I can be effective on my 'on' days.'
I'm taking a summer course and it's so condensed. I feel like I'm not actually learning, just memorizing to survive.

Summer courses are incredibly intense. That feeling of 'cramming' rather than deep learning is a very common and valid complaint. The thought is 'I'm not actually learning.' Let's challenge that. Is it possible to learn foundational concepts even in a condensed format, which you can build on later?
Maybe. I'm learning the keywords at least.

Keywords are the building blocks. A reframe could be: 'This condensed format is not ideal for deep learning. My goal is to master the core concepts and vocabulary right now. I am building a foundation that I can deepen with further study later on.'
I have a terrible grade in one class. It's going to tank my whole GPA.

It's very stressful to see one bad grade and feel it's pulling everything down. It can feel like it negates all your other hard work. The thought is 'it's going to tank my GPA'. Have you done the actual math to see what the impact will be?
No, I'm too scared to.

Often the imagined impact is much worse than the mathematical reality. Facing the numbers is a way to challenge the fear. A reframe could be: 'I am scared of what this grade will do to my GPA. Instead of worrying about the imagined catastrophe, I will take a deep breath and use a GPA calculator to see the actual, factual impact. Once I have the data, I can make a real plan.'
I'm the treasurer for a student club and I'm terrified of messing up the budget.

Taking on a position of responsibility like that is commendable, and it's completely normal to feel anxious about making a mistake. The fear is about 'messing up'. What's a practical step you could take to minimize the risk of errors?
I could ask last year's treasurer for their spreadsheets, or have another exec member double-check my work.

Those are both excellent, responsible strategies. You're building a safety net. A reframe could be: 'I am feeling the pressure of this responsibility. Instead of just worrying, I will act responsibly by using existing resources and asking for a second opinion on my work. Good processes prevent mistakes.'
My creative writing professor said my story was 'a little cliché'. I feel like I have no original ideas.

Oof, that's tough feedback to hear, and it's easy to generalize it to your entire creative ability. The thought is 'I have no original ideas.' But let's look closer. Is 'a little cliché' the same as 'completely unoriginal and terrible'?
No, it's less harsh.

Right. It's specific feedback on one element, not a judgment of your soul. Almost all writers start with cliché ideas and learn to add their unique voice. A reframe could be: 'This feedback pointed out a cliché element in my story. That's a common issue for developing writers. This is a great opportunity for me to practice taking a familiar idea and adding my own unique twist to it.'
I have to write an annotated bibliography and it seems like so much tedious work. I can't get started.

That's a very common reaction. Annotated bibliographies can feel like academic busywork, and it's hard to get motivated for something tedious. What is the actual skill that this assignment is designed to teach?
How to evaluate sources, I guess.

Exactly. It's a foundational research skill. Instead of seeing it as one giant, tedious task, what if you saw it as a series of small, separate tasks? A reframe could be: 'This feels tedious, but it's teaching me a core research skill. My only goal for the next 30 minutes is not to 'do the whole thing', but just to find and summarize one single source. I can handle one.'
I have a final exam that's worth 50% of my grade. If I mess this up, the whole semester was a waste.

That's an immense amount of pressure on one exam. It's completely understandable to feel like everything is riding on this. The thought is 'the whole semester was a waste' if this one exam goes poorly. Is the grade the only thing you gained this semester?
What do you mean?
Did you learn new concepts, develop any skills, or gain any insights, regardless of the final grade? Is that knowledge truly 'wasted'?
No, I did learn a lot. I just want the grade to show for it.

The desire for a good grade is valid. But let's separate the learning from the grade. A more balanced thought could be: 'This exam is very important for my grade, and I will prepare seriously for it. However, the knowledge and skills I've gained this semester have value in themselves, and that cannot be erased by a single exam score.'
I'm the only one in my friend group who doesn't have a summer internship lined up. I feel like such a loser.

It's really tough to feel like you're the only one left behind while your friends are moving on to the next step. That's a painful and isolating feeling. The thought 'I'm a loser' is a very harsh self-judgment. Is getting a summer internship the only measure of a person's worth or future success?
No, but it feels like it right now.

Feelings aren't always facts. A summer can be used for many valuable things: taking a summer course, working a different kind of job, learning a new skill, or even just resting. A reframe could be: 'I'm disappointed I don't have an internship this summer, and it's okay to feel that way. However, I will use this summer for other valuable activities that also contribute to my growth.'
My professor uses cold calling in class and it terrifies me. I spend the whole lecture just worrying I'll be next.

That's a very stressful classroom environment. When you're consumed by anxiety about being called on, it's impossible to actually learn. The thought is 'I'm just waiting for my turn to be humiliated.' What is the most realistic outcome if you are called on and don't know the answer?
The professor would probably just move on to someone else.

Exactly. The imagined catastrophe is much bigger than the likely reality. A helpful reframe could be: 'I find cold calling very stressful. I will remind myself that the most likely outcome of not knowing an answer is neutral and brief. I will try to redirect my focus to the lecture content itself, even if it's for 5 minutes at a time.'
I'm trying to study for a test with a friend, and they keep explaining things to me. I feel like they think I'm an idiot.

That can be an uncomfortable dynamic. It's easy to interpret someone explaining things as a judgment on your intelligence. The thought is 'they think I'm an idiot'. What's another possible reason why your friend might be explaining things?
Maybe explaining it helps them solidify their own understanding?

That's a very common and highly effective learning technique—'learning by teaching.' It might not be about you at all. A reframe could be: 'When my friend explains concepts to me, I feel self-conscious. However, it's very likely they are doing it to reinforce their own learning, a common study method. This isn't a judgment on me.'
I have to write a formal lab report and I find it so boring and difficult. I'm just not a scientific writer.

Formal scientific writing is a very specific and often unnatural style. It's valid to find it difficult if it's not your usual mode of expression. The thought 'I'm not a scientific writer' treats it like an innate talent. What if we viewed it as a skill to be learned, like a recipe?
Like a recipe?

Yes. A lab report has a structure: Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion. It's a formula. Instead of 'I'm not a scientific writer,' the reframe could be: 'Scientific writing is a technical skill I haven't mastered yet. I will focus on learning the 'recipe' and following the structure, section by section, rather than worrying about having a 'talent' for it.'
I procrastinated on a project and now the deadline is tomorrow. I hate myself for doing this again.

That feeling of self-loathing when you're up against a deadline because of procrastination is awful. The cycle is exhausting. The thought 'I hate myself' is understandable, but is it helpful right now? Does it give you energy to work?
No, it just makes me want to give up.

Exactly. We can't change the past few weeks, but we can change the next few hours. Let's practice radical acceptance for a moment. A reframe could be: 'I made choices that led me to this stressful situation. I can analyze why later. For the next 12 hours, my only job is to focus completely on the task at hand, without wasting energy on self-blame.'
I feel like I'm bothering my professor by going to their office hours. They're probably busy.

It's very considerate of you to be mindful of your professor's time. However, the thought 'I'm bothering them' misinterprets the purpose of office hours. Why do universities require professors to hold office hours?
So students can get help.

Exactly. It is a scheduled and paid part of their job. You are not an interruption; you are the entire point of that scheduled time. A reframe could be: 'Attending office hours is not 'bothering' my professor; it is using a resource that has been specifically created for my benefit. It is a sign of an engaged student.'
I was checking my student loan balance and now I'm so anxious I can't think about anything else. My future feels hopeless.

Seeing that number can be incredibly overwhelming and can certainly cast a dark cloud over everything. It makes perfect sense that you feel anxious and hopeless. That's a very real stressor. While I can't give financial advice, we can work with the thought. The thought is 'my future is hopeless'. Is that 100% true, or are there steps, however small, that can be taken over time?
I guess there are repayment plans and things.

Right. The problem is huge, but it's not hopeless. It's a challenge to be managed over many years. A reframe for this moment could be: 'This number is scary and the feeling of hopelessness is powerful. But this is a long-term problem with long-term solutions. For today, I will acknowledge the fear, and then redirect my focus to the one task I can control right now: my next assignment.'
I want to change my major, but I'd be a year behind my friends. It would be embarrassing.

That fear of being 'left behind' by your peers is very powerful. It's natural to worry about how it will look. But let's challenge the premise. Is education a race against your friends, or is it about building the right foundation for your own future, which will last for decades?
The foundation for my future, obviously.

So, what is truly more 'embarrassing' in the long run: taking an extra year to get on the right path, or spending 40 years in a career you dislike because you were afraid of what your friends would think for a semester? A reframe could be: 'Taking an extra year feels embarrassing in the short term, but making a decision that's right for my own long-term happiness and career satisfaction is a sign of maturity and courage.'
This textbook is so dense, I have to re-read every paragraph five times. I must be a slow learner.

That sounds incredibly frustrating and inefficient. It's easy to blame yourself and think 'I'm a slow learner' when the material is difficult. But let's place the blame where it might belong. Is it possible the textbook is just poorly written and overly academic?
It's not very engaging, for sure.

So the problem might be the material, not the learner. Instead of 'I'm a slow learner,' the thought could be: 'This textbook is not written in a way that's easy for me to absorb. I will supplement it with other resources, like online videos or a study guide, that explain the same concepts in a different way.' That shifts the problem from your identity to your strategy.
I'm trying to make friends in my classes, but I feel so awkward starting conversations.

That's a very common anxiety. It can be tough to put yourself out there. While this is about social connection, it directly impacts your sense of belonging at university, which affects your studies. The thought seems to be 'I'm awkward'. What's a low-stakes way to start a conversation with a classmate?
I could ask them what they thought of the homework.

That's a perfect, topic-relevant opener. The focus is on the shared experience, not on you. A reframe could be: 'Initiating conversations feels awkward. I will start with a simple, low-stakes question about our shared classwork. This is a normal way to build a connection and doesn't require me to be perfectly smooth.'
I don't understand what the professor wants for this essay. The prompt is so vague. I'm going to fail because I don't know what to write.

Ambiguous instructions are a recipe for anxiety. It's completely valid to feel lost and worried when you don't know the target you're supposed to hit. The thought 'I'm going to fail' assumes you have no way to get clarity. What's the most direct way to solve the problem of a vague prompt?
Ask the professor to clarify what they're looking for.

Exactly. This isn't a test of your mind-reading ability. Asking for clarification is an intelligent and proactive step. A reframe could be: 'This prompt is vague, which is causing me anxiety. Instead of guessing and worrying, I will take the responsible step of asking the professor for clarification so I can do my best work.'
I'm supposed to be studying, but I just keep scrolling on my phone. I have no self-control.

That's a very common struggle. The phone is designed to be more engaging than a textbook. Beating yourself up by saying 'I have no self-control' usually just leads to more guilt and more scrolling. Does that thought help you put the phone down?
No, it makes it worse.

Right. Let's try a practical strategy instead of a self-judgment. A reframe could be: 'My phone is a powerful distraction. Instead of relying on willpower alone, I will change my environment. For the next 30 minutes, I will put my phone in another room or turn it completely off.'
I'm the first one in my group to finish my part of the project. Now I'm worried I did it too fast and missed something.

It's interesting how our brains can turn a positive, like being efficient, into a source of anxiety. The thought is 'I did it too fast, so it must be wrong.' Is speed inherently linked to low quality?
Not always, I guess.

You could be efficient because you understood the task well. Instead of assuming there's an error, what's a productive way to use your extra time? A reframe could be: 'I finished my portion efficiently. I will use this extra time not to worry, but to proactively double-check my work against the rubric and offer to help a teammate. My efficiency is an advantage.'
My friends are all taking really impressive, high-paying majors like engineering and I'm here in philosophy. I feel like I'm making a bad life choice.

It's easy to compare majors based on perceived prestige or future salary and feel like yours doesn't measure up. That's a valid concern. But is starting salary the only measure of a successful career or a happy life?
No. I really love philosophy.
And what skills is philosophy teaching you? Critical thinking, complex argumentation, clear writing?
Yes, all of those.

Those are incredibly valuable and transferable skills in any profession. A reframe could be: 'I am choosing a major I am passionate about that teaches me valuable, lifelong skills. Success can be defined in many ways, and I will focus on how my unique path prepares me for a thoughtful and fulfilling career.'
I have to give a speech in a foreign language class. I'm scared everyone will laugh at my accent.

That's an incredibly vulnerable position to be in. Speaking a non-native language requires immense courage. The fear of being laughed at is very real. But let's think about the context. In a language class, what is everyone there to do?
Learn the language.

Exactly. Everyone in that room is a learner. Everyone has an accent. An accent is not a mistake; it's a sign that you know another language. A reframe could be: 'My accent is a sign of my bilingualism, not a source of shame. Everyone in this class is a learner, and my goal is to communicate my ideas, not to sound like a native speaker.'
I want to apply for a competitive scholarship, but I probably won't get it. There's no point in trying.

That's your mind trying to protect you from the potential pain of rejection. It's a very common thought. But let's look at the logic. The thought is 'there's no point in trying.' If you don't apply, what is the chance you will get it?
Zero.
And if you do apply, what is the chance?
Greater than zero.

Exactly. By not applying, you guarantee the outcome you're afraid of. By applying, you create a possibility. A reframe could be: 'I am afraid of being rejected, and that's okay. But not applying is a guaranteed 'no.' I will focus on putting together the best application I can, because that is the only part I can control. The outcome is not my decision, but the effort is.'
I got a lower grade on my essay than my roommate, even though we studied together. They're just smarter than me.

That's a really tough and direct comparison that would make anyone feel bad. It's easy to jump to the conclusion that it's a simple matter of intelligence. But are grades a pure measure of intelligence? Or do they also reflect things like writing style, interpretation, and maybe even what the specific grader was looking for that day?
I guess it's not just about being smart.

Right. There are many variables. Comparing yourself is a recipe for misery. A reframe could be: 'It is painful that I got a lower grade. However, instead of comparing myself to my roommate and making a judgment about my intelligence, I will focus on the actionable feedback from my professor to understand what I can do differently next time.'
I'm so stressed about my future that I'm completely unable to get my work done now. It's a vicious cycle.

That is a classic anxiety cycle. The worry about the future paralyzes you in the present, which then gives you more to worry about. It's exhausting. The key is to break the cycle by shrinking your focus. Can you solve your entire future today?
No.
Can you complete one small reading for your next class in the next hour?
Yes, probably.

That's the only goal then. A reframe for this moment is: 'My anxiety about the future is overwhelming me. I will consciously put those big thoughts aside for now and shrink my world to one single, manageable task. My only job for the next hour is to complete this one reading.'
I just feel like I'm drowning. Every time I finish one assignment, two more appear. It never ends.

That feeling of being on a never-ending treadmill is a hallmark of burnout. It's completely valid to feel like you're drowning. The thought 'it never ends' is part of that feeling. While it feels true, is there a scheduled break coming up? A weekend? A fall or winter break?
Yeah, fall break is in two weeks.

Okay, so there is a tangible end point. There is a shore. A reframe could be: 'I feel like I'm drowning right now, and that feeling is real. However, the calendar shows that a break is coming. My goal is not to solve everything forever; it is to keep my head above water for the next two weeks until I can get to shore and rest.'
I feel like I’m not capable of handling all my assignments.
It’s understandable to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes you feel incapable?
That there’s too much work and I’ll fall behind.
Have you managed a heavy workload successfully before?
Yes, I’ve balanced multiple assignments before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I can manage it by prioritizing and taking it step by step”?
I feel like I’ll never understand this lecture.
It’s normal to feel stuck sometimes. What thought comes to mind when you feel that way?
That I’m not smart enough to grasp the content.
Have you understood complex lectures before?
Yes, I’ve learned difficult material before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may struggle now, but I’ve understood complex material before and can work through this lecture too”?
I feel anxious about my upcoming exam.
It’s normal to feel nervous. What thought specifically worries you?
That I’ll fail no matter how much I study.
Have you passed exams before even when you felt uncertain?
Yes, I’ve done well under pressure in the past.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel anxious, but I’ve passed exams before and can prepare to do my best this time”?
I feel like my grades are never good enough.
It’s normal to feel concerned about grades. What thought makes you feel that way?
That anything less than perfect is a failure.
Is it realistic to expect perfection every time?
No, that’s too extreme.
Could a balanced thought be: “My grades reflect my effort, and I can learn and improve even if they aren’t perfect”?
I feel like I’ll embarrass myself during class discussions.
It’s normal to feel nervous. What thought makes you feel that way?
That I’ll say something wrong and everyone will notice.
Have you participated successfully in class before?
Yes, my contributions have been well-received before.
Could a balanced thought be: “Even if I feel nervous, my ideas are valuable and I can participate confidently”?
I feel overwhelmed by my term paper.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes it feel overwhelming?
That I won’t be able to finish it on time.
Have you completed large projects under deadlines before?
Yes, I’ve finished significant assignments successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “I have a lot to do, but I’ve completed big projects before and can manage this paper step by step”?
I feel like I’m not good at public speaking.
It’s natural to feel anxious. What thought makes you feel that way?
That I’ll forget my points and look foolish.
Have you spoken in public before and handled it well?
Yes, I’ve managed presentations successfully.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve handled presentations before and can do well again”?
I feel like I’ll never finish studying all the material.
It’s normal to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes it feel impossible?
That there’s too much to learn and I can’t keep up.
Have you studied large amounts of material successfully before?
Yes, I’ve managed extensive study sessions before.
Could a balanced thought be: “There’s a lot to cover, but I’ve handled large amounts of material before and can plan to study effectively”?
I feel like I’ll fail my project presentation.
It’s normal to feel nervous. What thought comes up that makes you feel you’ll fail?
That I won’t explain everything clearly and will look unprepared.
Have you presented projects successfully before?
Yes, I’ve managed project presentations well.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may feel nervous, but I’ve presented projects successfully before and can prepare to do well”?
I feel like my thesis is too difficult.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes it seem too difficult?
That I won’t be able to complete it properly.
Have you handled large, challenging projects before?
Yes, I’ve successfully completed complex projects.
Could a balanced thought be: “The thesis is challenging, but I’ve managed difficult projects before and can handle this step by step”?
I feel like I’ll never improve my study habits.
It’s normal to feel discouraged sometimes. What thought makes you feel that way?
That I’m not disciplined enough to change.
Have you improved your habits or routines in the past?
Yes, I’ve successfully built better routines before.
Could a balanced thought be: “I can improve my study habits gradually, as I’ve successfully changed routines before”?
I feel like I’ll fail my math exam.
It’s normal to feel anxious. What thought specifically worries you?
That I don’t understand the formulas well enough.
Have you succeeded in understanding and applying formulas before?
Yes, with practice I’ve done fine in the past.
Could a balanced thought be: “I may struggle, but with practice I’ve handled formulas before and can prepare for this exam”?
I feel like my essays will never be good enough.
It’s normal to feel self-critical. What thought leads you to feel that way?
That if it’s not perfect, it’s worthless.
Is it realistic to expect perfection every time?
No, that’s unrealistic.
Could a balanced thought be: “My essays don’t need to be perfect to be valuable; I can improve them with effort”?
I have a presentation in a huge lecture hall. I'm scared I'll freeze up when I see all those people.

Presenting to a large audience can feel incredibly intimidating. It's very normal to worry about freezing up. The specific thought is 'I'll freeze when I see all those people.' What are some strategies you could use to manage that feeling in the moment?
I could focus on one friendly face in the crowd, or just look at the back wall.

Those are excellent, practical strategies. You're not trying to eliminate the fear, but to manage it. A reframe could be: 'I know that I feel anxious in front of large crowds. Therefore, I will go in with a clear strategy to manage that feeling by focusing on a specific spot or friendly face. I have a plan to handle the anxiety.'
My professor is really smart and accomplished. I'm too intimidated to ask them a question.

It's completely normal to feel intimidated by someone with a lot of expertise. That feeling is very common. The thought is 'I'm too intimidated to ask.' But what is a professor's role in relation to their students?
To teach them.

Exactly. Your questions are the primary tool they have to know if their teaching is effective. Your curiosity is essential to the process. A reframe could be: 'While I find my professor's expertise intimidating, their primary role is to teach me. My questions are a necessary part of that process, not an annoyance.'
I got a comment on my paper that just says 'unclear'. I don't know what it means and I feel hopeless.

That kind of vague feedback is incredibly frustrating and unhelpful. It's understandable to feel hopeless when you don't know how to improve. The thought is 'I'm hopeless because I don't understand.' But this is a problem of missing information. What's the most direct way to get that information?
Email the professor and ask which part was unclear.

Precisely. This isn't a personal failure; it's a communication gap. A reframe could be: 'This feedback is not actionable, which is frustrating. I will take the professional step of asking for specific clarification so that I can make the necessary improvements. I am seeking data, not admitting defeat.'
I'm trying to study for my history exam, but I just find the material so boring. I can't make myself care.

It's very difficult to study material that you don't find intrinsically interesting. Forcing yourself to care is exhausting. The thought is 'I can't care about this.' But do you need to 'care' about it personally to pass the exam?
No, I just need to know the information.

Right. Let's reframe the goal. The goal is not 'develop a passion for history,' but 'learn this specific information for the exam.' A different approach could be: 'I don't find this material engaging. I will treat it like a puzzle or a game, focusing on the challenge of memorizing the facts I need to succeed, rather than trying to force an emotional connection to it.'
I have a take-home exam and it feels like a trap. The questions are probably going to be impossibly hard.

Take-home exams can feel very ambiguous, and that uncertainty can create a lot of anxiety. You're anticipating the worst-case scenario. The thought is 'the questions will be impossibly hard.' Why might a professor assign a take-home exam instead of an in-class one?
So we can use our notes and take more time to think.

Exactly. It's often designed to test deeper thinking, not just memorization. The format is an advantage. A reframe could be: 'This take-home exam format is different and that makes me nervous. However, it's designed to allow me to use my resources and think deeply, which are my strengths. I will see it as an opportunity, not a trap.'
My friends are all traveling and having fun, and I'm stuck here taking summer classes. I feel like I'm missing out on my youth.

That's a tough feeling, especially when you see their fun on social media. That 'fear of missing out' is very real and painful. The thought is 'I'm missing out.' Let's reframe the situation. You are making a short-term sacrifice for what long-term gain?
To graduate earlier or lighten my load for the fall semester.

So you are strategically investing in your future self. That's a very mature choice. A reframe could be: 'I feel a pang of jealousy seeing my friends travel. I will acknowledge that feeling, and then remind myself that I am making a smart, strategic choice for my long-term academic goals. My time for travel will come.'
I have to write a biography paper, but I feel like I don't know the person well enough. I'm going to misrepresent them.

That's a very conscientious thought. It shows you have a high degree of integrity and want to do justice to your subject. The fear is 'I'll misrepresent them.' But what is the nature of a biography? Is it to capture a perfect, objective truth, or is it to present an interpretation based on available evidence?
An interpretation based on evidence.

Exactly. Your job is not to be a mind-reader, but to be a good researcher. A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to capture this person's soul, but to build a well-supported interpretation based on my research. I will focus on the quality of my evidence and my argument, and trust that this is the purpose of the assignment.'
I keep getting distracted by notifications on my laptop while I'm in a Zoom lecture. I'm a bad student.

Those notifications are designed by teams of experts to be distracting. It's not a personal failing on your part; you're fighting against a very powerful system. Labeling yourself a 'bad student' is unhelpful. What's a practical, environmental change you can make?
I could close all other tabs and turn on 'Do Not Disturb' mode.

That's a perfect strategy. You're taking control of your environment instead of just relying on willpower. A reframe could be: 'I recognize that notifications are a powerful distraction. Instead of blaming myself, I will take the practical step of creating a distraction-free digital environment during my lectures.'
The reading for my philosophy class is like another language. I don't understand any of it. I'm not smart enough for this.

Academic philosophy is notorious for being dense and difficult. It's very common to feel completely lost at first. You are not alone in that. The thought 'I'm not smart enough' connects this difficulty to your identity. But what if the problem is just that you haven't learned the 'language' yet?
What do you mean?

Like learning French, you need to learn the vocabulary and grammar of philosophy. A reframe could be: 'I am new to the language of academic philosophy. It's okay that I don't understand it all at once. I will focus on learning the key terms and concepts, just like I would with any new language.'
I got a really good grade on my last project. I'm scared I can't live up to that on the next one.

That's a surprising source of stress, isn't it? The fear of not being able to replicate your own success. It's a lot of pressure. The thought is 'I can't live up to that.' But what did you learn from doing that last project that you can apply to this one?
I learned how to manage my time better and how to structure my argument.

So you are not starting from zero. You are starting with more skills and experience than before. A reframe could be: 'I am proud of my last success, and it's normal to feel pressure to repeat it. However, I am more skilled now than I was before. I will focus on applying the same successful process, and trust that a good process leads to a good result.'
I feel like everyone in my class has their life together and I'm a mess.
