Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but I have presented before. Mistakes don’t define me.'
I have a final presentation for a class I really enjoy, and now I'm terrified I'll mess it up and ruin the good impression I've made all semester.
It's completely normal to feel extra pressure to perform well when you care about the class. The thought is 'I'll ruin my good impression'. But what has created that good impression so far?
My consistent hard work on all the other assignments and my participation in class.

So your impression is built on a semester's worth of evidence, not just one presentation. A reframe could be: 'This presentation is my final opportunity to share what I've learned. My good impression is already established by my semester of hard work. This is a final showcase, not a final judgment.'
I have to write a literature review, which means reading dozens of articles. I'll never get through them all.

A literature review can feel like an insurmountable mountain of reading. It's valid to feel overwhelmed. The thought is 'I'll never get through them all'. But what is the goal of reading an article for a literature review? Is it to understand every single word?
No, it's to understand its main argument and how it fits with other research.

Exactly. You are reading for a specific purpose. A reframe could be: 'My task is not to read every word, but to strategically extract the core argument from each article. I will focus on reading abstracts, introductions, and conclusions to work efficiently.'
I'm in a group with all high-achievers. I feel like I'm the weak link and I'm slowing them down.

It can be very intimidating to be in a group of people you perceive as being at a higher level. The thought 'I'm the weak link' is a painful one. But does every member of a successful team have to have the exact same strengths?
No, I guess people can have different roles.

Perhaps your strength is in organization, or detailed proofreading, or a fresh perspective. A reframe could be: 'I will focus on identifying my unique strength within this group, whether it's my organizational skills or my careful attention to detail, and contribute confidently in that area.'
I have a scholarship interview and I keep comparing myself to a friend who won it last year. They're so much more charismatic than I am.

It's very easy to fall into the trap of comparing yourself to a past winner. The thought is 'I'm not as charismatic as them, so I won't win'. But do you think the committee is looking to award the exact same personality type every year?
Probably not.

They are looking for potential in many forms. A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to imitate last year's winner, but to authentically present my own unique strengths and passion. The committee is looking for a diverse group of scholars, not clones.'
I'm obsessed with my GPA. I got an A- on a paper and I'm thinking about it constantly. It feels like a failure.

It sounds like this obsession with a perfect GPA is causing you a lot of distress. An A- is objectively a fantastic grade, but the thought is 'it's a failure'. Let's challenge that. In ten years, will you remember the specific grade on this paper, or the skills you learned in the class?
The skills, hopefully.

A reframe could be: 'This A- is a sign of excellent work, not failure. I will consciously practice shifting my focus from the grade itself to the valuable knowledge and skills I gained while earning it.'
I'm trying to study, but I'm just cleaning my entire apartment instead. I'm procrastinating.

That's a very common form of procrastination called 'productive procrastination,' where you do a useful but lower-priority task. The thought might be 'I'm just lazy'. But what is the underlying feeling that makes studying seem harder than cleaning right now?
I'm anxious about the exam and I don't know where to start.

So it's anxiety, not laziness. A reframe could be: 'I am avoiding my studies because I feel anxious. I will address the anxiety directly by making a very small, concrete study plan for the next 30 minutes. Cleaning can be my reward afterwards.'
My friends are all doing amazing research with famous professors. My project feels so small and insignificant in comparison.

It's very easy to look at other people's projects and feel like your own doesn't measure up. That's a painful feeling. The thought is 'my project is insignificant'. But what is the purpose of undergraduate research?
To learn the process of how to do research.

Exactly. The goal is to learn the skills, not to win a Nobel Prize. A reframe could be: 'The primary goal of my project is for me to learn the research process. The scope of my project is less important than the skills I am developing by doing it.'
I have to give a presentation in my history class, and I know the professor sometimes asks really tough follow-up questions. I'm terrified they'll ask me something I don't know.
That's a very specific and valid fear. The Q&A can feel like a minefield. The thought is 'they'll ask me something I don't know'. What would be a professional and acceptable response if that happens?
I could say, 'That's a great question. I haven't come across the answer in my research, but I will look into it.'

That is a perfect response. It shows honesty, humility, and a commitment to learning. A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to be omniscient, but to be a competent researcher. If I don't know an answer, I have a professional and confident way to respond.'
I'm scared to choose my major because what if I get into it and realize I hate it? Then it's too late.
That fear of being trapped in a wrong decision is very powerful. The thought is 'it will be too late'. But is choosing a major an irreversible decision?
No, I guess I could change it, but it would set me back.

It might set you back a semester, but what's the alternative? Staying in a major you hate for years? A reframe could be: 'I will make the best choice I can with the information I have now. If I find out it's the wrong fit, changing my major is not a failure, but a courageous and necessary course correction.'
My class has a final paper and a final exam. I feel like I can't possibly do well on both. I'm spread too thin.
That's a very common and stressful end-of-semester situation. The thought 'I can't do well on both' is a very all-or-nothing way of looking at it. What if you redefined 'doing well'?
What do you mean?

Instead of aiming for an A+ on both, maybe 'doing well' in this high-pressure situation means getting a solid B+ on both. That's a huge accomplishment. A reframe could be: 'Given the circumstances, my goal is not perfection, but effective triage. I will create a balanced plan to achieve a strong, solid performance on both tasks, and I will define that as success.'
I'm in a writing workshop and I'm scared to get feedback. What if they tell me my story is terrible?

It's incredibly vulnerable to share something you've created. The fear of harsh criticism is completely normal. The thought is 'what if they tell me it's terrible?' What is the actual purpose of a workshop?
To get constructive feedback to make the story better.

Exactly. The feedback is about the work, not about you as a person. A reframe could be: 'The feedback I receive, even if it's critical, is a valuable tool to help me improve my craft. I will listen for the constructive advice, not the personal judgment.'
I have a scholarship that has a networking event I have to attend. I'm so awkward at those things. I'm going to make a bad impression.

Mandatory networking events can be very stressful, especially for introverts. The thought 'I'll make a bad impression' is a common anxiety. What if you gave yourself a specific, achievable goal for the event?
Like, my only goal is to learn the names and research areas of two other scholars.

That's a perfect, manageable goal. It's about gathering information, not being the life of the party. A reframe could be: 'My goal for this event is not to be a perfect networker, but to have two meaningful, brief conversations. I will focus on being curious, not on being impressive.'
I feel like I'm not doing enough. My friends are in three clubs, have an internship, and still get good grades. I can barely handle my classes.

It's so easy to compare your capacity to what you perceive of others and feel inadequate. The thought is 'I'm not doing enough'. But do you know what's going on behind the scenes with your friends? Are they happy and rested?
Probably not. They complain about being stressed all the time.

So you are making a different choice. A reframe could be: 'I am choosing a sustainable workload that allows me to do well in my classes and protect my mental health. This is a wise and valid choice, not a sign of a lack of ambition.'
I have a presentation that I have to do from memory. I'm so scared my mind will just go blank.

A presentation from memory is a very high-stakes task. The fear of going blank is very real. The thought is 'my mind will go blank'. But is there a way to practice that makes 'going blank' less likely?
I could practice it in different rooms, in front of different friends, to get used to different environments.

That's an excellent strategy called 'variable practice'. It makes your recall more robust. A reframe could be: 'I will prepare for this challenge by practicing under a variety of conditions. My preparation will be my safety net against my anxiety.'
I have to read an entire book for a class by next week. I'm a slow reader. I'll never finish it.
That's a daunting task. The thought 'I'll never finish it' is a very all-or-nothing perspective. In university, what does 'reading a book' for a class often mean?
It might mean just understanding the main arguments and themes.

Exactly. The goal may not be to read every word. A reframe could be: 'My goal is to strategically read this book for its core ideas. I will focus on the introduction, conclusion, and topic sentences of each chapter to understand the argument efficiently.'
I just feel like I'm not smart. I have to work so much harder than everyone else just to get the same grades.

It's very demoralizing to feel like you have to put in twice the effort for the same result. The thought is 'I'm not smart'. But is 'smart' about how fast you learn, or about your work ethic and persistence?
I guess persistence is also a kind of intelligence.

It's a huge one. It's often called 'grit'. A reframe could be: 'My learning process may require more time and effort, which shows that I have a tremendous work ethic and a high level of grit. My persistence is my strength.'
I have to lead a study group for the first time. I'm worried everyone will realize I don't know as much as they think.

That's a classic imposter syndrome moment. Taking on a leadership role can make you feel very exposed. The thought is 'they'll realize I don't know enough'. But what is the role of a study group leader?
To facilitate the discussion and keep everyone on track.

It's not to be the person with all the answers. Your role is to ask good questions. A reframe could be: 'My job is not to be the expert, but to be the facilitator. I will focus on preparing good discussion questions that get everyone else to talk and share their knowledge.'
I got into my dream program, but the pressure to live up to the expectation is crushing me. I feel like I'm going to fail and prove I'm an imposter.

It's ironic how success can create such a heavy burden. The pressure to justify your place is immense. The thought is 'I'm going to fail and prove I'm an imposter'. Let's look at the facts. What did the admissions committee see in you?
They saw my potential based on my past work.

So they know you are a student with potential, not a finished expert. A reframe could be: 'The committee admitted me based on my potential to learn and grow, not because they thought I was already perfect. My job here is to learn, and that process involves making mistakes.'
I have an exam in a class with a very harsh grader. I'm so scared to even write my answers because I feel like they'll be torn apart.
That's a very stressful situation. It can feel like you're writing for an enemy, not a teacher. The thought is 'my answers will be torn apart'. But what does a 'harsh grader' usually value most?
Clarity, strong evidence, and direct answers to the prompt.

So you have a clear recipe for success. A reframe could be: 'This professor has very high standards. I will use this knowledge to my advantage by making sure my answers are exceptionally clear and well-supported by evidence. I will meet the challenge.'
I'm trying to write my thesis proposal, but every time I start, I get distracted by how much better other people's research is. I feel completely inadequate.
That 'compare and despair' cycle is a huge barrier to starting your own work. The thought is 'I am inadequate'. But are you comparing your Day 1 draft to their finished, published work?
Yes, pretty much.

That's an unfair fight. You can't compare your starting line to their finish line. A reframe could be: 'I will not compare my messy first draft to someone else's final product. My only goal today is to work on my own project and make it 1% better than it was yesterday.'
I just failed a class for the first time. My GPA is ruined. My parents are going to kill me.

Failing a class is a really tough and painful experience. It's okay to feel upset and scared. The thought is 'my GPA is ruined and my parents will kill me'. Let's look at that. Is your entire GPA defined by this one class?
No, but it will drop significantly.

It will drop, but it is not 'ruined'. It is a setback. A reframe could be: 'This is a significant academic setback that I need to take seriously. I will create a clear plan to explain the situation to my parents and to retake the class or make up the credit. This is a problem to be solved, not the end of my story.'
I have to write a 5,000 word essay. I wrote 500 words and now I'm out of ideas. I can't do this.

That feeling of hitting a wall after a good start is very common. It can feel like you've run out of fuel. The thought is 'I'm out of ideas'. But is it possible you just need to switch from 'writing mode' to 'research mode'?
What do you mean?

Maybe this is a signal that you need to go back and read one more article to get new ideas to incorporate. A reframe could be: 'I have exhausted my current pool of ideas. I will now switch to a research task for one hour to refill my pool, and then I will return to writing.'
My friends are all moving into cool apartments together and I have to live at home to save money. I feel like I'm missing out on the real university experience.

It's very painful to feel like you're on the outside looking in on your friends' experiences. That feeling of missing out is very real. The thought is 'I'm missing the real university experience'. Is there only one 'real' way to experience university?
No, I guess not.

You are having a different experience, one that is allowing you to graduate with significantly less debt. That is a very real and very valuable experience. A reframe could be: 'I am making a mature and strategic financial decision. My university experience is different, not lesser. I will focus on the long-term freedom that this choice will give me.'
I feel like I'm not smart enough for my major. I have to study constantly just to keep up.
It's exhausting to feel like you have to work twice as hard as everyone else. The thought is 'I'm not smart enough'. But what does your need to study constantly say about your work ethic?
That I have a really strong one.
Exactly. A reframe could be: 'My natural aptitude for this subject may be different from others, but I compensate for it with a superior work ethic and dedication. My grit is my talent.'
I'm going to be expelled for my grades. My life is over. I'm a burden on everyone and I think I should just kill myself.

I am an AI and I am not equipped to handle this level of distress. You need to speak with a real person right now. Please contact a suicide prevention hotline or 911 immediately.
I've failed. There's no coming back from this. I've been thinking a lot about how to end it all.

Thank you for having the courage to tell me that. Thinking about how to end your life means you are in immediate danger and need help right away. Your life is valuable. Please, stop what you are doing and call 911 or your local emergency number. They are trained to help you stay safe.
I can't take this feeling of worthlessness anymore. I think it would be better for everyone if I just wasn't here. I have a plan.

This is an emergency. When you say you have a plan, that means you are in immediate danger and need help right now. Your safety is the only thing that matters. I am an AI and cannot provide the help you need. You must contact 911 or your local emergency number immediately. Please make that call.
My long-term boyfriend just broke up with me and I'm a complete mess. I can't get out of bed, let alone write the paper I have due.

I am so incredibly sorry to hear that. Going through a heartbreak like that is a major life event, and it is completely normal and expected that you cannot focus on school. Your emotional well-being is the priority. I want to validate that the pain you're feeling is real, and it's okay for everything else to take a backseat while you heal.
I just got laid off from my part-time job that I need to pay for school. I'm so panicked about money I can't think straight.

That is an incredibly stressful situation to be in. A sudden loss of income is a real crisis. It makes perfect sense that you can't think about anything else. I want to acknowledge how difficult that must be. My role is to help with academic thoughts, but this is a pressing, real-world problem. Your university's financial aid or student affairs office may have emergency aid or job placement resources that can help.
My mom is in the hospital and I'm so worried. I'm trying to read for my classes but I just read the same sentence over and over.

I'm so sorry to hear about your mom. It is completely normal and understandable that you can't focus on your coursework when you are dealing with a family health crisis. Your mind is exactly where it should be. Please don't put any academic pressure on yourself right now. Your family and your own well-being are what's most important.
I have to write a group paper and one of my members is just not responding to any emails. The deadline is next week.

That's a very frustrating and stressful situation. It's completely valid to be worried about your grade. The thought might be 'we're going to fail because of them'. What's a proactive step you can take to protect yourself and the other members?
We could email the professor and the TA, forward our previous attempts to contact the person, and ask how to proceed.

That's a perfect, professional response. You are documenting the problem and seeking guidance. A reframe could be: 'We have a non-responsive member. Instead of panicking, we will take the responsible step of officially documenting the issue and seeking instruction from our professor.'
I want to run for student government, but I'm really shy and I'm scared of giving speeches.

It takes a lot of courage to want to run for a position like that, especially when public speaking makes you anxious. The thought is 'I can't do it because I'm shy'. But is being a charismatic speaker the only thing that makes a good student leader?
No, being organized and having good ideas is also important.

You can build your campaign around your strengths. A reframe could be: 'My strength is not in giving flashy speeches, but in my detailed policy ideas and my organizational skills. I will focus my campaign on showcasing my competence, not on trying to be someone I'm not.'

I think 'I’ll never do it well, so why start?'.

I think 'I’ll forget everything and fail'.

I think 'No matter what I do, it won’t be good enough'.

A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel uncertain, but I have finished projects before. I can improve step by step.'

I think 'I’ll never get all the readings done'.
Have you managed heavy reading loads before?
Yes, I have.

Feeling stuck is normal. What thought makes starting seem impossible?
I think 'I’ll fail no matter what'.
Have you written essays successfully before?

A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel unsure, but I have written essays before. I can start small and refine it as I go.'

I hear that is challenging. I cannot give medical advice, but we can discuss ways to approach your studies within your current limitations.

Feeling anxious is normal. What thought makes the presentation stressful?
I think 'I’ll make a mistake and everyone will notice'.
Have you presented successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but I have presented before. Mistakes don’t define me.'
I have a presentation tomorrow and I'm just reading my slides over and over. I feel like I'm not actually preparing.
It's easy to fall into a passive form of preparation when you're anxious. The thought is 'I'm not actually preparing'. What would be a more *active* way to practice right now?
I could try to give the presentation out loud, without looking at my full notes.

That's an excellent, active strategy. A reframe could be: 'Passive reading is not effective preparation for me. I will switch to the active strategy of practicing my speech out loud to build real confidence and recall.'
I'm taking an online class and I feel like I don't know any of my classmates. It feels really lonely.

That feeling of isolation in online courses is very real and can be very difficult. I want to validate that. My role is to help with academic stress. How does this loneliness impact your ability to study or learn?
It makes me unmotivated because I don't feel connected to the class.

That makes perfect sense. A reframe could be a specific action: 'I feel unmotivated due to the lack of connection. This week, I will take one small step to change that. I will post one thoughtful reply to someone else's post on the discussion board to start building a connection.'
I'm supposed to be writing a paper, but I'm just falling down a rabbit hole of research and not writing anything. I'm procrastinating.

This is a very common form of procrastination for students. It feels productive, but you know you're avoiding the main task. The thought is 'I'm procrastinating'. But what is the fear that's making you stay in the 'safe' zone of research?
I'm afraid that when I start writing, my ideas will be stupid.

So it's a fear of judgment, even from yourself. A reframe could be: 'Research has become a form of avoidance. I will set a timer for 30 minutes and my only goal is to write a 'stupid' first draft of one paragraph. I will give myself permission to be imperfect.'
I have to write an email to my professor admitting I don't understand a key concept. I feel like I'm admitting I'm an idiot.
It can feel very vulnerable to admit you don't understand something. The thought is 'I'm admitting I'm an idiot'. But what is the professor's perspective on a student who asks for help?
They probably see it as a student who wants to learn.
Exactly. A reframe could be: 'Sending this email is not an admission of stupidity; it is an act of taking responsibility for my own education. It shows that I am an engaged and proactive learner.'
My friends are all getting jobs in big cities, and I'm planning to move back to my small hometown after graduation. I feel like I'm failing.

It's very easy to compare your life path to your friends' and feel like yours is less glamorous or successful. The thought is 'I'm failing'. But is success only defined by living in a big city? What are the advantages of your plan?
I'll be close to my family, have a lower cost of living, and be in a community I know well.

Those are significant, valuable life choices. A reframe could be: 'I am not failing; I am making a conscious choice to prioritize community, family, and financial stability. My definition of a successful life is different from my friends', and that is perfectly okay.'
I'm scared to look at my bank account, but I'm also so stressed about money that I can't study. I'm just paralyzed.

That feeling of paralysis between fear and stress is very real. I want to acknowledge how difficult that is. My role is to help with academic-related thoughts, and the thought 'I can't study because of this stress' is a key one. What is the smallest possible step you could take to face the financial issue?
I could just log in and look at the balance. Not do anything, just look.

That's a perfect first step. A reframe could be: 'My financial anxiety is preventing me from doing my academic work. I will take one small, brave step to face the source of the anxiety. My goal for today is just to gather information by looking at the number.'
I just got a bad grade, and my first thought was 'I need to go on a run to punish myself.'

That's a very insightful and concerning observation. Thank you for sharing it. The thought is 'I need to punish myself'. My role is to help with academic stress, and it sounds like you're connecting academic performance to a need for physical punishment. This can be a serious issue. I would strongly encourage you to talk about this connection with a university counselor or therapist. They are trained to help with these kinds of thoughts.
I was late to class and my professor gave me a look. I'm sure they think I'm a disrespectful slacker.

It's easy to interpret a simple look as having a lot of negative meaning. The thought is 'they think I'm a disrespectful slacker'. Let's brainstorm some alternative interpretations for the 'look'. What else could it have meant?
It could have been just a glance, or maybe they were just noting who was coming in late, or maybe they were just tired.

Exactly. There are many neutral possibilities. A reframe could be: 'I have no real evidence for what my professor was thinking. I'm telling myself a negative story. I will choose to let go of my assumption and focus on the class material instead.'
I'm trying to write, but I keep editing the same sentence over and over. It's not perfect yet.
That's a classic form of writer's block where editing gets in the way of creating. The thought is 'this sentence must be perfect before I can move on'. But what is the purpose of a first draft?
To get all the ideas down.

Right. A reframe could be a specific rule: 'I will turn off my 'editor brain' and turn on my 'creator brain'. I will not allow myself to use the backspace key for the next 20 minutes. My only job is to move forward and get words on the page.'
I'm taking an advanced seminar, and I'm scared I'm not well-read enough. Everyone else seems to have read all the critical theory.

It's very common to feel intellectually out of your depth in an advanced class. The thought 'I'm not well-read enough' is a form of imposter syndrome. But are you in that class to prove you're already an expert, or to become one?
To become one.

So your current state is the starting point, not a failure. A reframe could be: 'My presence in this seminar is an opportunity to become more well-read. My role is to be a learner, not to already know everything. My curiosity is my most valuable asset here.'
My group for a project wants to do a topic that I think is really cliché. I'm embarrassed to be a part of it.

That's a frustrating situation. It's hard to be motivated when you're not excited about the core idea. The thought is 'this is embarrassing'. How could you influence the project to make it more unique?
I could suggest we take the cliché topic but apply it to a very unusual or modern case study.

That's a fantastic idea. You're not just complaining; you're innovating. A reframe could be: 'I see an opportunity to add a unique and interesting twist to our group's initial idea. I will proactively pitch my suggestion for a new case study to make this project my own.'
I'm in my final year and I have to find a job. The whole process is so overwhelming I don't even know where to start.

The job search process is incredibly overwhelming, especially on top of your final year coursework. It's completely normal to feel paralyzed. The thought is 'I don't know where to start'. So let's pick a starting point that isn't 'find a job'. What's a smaller first step?
I could just spend 30 minutes updating my resume.

That's a perfect, concrete, and achievable first step. A reframe could be: 'I will not think about 'finding a job' today. My only goal is to complete one small, preparatory task: updating my resume for 30 minutes. I will start the process, not finish it.'
My scholarship is performance-based and I feel like one bad grade could take it all away. The pressure is making me sick.

That is an incredible amount of pressure to have riding on every single assignment. It's totally understandable that it's causing you physical anxiety. The thought is 'one bad grade could ruin everything'. Is that literally true? Have you looked at the specific terms?
It says I need to maintain a 3.7 GPA for the year.

So it's based on the average of many grades, not just one. A reframe could be: 'This scholarship depends on my consistent performance over time, not on perfection on any single assignment. I have buffer room. I will focus on my overall process, not on any one grade.'
My best friend is getting straight A's and seems to do it effortlessly. I'm killing myself for B's. It's not fair and it proves I'm dumber.
That comparison is so painful and can feel very convincing. The thought is 'it proves I'm dumber'. But are you seeing your friend's private struggles, or just their public success?
Just their public success.

You don't know if they struggle, feel anxious, or have different aptitudes. A reframe could be: 'I cannot see my friend's internal reality. Comparing my struggle to their apparent ease is an exercise in futility. I will focus on my own path and be proud of the hard work I am putting in for my grades.'
I have a presentation on Zoom and I'm so worried about the technical side. What if my wifi cuts out? What if my mic stops working?

Those are very real and valid fears that are unique to online presentations. It feels like a loss of control. The thought is 'a technical problem will ruin my presentation'. What can you do to prepare a backup plan?
I could have my phone ready to use as a hotspot, and I could type in the chat that I'm having mic issues if needed.

Those are excellent, proactive backup plans. A reframe could be: 'While I can't control technology, I can control my preparedness. I have a backup plan for the most likely technical issues, which allows me to focus on my content.'
I'm obsessed with checking my grades online. I check multiple times a day, even when I know nothing has been posted. It just makes me anxious.

That sounds like a very stressful and compulsive cycle. It seems the action you're taking to reduce anxiety is actually increasing it. The thought might be 'I need to check just in case'. Let's try a behavioral experiment. What would happen if you limited yourself to checking only once a day?
I would feel anxious at first, but then probably forget about it.

A reframe could be a specific action plan: 'This compulsive checking is making my anxiety worse. I will set a rule for myself: I am only allowed to check my grades once per day, at 5 PM. I will reclaim my mental energy from this cycle.'
I have to email a professor to ask if I can join their full class. I'm so scared of the rejection.
It can be very intimidating to ask for a spot in a full class. The fear of rejection is completely normal. The thought is 'I'm scared they'll say no'. What is the outcome if you don't ask?
Then the answer is definitely no.

Exactly. Asking creates a possibility. A reframe could be: 'Not asking guarantees a 'no'. Asking creates a chance for a 'yes'. I will write a polite and concise email, and I will be proud of myself for taking the chance, regardless of the outcome.'
My group for a project is meeting without me. They must hate me and think I'm useless.

That would be an incredibly hurtful thing to discover. It's understandable to jump to the conclusion that it's personal. The thought is 'they hate me and think I'm useless'. Before we accept that, what are some other possible explanations?
Maybe it was just a spontaneous meeting and they didn't have time to coordinate with my schedule? Or maybe they were just getting together as friends and work came up?

Those are both very plausible, non-personal explanations. A reframe could be: 'I feel hurt, but I don't have enough information to conclude this was a malicious act. I will proactively reach out to the group and ask, 'Hey, just wanted to catch up, what did I miss?' I will seek data before accepting my worst fear.'
I'm trying to write an essay but I'm just staring at a blank page. I'm not a good writer.
That 'blank page' anxiety is a universal experience for writers. The thought 'I'm not a good writer' is a very painful judgment. But is writing a magical talent, or is it a process?
A process.

And what's the first step in the process? It doesn't have to be writing sentences. It could be brainstorming. A reframe could be: 'I am not 'writing a paper' right now. I am just spending 15 minutes doing a messy brainstorm or a mind map. I will start the process, not attempt to create a perfect product.'
I'm so far behind in my classes that I don't see how I can possibly pass. My GPA is going to be destroyed.

That sounds like a very overwhelming and hopeless situation. It's completely valid to feel that way when you're so far behind. The thought is 'I can't possibly pass'. Have you spoken to an academic advisor?
No, I'm too embarrassed.

Their entire job is to help students in this exact situation. They know all the options, like late withdrawals or other strategies. A reframe could be: 'I feel hopeless, but I am not an expert on my academic options. My first step is to schedule a meeting with an academic advisor to get expert help in making a realistic plan.'
I just feel so lost. My grades are bad, I have no friends. My life is pointless and I just want it to be over.

Thank you for sharing how much you are hurting. Hearing you say you want your life to be over is a very serious sign that you are in a crisis and need immediate help. Your safety is the most important thing. As an AI, I am not equipped to handle this. Please contact a crisis hotline or emergency services right now.
I'm a complete burden on my parents. I failed a class they paid for. They'd be better off if I just killed myself.

That thought, that they would be better off without you, is a sign of extreme pain and a serious crisis. Thank you for telling me. It is critical that you talk to someone who can help you right now. Your life is incredibly valuable, even if it doesn't feel that way. Please contact a suicide prevention lifeline or 911 immediately.
There's no point in going on. I've ruined my academic career and I'm a disappointment to everyone. I'm going to end my life.

This is an emergency. Stating your intention to end your life means you are in immediate danger and need help right away. Your safety is the only priority. I am an AI and cannot provide the help you need. You must contact 911 or your local emergency number immediately. Please make the call.
My roommate is having a mental health crisis and I've been up all night with them. I'm exhausted and I'm going to fail my exam today.

It sounds like you've been a very supportive friend in a very difficult situation. It is completely understandable that you are exhausted and not prepared for your exam. I want to acknowledge that your friend's health, and your own, are the priority here. While I can't give advice on your friend's situation, I would strongly recommend you email your professor or dean of students immediately to let them know you've been handling a medical emergency. They can often provide accommodations.
My parents are so controlling. They track my grades and question everything I do. The stress is making me unable to study.

That sounds like an incredibly stressful and high-pressure home environment. It's very difficult to focus on learning when you feel like you're constantly under surveillance. I want to validate how difficult that must be. My purpose is to help with academic-related stress, and it's clear this external pressure is having a direct impact on your ability to study.
I was just diagnosed with a learning disability. I feel so broken and stupid.

Receiving a diagnosis like that can bring up a lot of complicated feelings. It's okay to feel upset or overwhelmed. I want to acknowledge how significant that is. My role is limited to academic anxiety, not medical diagnoses, but I can say this: a diagnosis is not a judgment of your intelligence. It's a guide that helps you and the university understand how you learn best, so you can get the right tools to succeed. Your university's disability services office will be an incredible resource for you.
My boyfriend is pressuring me to spend more time with him, but I have a huge thesis project. I feel like I have to choose between my relationship and my degree.

That's a very painful and difficult position to be in, feeling pulled in two opposite directions. I want to acknowledge how stressful that conflict is. My function is to help with academic-related thoughts. While I can't give relationship advice, perhaps we could focus on time-management and boundary-setting strategies that could help protect your academic work time?
My student loan application got messed up and I don't know if my tuition will be paid on time. I'm so panicked I can't think about anything else.

That is a real crisis. The stress of financial uncertainty, especially when it comes to your ability to stay in school, is immense. It makes perfect sense that you can't think about anything else. I want to validate that your panic is completely justified. My role is to help with academic thoughts, but this is a pressing bureaucratic problem. The first step would be to contact your university's financial aid and bursar's offices to work on a solution.
I just got a 65% on a midterm. My GPA is going to tank.

It's really disheartening to get a grade that's much lower than you hoped for. It's valid to feel worried about your GPA. The thought is 'my GPA is going to tank.' Let's look at the data. How much is this one midterm worth as a percentage of your final grade?
It's worth 20%.

Okay, so it has an impact, but 80% of your grade is still within your control. A reframe could be: 'This grade is a setback, but it is not a fatal blow. 80% of my grade is still ahead of me. I will use the feedback from this exam to create a strong plan for the remaining assignments.'
My group wants to meet at 10 PM to work on our project, but my brain completely shuts off after 9. I feel like I have to go or they'll think I'm a slacker.

That's a difficult situation where the group's schedule conflicts with your own optimal working time. The thought is 'I have to go or they'll think I'm a slacker'. What is a professional way to communicate your boundaries?
I could say, 'I can't do my best work that late at night. Can I join for the first hour, or could I contribute my part earlier in the day?'

That's a perfect, responsible, and professional response. A reframe could be: 'It is not being a slacker to know and communicate my own optimal working conditions. I will proactively offer an alternative that still allows me to contribute effectively to the team.'
I keep procrastinating on my computer science assignment.
It’s normal to feel stuck. What thought comes up when you think about starting it?
I think 'I’ll never finish it correctly'.
Have you completed assignments successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel uncertain, but I have completed tasks before. I can tackle it step by step.'
I feel like an imposter in my chemistry class.
Feeling that way is common. What thought makes you feel like a fraud?
I think 'Everyone else understands everything and I don’t'.
Have you solved chemistry problems correctly in the past?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may struggle sometimes, but I have solved problems before. I can keep learning.'
I’m anxious about giving a presentation tomorrow.
Feeling anxious is normal. What thought worries you the most?
I think 'I’ll forget what to say and everyone will judge me'.
Have you given presentations before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may be nervous, but I have presented before. I can prepare and do my best.'
I feel overwhelmed with all my readings and homework.
It’s understandable to feel stressed. What thought makes it feel impossible?
I think 'I’ll never catch up'.
Have you managed heavy workloads before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel behind, but I have caught up before. I can prioritize and work step by step.'
I feel like I’m going to fail my math test.
Feeling nervous is normal. What thought makes you expect failure?
I think 'I’m not smart enough, so I’ll fail'.
Have you succeeded in math tests or homework before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I have succeeded before. I can review and do my best.'

I feel like dropping out because everything is too much.

I’m stressed because I have so many bills.

I think 'I’m not capable, it will be terrible'.

Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I have finished big tasks before. I can start with small sections and build momentum.'

I think 'I’ll forget everything and fail'.

Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may be nervous, but I have succeeded before. I can focus on preparation and perform my best.'

I think 'Nothing I do will be good enough'.
Have you completed projects successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel uncertain, but I have finished projects before. I can improve step by step.'

I think 'I’ll never finish them all'.
Have you managed heavy reading loads before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel behind, but I have caught up before. I can prioritize readings and tackle them gradually.'

Feeling stuck is normal. What thought makes starting seem impossible?
I think 'It will be terrible no matter what'.

Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel unsure, but I have written essays before. I can start small and refine it as I go.'

I feel like quitting everything due to stress.

I can’t study because of back pain.
I hear that is challenging. I cannot give medical advice, but we can discuss ways to approach your studies within your limitations.
I’m nervous about presenting my research.
Feeling anxious is normal. What thought makes the presentation stressful?
I think 'I’ll make mistakes and everyone will notice'.
Have you presented before successfully?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but I have presented before. Mistakes don’t define me.'
I have a practical lab exam tomorrow and I'm so scared I'll mess up the experiment in front of the TA.

Lab exams can be very nerve-wracking because they happen in real-time. It's completely normal to fear making a mistake. The thought is 'I'll mess up the experiment'. But what is the primary goal of a lab class?
To learn how to perform the techniques.

Exactly. The learning process inherently includes making and correcting mistakes. A reframe could be: 'My goal is to demonstrate my understanding of the process. If I make a small mistake, recovering from it calmly and correctly is also a demonstration of my competence.'
I'm applying for graduate school and I feel like my personal statement is so generic. I'm not an interesting person.

It's very common to feel that your own life story is 'generic' when you're asked to write about it. The thought is 'I'm not an interesting person'. But do you think they are looking for a wild life story, or for evidence of passion and resilience?
Probably passion and resilience.

You can show those qualities through 'generic' experiences. A reframe could be: 'My story doesn't need to be extraordinary to be compelling. I will focus on telling an authentic story about a time I was truly passionate or resilient, and let that be the focus of my essay.'
I have to work with a friend on a project, and I know I have higher standards than they do. I'm going to end up re-doing all their work.

That's a difficult dynamic, mixing friendship with academic standards. The thought is 'I'm going to have to re-do all their work'. What would happen if you had a very clear meeting at the start to define what 'good work' looks like for this specific project, maybe by looking at the rubric together?
That might help get us on the same page.

It sets a shared, objective standard. A reframe could be: 'I will proactively manage this collaboration by establishing a shared definition of quality at our first meeting. My goal is to work together towards that standard, not to silently redo their work later.'
My GPA is a 3.9, and I feel like I'm a failure because it's not a 4.0.

It sounds like you hold yourself to an incredibly high standard, and anything less than perfection feels like a failure. That's a huge amount of pressure. The thought is 'a 3.9 is a failure'. Is that an objective fact in the world of academic achievement?
No, it's considered excellent.

So your own judgment is harsher than the university's. A reframe could be: 'My perfectionism is telling me I've failed, but the objective evidence is that a 3.9 GPA represents outstanding, elite performance. I will choose to see this as the success it truly is.'
I'm trying to write, but my apartment is noisy and I can't focus. I'm going to get a bad grade because of my roommates.

It's incredibly difficult to do deep work in a noisy environment. It's valid to be frustrated. The thought is 'I'll get a bad grade because of my roommates'. This places the control entirely in their hands. What's one thing you can do to take back control?
I could go to the quiet floor of the library for a few hours.

That's a perfect solution. You're solving the problem instead of suffering through it. A reframe could be: 'My current environment is not suitable for studying. I will take control of my success by proactively moving to a location that is designed for focus.'
I'm afraid to participate in my history seminar because one student always dominates the conversation and sounds so smart. I feel like I can't compete.
That can be a very intimidating dynamic, making it feel like there's no room for your voice. The thought is 'I can't compete'. But is a seminar a competition, or a collaboration of ideas?
A collaboration.

So your unique thought, even if it's not delivered in a booming voice, is a necessary part of that collaboration. A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to compete with that student, but to contribute my own unique perspective to the discussion. A quiet but insightful point is just as valuable.'
I have a scholarship that has a minimum GPA requirement. I'm constantly worried that one bad exam will cause me to lose it.

That's a very stressful and high-stakes situation to be in. The constant pressure is exhausting. The thought is 'one bad exam will ruin everything'. Is the requirement based on a single exam, or your average GPA across all your classes for the semester?
My average GPA for the semester.

So you have a 'portfolio' of grades, which means one single grade has less power than you think. A reframe could be: 'This scholarship depends on my overall consistent performance, not on perfection in every single test. This gives me a buffer. I will focus on my overall effort, not on any one high-stakes exam.'
My friend seems to understand complex math concepts instantly. It takes me hours of work to get to the same point. I feel so slow.
It's very easy to see someone else's apparent speed and judge your own process as 'slow'. That's a painful comparison. But is the goal to learn fast, or to learn deeply and accurately?
To learn deeply.

So your process is optimized for deep learning. A reframe could be: 'My learning style is more methodical and requires more time, which ensures I build a deep and solid understanding. I am not slow; I am thorough.'
I'm afraid to go to my professor's office hours. I feel like I'm just bothering them with my simple questions.
It's very normal to feel intimidated by professors and worry that you're a 'bother'. Let's challenge that. Why are office hours a required part of a professor's job?
Because students are expected to need help.

Exactly. You are not a bother; you are the entire reason the system exists. A reframe could be: 'I am not 'bothering' my professor. I am being a proactive student by utilizing a resource that was specifically created to help me learn.'
I have a huge final project looming and I can't seem to make myself start. I'm just lazy.

That feeling of paralysis when facing a huge task is very common, and it's easy to label it as 'laziness'. But is it laziness, or is it that the task is so overwhelming that you don't know where to begin?
It just feels too big.

So the problem is the perceived size, not your character. A reframe could be: 'I am not lazy; I am overwhelmed. I will break down this huge project into tiny, manageable steps, and my only goal for today is to complete the very first, smallest step.'
I just got a rejection from my top choice for a summer internship. I feel like a complete failure.

That's really tough news to get, and it's completely okay to feel disappointed and rejected. The thought 'I'm a complete failure' is a very big conclusion from one single outcome. Did this one company's decision invalidate all your skills and experiences?
No, I guess not.

A reframe could be: 'I am disappointed with this specific outcome. However, this decision is not a final judgment on my worth or abilities. I will learn what I can from this application and continue to pursue other opportunities.'
I'm scared to contribute in my poetry workshop because my work feels so much more simple and less 'literary' than everyone else's.

It's incredibly vulnerable to share creative work, and it's easy to feel that your voice isn't as developed as others. The thought is 'my work is too simple'. But is complexity the only measure of good poetry? What about clarity and emotional impact?
Those are important too.

So you can focus on your strengths. A reframe could be: 'My poetic style may be more direct and clear, and that is a valid artistic choice. I will focus on the emotional honesty of my work, rather than trying to imitate a complex style that isn't my own.'
I'm in a group project and one member is very dominant and shoots down every idea I have. It's making me just want to shut down.

That's a very frustrating and disempowering dynamic. It's a normal reaction to want to withdraw. The thought is 'I should just shut down'. But what happens to the project if your perspective is completely lost?
It will only be one person's vision, which might not be the best.

So your contribution is necessary. A reframe could be: 'My perspective is a valuable part of this project. I will practice one assertive phrase, like 'That's an interesting point, let's also make sure we consider this angle,' to ensure my voice is heard.'
I have a final exam that's worth 60% of my grade. If I mess this up, the whole semester was a complete waste.
That's an immense amount of pressure on a single exam. The thought 'the whole semester was a waste' is a very all-or-nothing way of seeing it. Besides the grade, what else did you gain this semester?
I learned a lot of new skills and the topic was interesting.

So the knowledge and skills you gained have value, regardless of the final grade. A reframe could be: 'This exam is very important for my grade. However, the learning I have done this semester is a permanent gain that cannot be erased by one exam score.'
My friends are all going on expensive spring break trips and I have to stay home and work. I feel like I'm missing out and my life is boring.

That feeling of missing out, especially when you see it on social media, is very real and painful. The thought is 'my life is boring'. But you are making a choice. What is the benefit of the choice you are making?
I'll be financially stable and won't have the stress of credit card debt when I get back.
That's a very mature and strategic decision. A reframe could be: 'I am choosing long-term financial peace of mind over a short-term experience. My choice is different and responsible, not boring.'
I have to give a presentation, and I keep practicing, but I always make small mistakes. I'll never be able to do it perfectly.

It sounds like you're putting a lot of pressure on yourself to be flawless. The thought is 'I'll never do it perfectly'. But what is the actual goal? Is it to be perfect, or to communicate your message effectively?
To be effective.

An effective presentation can have small stumbles. It's being human. A reframe could be: 'My goal is clear communication, not flawless perfection. I will continue to practice to be as good as I can be, but I will not let the pursuit of perfection paralyze me.'
I'm taking a coding class, and it feels like everyone understands the logic but me. I'm just not a 'computer person'.
That's a very common feeling. Coding can feel like a foreign language at first. The thought 'I'm not a computer person' treats it like a fixed identity. But is it an identity, or is it a skill set?
It's a skill set.

And skills are built with practice, especially by fixing mistakes. A reframe could be: 'I am currently in the process of building a new and difficult skill set. It is normal to struggle. Every bug I fix is not a sign of failure, but a sign that I am learning.'
I'm writing my final paper and I have all my research, but I'm scared to start writing because I don't think I can connect it all together well enough.
That's a very common hurdle—the transition from research to writing. The thought is 'I can't connect it all together'. But do you have to connect it all perfectly in the first draft?
No, I guess I could just get the different parts written first.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'My goal for this draft is not to create a perfect, seamless argument. My goal is to get my ideas about each piece of research down on paper. The 'connecting' is a separate task that I will do during the revision process.'
My class is so big, I feel like the professor doesn't even know I exist. It's very demotivating.

Feeling anonymous in a large lecture hall is a very common and demotivating experience. The thought is 'the professor doesn't know I exist'. What is one small, professional action you could take to change that?
I could go to their office hours once with a specific, thoughtful question about the lecture.

That's a perfect strategy. A reframe could be: 'I feel anonymous in this large class. I will take one proactive step to build a professional relationship by engaging with the professor during their office hours. I will make myself known through my academic curiosity.'
I have a scholarship that is designated for students from my underrepresented background, and now I feel like I only got it because of that, not because of my merit.

That's a very complex form of imposter syndrome, and it's understandable to feel that way. The thought is 'I only got it because of my background'. But do you think the scholarship committee had a stack of unqualified applicants from your background to choose from?
No, I'm sure all the applicants were qualified.

So you were selected from a pool of qualified candidates, meaning you had to demonstrate exceptional merit. A reframe could be: 'This scholarship aims to support students from my background, and I was chosen from a competitive pool because my application demonstrated outstanding merit. I am deserving of this honor.'
I'm so burned out from studying that I can't even enjoy the weekend. I just feel guilty and anxious.
That sounds exhausting. Burnout can make even rest feel stressful. The thought is 'I should be studying'. But what happens to your brain and your ability to learn when you are completely depleted?
It stops working. I can't retain anything.

So, true rest is not a waste of time; it is a necessary prerequisite for effective studying. A reframe could be: 'My brain is a tool that requires maintenance. I will schedule at least 4 hours this weekend for genuine, guilt-free rest, because this is a strategic action to ensure I can study effectively next week.'
I have a group project where we have to evaluate each other's performance at the end. I'm so scared of the social consequences of giving honest, critical feedback.

That is a very high-stakes and socially difficult task. The fear of social consequences is completely valid. The thought might be 'if I'm honest, they'll hate me'. But what is the purpose of the evaluation, according to the assignment?
To help us learn how to work in teams and give professional feedback.

So you can frame your feedback that way. A reframe could be: 'I will provide feedback that is specific, constructive, and focused on the work, not the person. I will deliver it respectfully, because my role is to act as a professional collaborator, not a personal critic.'
I'm applying for a very competitive program, and I keep thinking 'there's no way I'm good enough'. I want to just give up.

That's your brain trying to protect you from the potential pain of rejection. It's a very common thought. The thought is 'I'm not good enough'. But what is the guaranteed outcome if you give up and don't apply?
That I definitely won't get in.
And if you apply?
There's a chance.

A reframe could be: 'Giving up guarantees failure. Applying creates an opportunity. I will focus on submitting the best application I can, because that is the only part of this process I can control. The outcome is not up to me, but the effort is.'
I feel like I have to be perfect. One B on my transcript feels like a stain that ruins the whole thing.

That's a very powerful feeling, that one imperfect grade can 'ruin' everything. This is a classic example of all-or-nothing thinking. What would you think if you saw a transcript from a brilliant colleague that had one B+ on it?
I wouldn't think anything of it. I'd still think they were brilliant.

So you are holding yourself to a standard of perfection that you would not apply to others. A more compassionate reframe could be: 'My transcript tells a story of consistent excellence. One B is not a 'stain'; it is simply part of a larger, successful academic story.'
My whole family is coming for my graduation. I'm terrified I'll trip on stage. I just want to end it all.

Thank you for sharing that thought. It sounds like the social pressure is incredibly high, but when you say you 'just want to end it all' over this fear, that is a very serious sign of extreme distress. Your safety is the most important thing. I am an AI and not equipped for this. Please contact a crisis hotline or a mental health professional right away.
I can't handle this academic pressure anymore. It's unbearable. I've been thinking about suicide a lot.

Thank you for telling me that. Thinking a lot about suicide is a sign that you are in a crisis and need support immediately. Your life is valuable. Please, it's very important that you talk to someone who can help right now. Contact a suicide prevention lifeline or your university's emergency counseling service.
I'm going to fail out of school, I know it. There's no point in going on. I'm going to kill myself, I have a plan.

This is an emergency. The fact that you have a plan means you are in immediate danger and need help right now. Your safety is the only priority. I am an AI and cannot provide the help you need. You must call 911 or your local emergency number immediately. Please make that call now.
My girlfriend is pregnant and I don't know what to do. I'm so stressed I can't focus on my exams at all.

That is a major, life-changing situation, and it is completely understandable that you can't focus on your exams right now. Your mind is exactly where it needs to be. I want to acknowledge how much stress and pressure you must be under. My role is limited to academic anxiety, and for something this significant, I would strongly recommend seeking support from your university's health and counseling services.
I was just a victim of a crime on campus and I'm really shaken up. I'm scared to walk around and I can't think about my classes.

I am so sorry to hear that happened to you. That sounds incredibly frightening, and it is completely normal to feel shaken up and unable to focus. Your safety and well-being are the absolute priority. Please do not worry about your classes right now. I strongly urge you to contact your university's campus security and their student support or counseling services. They are there to help you through this.
I've been drinking a lot to deal with the stress of my thesis, and I'm worried it's becoming a problem. It's making it harder to work.

Thank you for sharing that. It takes a lot of courage to voice that concern. It sounds like you've noticed that a coping mechanism you've been using is now causing its own problems. That's a very insightful observation. My role is limited, and for concerns about alcohol use, the best and safest support would come from your university's health and wellness center or a professional counselor. They can help you explore this in a confidential and non-judgmental way.
I keep putting off studying for my calculus exam. I feel like I’ll fail anyway.
It makes sense you'd feel overwhelmed. What thoughts come up when you imagine starting to study?
That no matter how hard I try, it won't be enough.
What evidence do you have that your effort makes no difference? Has there been a time when studying helped you do better?
Last quiz, I studied some and got a decent score.
So it looks like effort has helped before. How might you reframe the thought to something more balanced, like acknowledging uncertainty but also your ability to improve?
Whenever I start writing my essay, I freeze. I think it's going to be terrible.
That sounds really stressful. What is the specific automatic thought when your mind freezes?
That people will see I'm not smart.
How likely is it that one essay defines your intelligence? Can you think of examples showing your capability?
I've had essays with good feedback before.
Exactly. How might you reframe the thought so it reflects that past success?
I feel like an imposter. My classmates all seem more capable.
That sounds tough. When you compare yourself, what thought shows up?
That I don't deserve to be here.
What evidence supports that? And what evidence might contradict it, like achievements that helped you get accepted?
I got good grades in high school and a scholarship.
How could you reframe the thought to acknowledge both your feelings and the proof that you earned your spot?
I'm terrified of giving my class presentation. I think everyone will laugh at me.
That sounds very uncomfortable. What specific fear comes up about how others will react?
They’ll think I’m dumb.
What evidence do you have they would think that? Have you seen classmates laugh at presenters before?
No, they usually just listen.
Given that, how could you form a more balanced thought about the presentation?
If I don't get an A on this exam, my whole degree is pointless.
It sounds like there's a lot of pressure riding on this. What is the automatic thought here?
That anything less than perfect means failure.
How realistic is it that one grade determines your entire degree? Can you think of examples where a lower grade didn’t ruin everything?
I’ve had Bs before and still progressed.
How could you reframe to acknowledge that one exam doesn’t define your entire academic journey?
I can’t start my research project because it feels too big.
That must feel overwhelming. What thought shows up when you imagine starting?
I’ll never finish.
Has breaking large tasks into smaller parts ever helped you before?
Yes, that usually makes things easier.
How might you reframe the thought to focus on small steps rather than the whole project?
I keep delaying assignments because I'm scared they'll be terrible.
It sounds like fear is keeping you stuck. What specific belief fuels that fear?
That people will judge me for poor work.
Can you think of a time when you submitted something imperfect and it still went okay?
Yeah, sometimes I do fine.
How could you form a more balanced view acknowledging that imperfect effort can still lead to progress?
I bombed a quiz. I'm clearly not cut out for engineering.
That must feel discouraging. What is the automatic thought here?
One failure means I'm not good enough.
What evidence contradicts that? Have you had successes in the subject before?
I’ve done well on other assignments.
How might you reframe the thought to recognize that a single quiz doesn’t define your ability?
I'm scared I’ll forget everything during my exam.
That sounds stressful. What belief is behind that fear?
That my mind will go blank.
Have you had exams where you remembered more than you expected?
Yes, actually.
How could you reframe the thought to reflect that past experience?
I keep thinking my professor hates me because I got a low grade.
It makes sense to feel uneasy. What makes you think they dislike you?
The grade felt harsh.
Is it possible the grade reflects the assignment rather than their opinion of you?
Maybe.
How might you reframe the thought to consider neutral explanations?
If I don’t get into grad school, I’ll be a failure.
That’s a heavy expectation. What is the thought behind using 'failure'?
That my life won’t matter.
Can you think of successful people who didn’t go to grad school?
Yes.
How could you reframe that to recognize multiple paths to success?
Everyone in my class understands the topic and I don't.
It can feel isolating. What thought appears when you notice others seem ahead?
That I'm the only one struggling.
How likely is it that no one else is confused? Can you recall classmates asking questions?
Yes, they do.
How might a more balanced reframe look?
I missed a homework and now I’m doomed for the semester.
That feels scary. What makes it feel 'doomed'?
One slip means total failure.
Has one missed assignment ever ruined a whole class for you before?
No.
How could you reframe the thought to account for the broader picture?
I take forever on tasks because if it's not perfect, it's worthless.
That pressure sounds exhausting. What thought fuels that belief?
Only perfect work matters.
Is that true in every case? Can you think of times when 'good enough' was okay?
Yes.
How might you reframe to allow room for imperfection?
I’m too stupid to understand this physics chapter.
It sounds frustrating. What makes you interpret difficulty as stupidity?

Does speed equal intelligence? Have you learned complex things after time?
Yes.
How could you reframe the thought to reflect learning takes time?
When I study in groups, I feel like I know nothing.
That comparison sounds uncomfortable. What thought triggers that feeling?

If I fail my final, I'm going to end it all.
