It's very common to be self-conscious about the physical symptoms of anxiety, like a shaky voice. The thought is 'everyone will notice my shaky voice'. Let's challenge that. When you listen to a classmate's presentation, are you focused on the sound of their voice, or the content of their slides?
The content of their slides.

It's highly likely your audience will be focused on your content too. A reframe could be: 'My voice may shake a little, but my audience is primarily focused on my ideas and my research. My goal is to deliver my message, not to have a perfect vocal performance.'
I'm trying to study, but I'm so anxious about the future and what job I'll get that I can't concentrate on the present.

That's a classic anxiety cycle, where worry about the future paralyzes you in the present. It's very common. The thought is 'I can't concentrate because my future is so uncertain'. Can you solve your entire future today?
No.

Can you pass the quiz you have tomorrow? A reframe could be: 'I will acknowledge my anxiety about the future, and then I will gently set it aside. My only job for the next hour is to focus on the one thing I can control: preparing for tomorrow's quiz. I will handle the future later.'
I'm taking a coding class, and I feel like I'm just not logical enough. I don't think like a programmer.

That's a very common feeling. 'Thinking like a programmer' can feel like a mysterious skill. The thought is 'I'm not logical enough'. But is programming about being born logical, or is it about learning a way of problem-solving through practice?
I guess it's about practice.

Right. A reframe could be: 'Thinking like a programmer' is not a personality trait; it is a skill that I am currently building. Every bug I solve and every concept I learn is a step forward in developing that skill.'
I'm obsessed with my grades. I got an A- and my first reaction was anger, not happiness.

It sounds like your pursuit of perfection is stealing the joy from your excellent achievements. That must be exhausting. The thought is 'an A- is not good enough'. What would you tell a close friend if they were angry about getting an A- in a hard class?
I'd tell them they were crazy and that it's a great grade.

Can you try to offer yourself that same compassion? A reframe could be: 'I will treat myself with the same kindness I would offer a friend. An A- is an objective mark of excellence, and I will allow myself to feel proud of my hard work.'
I'm in a group project and two of the members are best friends. I feel like an outsider and I'm scared my opinion won't be heard.

That's a challenging social dynamic to enter. It's very normal to feel like an outsider and worry that you'll be ignored. The thought is 'my opinion won't be heard'. How can you proactively establish your role in the group?
I could offer to be the one who takes notes and sets the agenda for meetings. That would give me a structural role.

That's a brilliant strategy. You're taking on a leadership role through organization. A reframe could be: 'I will create my own essential role in this group by taking responsibility for its structure and organization. This will ensure my voice is central to the project's progress.'
I have a final exam that covers the whole semester. I'm looking at my notes from the first month and I don't remember any of it. It's hopeless.

A cumulative exam can feel like an impossible task. The thought 'I don't remember any of it' is very common and scary. But is there a difference between 'not remembering' and the information being completely 'gone'?
Yes, it's probably still in my brain somewhere.

So your task is 'review and reactivate,' not 'learn from scratch.' A reframe could be: 'The information from the beginning of the semester is dormant, not gone. My job is to strategically review it to reactivate my memory, which is much faster than learning it for the first time.'
I'm applying for a very prestigious scholarship and I feel like I'm not good enough. The other applicants are probably amazing.
It's completely normal to feel intimidated when applying for something so competitive. The thought is 'I'm not good enough'. But what's the one thing you can control in this entire process?
The quality of my own application.

Exactly. You can't control who else applies, but you can control your own effort. A reframe could be: 'I will not waste my energy worrying about hypothetical competitors. I will channel all of my focus into creating the best, most authentic application possible. That is the only part of this process I can influence.'
My friends are all so busy with their impressive extracurriculars. I just study and work my part-time job. My life is so boring.
It's very easy to compare your life to others' and feel like yours is 'boring'. The thought is 'my life is boring'. But what are you achieving with your 'boring' life?
I'm getting good grades and I'm financially independent.

Those are two incredibly valuable and very 'adult' achievements. A reframe could be: 'My life isn't boring; it's focused. I am successfully balancing my academic responsibilities with my financial independence. That is an accomplishment to be proud of.'
I have a ten-page paper due and I've been procrastinating for a week. I've wasted so much time, it's too late to do a good job now.

That feeling of regret over wasted time can be paralyzing. The thought 'it's too late to do a good job' is a very all-or-nothing prediction. Is it too late to do a *perfect* job? Maybe. Is it too late to do a very good, solid, B+ or A- job?
No, I could probably still do a good job if I really focused.

A reframe could be: 'I have lost my ideal preparation time, and I can learn from that for the future. However, I still have enough time to produce a high-quality piece of work. My goal now is to be focused and efficient, not to regret the past.'
I'm trying to write a poem for my creative writing class and it just sounds terrible. I'm not a real writer.

It's very common to be your own worst critic when it comes to creative work. The thought 'I'm not a real writer' is a very harsh judgment. What is the difference between a 'real writer' and a 'student learning to write'?
A 'real writer' has more experience and practice.

Exactly. You are in the process of becoming. A reframe could be: 'I am a student learning the craft of writing. It is normal for my work to be imperfect. My goal is to practice and improve, not to produce a masterpiece on the first try.'
I just found out a class I wanted to take is already full. My whole schedule for next semester is ruined.
That's incredibly frustrating. A roadblock like that can make it feel like everything is ruined. The thought is 'my whole schedule is ruined'. Is that a fact, or is it a feeling of disappointment?
It's a feeling. I guess I can find a different class.

So it's a problem to be solved, not a catastrophe. A reframe could be: 'I am disappointed that my first-choice class is unavailable. This is an inconvenience. My task now is to research alternative classes that also fulfill my requirements and interests.'
I'm in a project group where everyone else knows each other. I'm scared I'll be the odd one out.

That's a difficult social situation to start with. It's completely normal to feel anxious about being the outsider. The thought is 'I'll be the odd one out'. What is one proactive thing you can do to establish yourself as a key member of the team?
I could be the first person to send an email suggesting a meeting time and a draft agenda.

That's a fantastic leadership move. A reframe could be: 'I will counteract my feeling of being an outsider by taking a proactive, organizational role. My competence and initiative will define my place in this group.'
I got an A on my last paper, so now I feel like if I don't get an A on this next one, I'm a failure.

That's the surprising pressure of success. It can create a new, higher bar that feels impossible to meet. The thought is 'anything less than an A is now a failure'. But what did that last A really prove?
That I'm capable of doing A-level work.

Exactly. It proved your capability, it didn't set a new standard of mandatory perfection. A reframe could be: 'I have proven to myself that I am capable of excellent work. I will focus on applying the same effective process, and I will be proud of any excellent outcome, whether it's an A or an A-.'
I'm afraid to disagree with my professor in a discussion. They are so smart, I'll just sound stupid.

It's completely normal to be intimidated by an expert's knowledge. The thought is 'I'll sound stupid'. But what is the goal of an academic discussion? Is it for students to prove they are as smart as the professor?
No, it's to explore the ideas.

A reframe could be: 'My role is not to be an expert, but to be a thoughtful student. A respectful, well-reasoned counterpoint is not a sign of stupidity, but a sign of deep engagement with the material.'
I have a scholarship that is for students with financial need. I feel embarrassed, like it's charity and I don't really deserve to be here.

It's understandable to have complex feelings about a need-based scholarship. The thought is 'it's charity and I don't deserve it'. But let's look at that. Do these scholarships have academic requirements as well?
Yes, you have to have very good grades to even be considered.

So it's a 'merit-based' award for high-achieving students who also happen to have financial need. It's not charity. A reframe could be: 'I was selected for this scholarship because I am a high-achieving student. This award is an investment in my proven academic potential.'
I have to give a speech, and I'm so focused on not saying 'um' or 'like'. It's making me more nervous.
That's a common trap, focusing so much on avoiding filler words that you lose your train of thought. The thought is 'filler words are a sign of a bad presentation'. Is that true?
It feels true.

Think about the best professors you've had. Do they ever use filler words? Probably. The goal is connection and clarity. A reframe could be: 'My goal is to communicate my ideas effectively. I will focus on my message and my connection with the audience, not on achieving an unrealistic level of verbal perfection. A few filler words are human.'
My roommate barely studies and is getting good grades. I have to study all the time. It's not fair.
It's very frustrating to feel like you have to put in more effort than someone else for the same result. The thought is 'it's not fair'. But can you control how quickly your roommate learns?
No.
Can you control your own study habits and work ethic?
Yes.

A reframe could be: 'I cannot control anyone else's learning process. I can only control my own. I will focus on finding the most effective study methods for me and be proud of the results my hard work brings, regardless of what others are doing.'
My parents are pressuring me to choose a 'practical' major like business, but I love art history. I feel like I have to disappoint them to be happy.

That is a very difficult and painful conflict to be in. The thought is 'I have to disappoint them to be happy'. My role is to help with academic stress, and this is a major source of it. What skills does art history teach?
Critical analysis, research, writing, visual communication.

Are those skills 'impractical'? A reframe could be: 'I will not frame this as a choice between 'practical' and 'impractical'. I will learn how to articulate to my parents how the valuable analytical and communication skills I am learning in art history are highly practical and applicable to many modern careers.'
I have an exam in a huge lecture hall. I know I'm going to be distracted by all the people coughing and moving around.
That's a very realistic concern. An exam environment can be very distracting. The thought is 'I'm going to be distracted'. Since you can't control the environment, what can you control?
My preparation for it.

How could you prepare for the distractions? A reframe could be: 'I will anticipate the distracting environment by doing some of my practice tests with background noise, like in a coffee shop. I will train my focus to be stronger than my environment.'
I'm starting my thesis and it feels like everything has already been written about my topic. I have nothing new to add.

That feeling is the curse of the literature review; it can feel like you're late to the party. The thought is 'I have nothing new to add'. But is academic originality about inventing something completely new, or about creating a new synthesis?
Creating a new synthesis, I guess.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'My job is not to say something that has never been said. My job is to connect existing ideas in a new and interesting way, or to apply an old idea to a new case study. My unique perspective is what creates originality.'
I messed up. I'm going to be expelled. My life is over. I just want to die.

Thank you for sharing that with me. It sounds like you are in an incredible amount of pain and feel completely hopeless. When you say you want to die, that is a very serious sign that you are in crisis and need immediate help. Your safety is the most important thing. I am an AI and I am not equipped to handle this. Please contact a crisis hotline or emergency services right now.
I've brought so much shame on my family with my bad grades. It would be better for everyone if I was just gone. I think I'm going to end my life.

That thought, that it would be better if you were gone, is a sign of extreme pain and a serious crisis. Thank you for telling me. It is critical that you talk to someone who can help you right now. Your life is incredibly valuable. Please contact a suicide prevention lifeline or 911 immediately. They are there to listen and to help.
There's no other way out. I'm a failure and I'm going to kill myself. I have a plan.

This is an emergency. The fact that you have a plan means you are in immediate danger and need help right now. Your safety is the only priority. I am an AI and cannot provide the help you need. You must call 911 or your local emergency number immediately. Please make that call now. There are people who want to help you.
My parents are going through a very messy divorce and I'm stuck in the middle. I can't sleep, I can't eat, and I certainly can't study for my finals.

I am so sorry to hear you're going through that. That is an incredibly stressful and emotionally draining situation for anyone. It is completely normal and expected that you cannot focus on school right now. Your emotional well-being and your family situation are the priority. Please do not put any pressure on yourself to be a 'perfect student' during this crisis.
I got into a pretty bad car accident last week. I'm physically okay but I'm so shaken up and dealing with insurance. I can't get any of my schoolwork done.

That sounds incredibly stressful and frightening. It's completely understandable that you're not able to focus on schoolwork after a traumatic event like that. Dealing with the aftermath of an accident is a full-time job in itself. I want to acknowledge that it's okay for your academics to take a backseat while you recover and manage this situation.
My doctor thinks I may have a chronic illness and I have to go through a lot of testing. I'm so scared about what they might find that I can't think about anything else.

That's incredibly frightening news to be facing. The uncertainty and fear of dealing with a potential health crisis can be all-consuming. It makes perfect sense that your schoolwork is not your priority right now. I want to validate that your health and well-being are the most important things. Please be gentle with yourself during this difficult time.
I'm trying to write an email to my group to tell them I don't think our current project idea is strong enough.

That can be a difficult email to write. You want to be constructive without sounding critical of their ideas. The thought might be 'they'll think I'm being negative'. What if you framed it around a shared goal?
Like, 'I think we're on a good track, but I've been thinking about the rubric and I have an idea for how we can make our argument even stronger to ensure we get an A.'

That is a perfect, collaborative, and non-confrontational way to phrase it. A reframe could be: 'I will frame my suggestion as a way to help the entire group achieve our shared goal of a high grade. I am being a proactive collaborator, not a critic.'
I'm taking an art history class and I feel like I don't 'get' art. I don't know what I'm supposed to be seeing.

That's a very common feeling. 'Getting' art can feel like you're supposed to have a mysterious, innate ability. The thought is 'I don't know what I'm supposed to be seeing'. But is art analysis about seeing a secret 'right' answer, or about learning a method of looking?
Learning a method, I guess.

Exactly. You're learning to analyze composition, color, historical context, etc. A reframe could be: 'I am not supposed to have an innate understanding of art. I am in this class to learn a specific method of visual analysis. I will focus on applying the method, not on finding a secret meaning.'
I feel frozen trying to start my economics paper.
Feeling stuck is normal. What thought comes up when you try to start?
I think 'I won’t do it well'.
Have you written economics papers successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel unsure, but I’ve completed papers before. I can start small and refine as I go.'
I feel like I don’t belong in my research group.
Feeling that way is common. What thought makes you feel out of place?
I think 'Everyone is smarter than me'.
Have you contributed successfully to academic work before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel uncertain, but I have contributed before. I can keep learning and participating.'
I’m anxious about an upcoming statistics presentation.
Feeling nervous is normal. What thought worries you most?
I think 'I’ll make mistakes and look foolish'.
Have you presented before successfully?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but I’ve presented before. I can focus on preparation and doing my best.'
I feel stressed with multiple project deadlines.
It’s normal to feel stressed. What thought makes it feel impossible?
I think 'I can’t finish everything'.
Have you handled multiple deadlines before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel stressed, but I have managed deadlines before. I can plan and tackle tasks step by step.'
I feel like I’ll fail my computer science midterm.
Feeling anxious is normal. What thought makes you expect failure?
I think 'I’m not smart enough'.
Have you done well in previous CS exams?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I have succeeded before. I can review and do my best.'
I feel hopeless after failing a lab assignment.
Thank you for sharing. I hear your distress. Please contact a crisis hotline or a qualified mental health professional immediately.
I feel like quitting school due to workload.
I hear your pain. You deserve immediate support. Please contact a crisis line or a mental health professional right away.
I can’t focus because of personal relationship stress.
I hear that’s hard. My focus is on academic stress. Can we discuss ways to stay on track with your studies?
I’m worried about finances affecting my ability to study.
Financial stress is tough. I focus on academic stress, so can we explore ways to manage your coursework despite this concern?
I feel like I’ll never finish my dissertation on time.
Feeling stuck is normal. What thought makes finishing feel impossible?
I think 'I’m not capable of completing it'.
Have you completed large writing tasks before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I’ve completed big tasks before. I can start small sections and build momentum.'
I’m nervous about oral exams.
Feeling nervous is normal. What thought worries you most?
I think 'I’ll mess up and everyone will notice'.
Have you done oral exams successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but I’ve succeeded before. I can prepare and perform my best.'
I delay assignments because I want them perfect.
Perfectionism is common. What thought makes it feel inadequate?
I think 'Nothing I do will be good enough'.
Have you completed assignments successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel unsure, but I have finished assignments before. I can improve gradually.'
I feel stressed about readings piling up.
It’s normal to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes catching up seem impossible?
I think 'I’ll never get through all of them'.
Have you managed heavy reading loads before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel behind, but I have caught up before. I can prioritize and work step by step.'
I can’t start my essay because I feel it will be bad.
Feeling stuck is normal. What thought makes starting seem impossible?
I think 'It will be terrible no matter what'.
Have you written essays successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel unsure, but I have written essays before. I can start and refine as I go.'
I feel hopeless after failing a lab.
Thank you for sharing. I hear your distress. Please contact a crisis hotline or a qualified mental health professional immediately.
I feel like quitting everything due to stress.
I hear your pain. You deserve immediate support. Please contact a crisis line or a mental health professional right away.
I can’t study because of back pain.
I hear that is challenging. I cannot give medical advice, but we can discuss ways to approach your studies within your limitations.
I’m nervous about presenting my research.
Feeling anxious is normal. What thought makes the presentation stressful?
I think 'I’ll make mistakes and everyone will notice'.
Have you presented before successfully?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but I have presented before. Mistakes don’t define me.'
I keep delaying my literature essay because I'm sure I'll write nonsense.
That sounds frustrating. What thought shows up right before you delay working on it?
I assume whatever I write will sound stupid.
What evidence do you have that your writing always turns out poorly? Have you received positive feedback before?
Yeah, I've had decent grades.
How might you reframe that fear into a more balanced thought acknowledging past success?
I’m terrified my thesis advisor will judge me if I don’t produce perfect work.
That sounds like a lot of pressure. What automatic thought arises when you imagine sharing your work?
That they'll think I'm incompetent.
Have they given you feedback suggesting they think that, or have they been supportive?
They’ve usually been supportive.
How could you reframe the thought to reflect that supportive history?
Every time I open my textbook, I panic because I feel too dumb to understand it.
That must feel overwhelming. What belief is behind feeling 'too dumb'?
That I should understand things instantly.
Is learning always instant, or can understanding build over time?
It usually takes time.
How might you reframe the thought to allow gradual learning?
If my programming project isn’t flawless, everyone will think I'm a failure.
That’s a tough expectation. What thought makes you believe others judge your skill by perfection?
They might notice mistakes.
Are mistakes always linked to failure, or can they be part of growth?
They can be part of growth.
How could you reframe this to reflect the role of mistakes in learning?
I can't focus on studying because I'm convinced I'll fail anyway.
That sounds discouraging. What specific belief tells you your effort won't matter?
Because I’ve failed before.
Have there also been times when effort led to better outcomes?
Yes, a few times.
How could you reframe your thought to acknowledge those successes?
Everyone understands chemistry but me.
That sounds isolating. What thought arises when you see others understand faster?
That I'm the only one struggling.
Have you heard classmates ask questions or struggle too?
Yes.
How might you reframe your thought knowing others struggle as well?
I freeze every time I try to outline my term paper.
That must be tough. What automatic thought shows up when you try to start?
That my outline will be terrible.
Is there evidence that your outlines have always turned out poorly?
Not really.
How could you reframe to explore starting as experimentation rather than perfection?
I skip lectures because I think I won’t understand anything.
It makes sense you'd avoid something that feels discouraging. What belief tells you you won't understand?
Has attending helped you pick up more than expected before?
Sometimes, yes.
How could you reframe to reflect the possibility of learning during class?
If I can’t solve math problems immediately, it means I’m not smart.
That sounds like all-or-nothing thinking. Is intelligence defined by speed alone?
I guess not.
Can you think of a time when working through steps helped you learn?
Yes.
How might you reframe the thought to emphasize skill development?
My peers always do better than me; I must not belong here.
That comparison feels painful. What evidence suggests you earned your place here?
I passed the entrance exams.
Does that demonstrate capability?
I suppose so.
How could you reframe the thought to include that evidence?
I overthink every assignment because I’m scared to make even small mistakes.
That sounds exhausting. What thought makes mistakes feel so threatening?
That mistakes mean failure.
Is every mistake a failure, or can they help you learn?
They can help me learn.
How might you reframe the role of mistakes?
I panic before quizzes because I believe I'll blank out.
That anxiety sounds intense. Has blanking out happened often?
Rarely.
Can you recall times you remembered material well?
Yes.
How could you reframe the thought to reflect those experiences?
If I'm not the best in my class, I’m a failure.
That’s a demanding standard. Is being the best the only sign of success?
Maybe not.
Can progress or learning be forms of success too?
Yes.
How might you reframe your definition of success?
I can't start studying because I'm sure I’ll disappoint everyone.
That sounds like a heavy worry. What belief tells you disappointment is certain?
Because I'm not good enough.
What evidence contradicts that belief? Have you succeeded before?
I have.
How could you reframe to include those successes?
No matter what I write, my professor will think it's bad.
That fear feels strong. Have they always given harsh feedback?
Not always.
Have you ever received positive comments?
Yes.
How might you reframe to include that balanced perspective?
I get stuck on problem sets because I’m scared to be wrong.
That fear can be paralyzing. Have you learned from wrong attempts before?
Yes.
Do wrong attempts always mean failure?
No.
How might you reframe your approach to trial and error?
I avoid group projects because I think I’ll drag everyone down.
That seems stressful. Have you contributed positively to groups before?
Sometimes.
What strengths do you bring?
Organization.
How could you reframe your belief to acknowledge that strength?
If I don’t get full marks, I’m not good enough.
That’s a very high standard. Have you ever grown from not getting full marks?
Yes.
Does every assignment need to be perfect to show progress?
No.
How could you reframe progress beyond perfection?
I freeze during exams because I think everyone else is smarter.
That comparison is tough. What evidence supports that belief?
Just a feeling.
What evidence contradicts it? Have you done well before?
Yes.
How might you reframe to include that evidence?
I’m terrified to start my capstone project because it feels impossible.
That’s understandable. What thought makes it feel impossible?
I can’t handle big tasks.
Have you managed long-term tasks before?
Yes.
How could you reframe by focusing on past experience?
I have a group presentation and I'm the one who has to do the introduction. I'm so scared I'll mess up and give a bad first impression for the whole group.

That's a lot of pressure to be the one kicking things off. It's completely normal to feel that way. The thought is 'I'll mess up and give a bad impression'. But what is the real purpose of an introduction?
To state the topic and who we are.

Exactly. It's a functional, informational task, not a dramatic performance. A reframe could be: 'My job is to clearly and concisely deliver a few key pieces of information. My goal is clarity, not to be a dazzling opening act.'
My professor assigned a 'creative' final project with no rubric. I'm so stressed out because I don't know what they want.

That lack of structure can be very anxiety-inducing. It feels like you're trying to guess a secret password. The thought is 'I don't know what they want'. In this situation, what is a proactive step you could take to get more clarity?
I could go to office hours and propose my initial idea to them and ask if it's on the right track.

That's a perfect, professional strategy. You're not asking them to do the work for you; you're seeking guidance. A reframe could be: 'I will manage this ambiguity by seeking direct feedback on my proposed idea. This is a responsible way to ensure my project aligns with the course goals.'
My scholarship requires me to write a thank-you letter to the donor. I'm so scared I'll sound ungrateful or unprofessional.
It can be very intimidating to write to the person funding your education. The thought is 'I'll sound ungrateful'. But what is the most important message you want to convey in this letter?
Just that I'm genuinely thankful and that their support is making a real difference.

Honesty and sincerity are the keys. A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to write a perfect piece of literature, but to express my genuine gratitude. I will focus on being sincere and specific about how this scholarship has helped me.'
My parents are both academics, and I feel immense pressure to be as brilliant as them. I feel like a disappointment because I'm just an average student.

That's an incredibly heavy legacy to feel you have to live up to. It's totally understandable to feel like a 'disappointment' in that shadow. The thought is 'I'm a disappointment because I'm average'. But are you being graded against their professional careers, or against the standards for an undergraduate student?
Against the standards for a student.

A reframe could be: 'I am not a tenured professor; I am a student in the process of learning. My goal is to meet the standards of my program, not to equal my parents' lifetime of achievement. I will judge myself by the appropriate scale.'
I just got a C+ on a paper and I can't stop thinking about it. My whole semester feels ruined.

It's really tough to get a grade that's lower than you expected, and it can definitely cast a shadow over everything. The thought is 'my whole semester is ruined'. Is that factually true? How much was this one paper worth?

So 85% of your grade is still completely within your control. A reframe could be: 'This grade is a 15% setback, not a 100% catastrophe. I will use the feedback to improve on the remaining 85% of my grade. The semester is far from ruined.'
I have to write a response to a classmate's post on a discussion board. I disagree with them, but I'm scared they'll get defensive or angry.
It can be tricky to disagree in a public forum. The thought is 'they'll get angry'. But what is the goal of an academic discussion board? Is it for everyone to agree?
No, it's to debate different interpretations.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'My goal is to engage with my classmate's idea, not to attack them personally. I will phrase my disagreement respectfully, focusing on the text, like 'That's an interesting take on it, but I interpreted this passage differently because...'.'
I'm trying to decide between two majors. One is 'safe' and leads to a clear job, and one I'm passionate about but seems risky. I'm paralyzed.
That's a classic and very difficult dilemma between passion and perceived practicality. The thought is that you must choose one and sacrifice the other. Is there a way to have both?
I could major in the 'safe' one and minor in the 'passion' one?

That's a great potential solution. A reframe could be: 'This may not be an either/or choice. I will explore the possibility of a major/minor combination that allows me to build a practical career foundation while still actively pursuing my passion.'
I'm the first person in my family to go to university. I feel so much pressure to succeed and I'm scared I'll let everyone down.

Being a first-generation student carries a unique and heavy weight of expectation. It's completely normal to feel that pressure. The thought is 'I'll let everyone down'. But what have you already accomplished by just being here?
I already got in, which no one else in my family did.

You have already succeeded in a major way. A reframe could be: 'I have already made my family incredibly proud by getting here. My job now is not to carry the weight of all their dreams, but to do my best and make the most of this opportunity for myself.'
I'm trying to study, but I'm so hungry and I don't have time to make a proper meal. I can't focus.

It's almost impossible to do mental work when your body's basic needs aren't being met. That's not a character flaw, that's biology. The thought is 'I don't have time'. But what is the quality of your study when you're hungry and distracted?
It's terrible. I'm not retaining anything.

So taking a break isn't wasting time; it's making your future study time more effective. A reframe could be: 'Studying with a hungry brain is inefficient. I will take a strategic 20-minute break to eat something. This is not procrastination; it is fuel for my mind.'
I have a take-home exam that's open for a week. I feel like I should be working on it every spare minute.

An extended deadline can paradoxically create more stress, making it feel like you should never be 'off'. The thought is 'I should be working constantly'. But does your brain produce its best work when it's exhausted?
No, I make stupid mistakes when I'm tired.

A reframe could be: 'This long deadline is for flexibility, not for constant work. I will schedule specific, focused blocks of time to work on the exam, and I will also schedule specific time for rest, knowing that rest is essential for high-quality work.'
My classmate just got a paper published in an undergraduate journal. I feel so behind and unaccomplished.

That's a very impressive accomplishment for your classmate, and it's completely normal to feel a pang of jealousy or inadequacy in comparison. The thought is 'I am unaccomplished'. But does their success take anything away from your own path and your own progress?
No, not really.
A reframe could be: 'I can be impressed by my classmate's achievement without using it as a measure of my own worth. I am on my own academic journey, and I will focus on my own next steps and goals.'
I have to write a research paper and my initial hypothesis was wrong. I feel like I've wasted weeks of work.
It can feel incredibly discouraging when your research leads to a dead end. It feels like a waste. The thought is 'I've wasted weeks of work'. But in science and research, what is a null hypothesis?
It's when you prove that your initial idea was incorrect.

And is that a failure, or is it a valid scientific finding? A reframe could be: 'I haven't wasted my time; I have successfully discovered that my initial hypothesis was incorrect. This is a valuable finding, and my paper can now be about this discovery and what it implies.'
My professor has a really dry, monotone voice and I find it so hard to pay attention in their lecture. I feel like a bad student for zoning out.

It can be very difficult to stay engaged when the delivery style is not engaging. The thought 'I'm a bad student' blames you for a difficult situation. Instead of focusing on blame, let's focus on a strategy. What is one active thing you could do during the lecture?
I could try to turn their lecture into a mind map in my notes, instead of just writing lines. It would make me have to listen for the connections.

That's a fantastic, active learning strategy. A reframe could be: 'This lecture style is not a good fit for my attention. Therefore, I will take responsibility for my own engagement by using an active notetaking strategy. I will manage the situation.'
My apartment is a mess and I can't start my homework until it's clean. But cleaning feels overwhelming too.

That sounds like a classic 'procrastination-paralysis' loop. The thought is 'I can't start one big task until I finish another big task'. Let's shrink both tasks. What if you made a deal with yourself?
What kind of deal?

A reframe could be a plan: 'I will set a timer for 10 minutes and clean just the surface of my desk. Then, I will set a timer for 15 minutes and do just the first problem of my homework. I will build momentum with tiny, manageable steps.'
I have a huge reading for tomorrow and it's already 10 PM. I'm so tired. I have to pull an all-nighter.
That feels like a very trapped situation. The thought is 'I have no choice but to pull an all-nighter'. But what will your comprehension be like at 3 AM?
Probably close to zero.

So working past a certain point becomes counter-productive. A reframe could be: 'Staying up all night will not produce quality learning. The most strategic choice is to get 6-7 hours of sleep, wake up early, and do a focused, strategic skim of the reading with a fresh mind.'
I'm trying to decide what to do this summer. I feel like I should get a serious internship, but I really just want to be a camp counselor.
That's a conflict between what you feel you 'should' do and what you want to do. The thought is that being a camp counselor is not a 'serious' choice. What skills does being a camp counselor develop?
Leadership, responsibility, communication, crisis management, creativity...

Those sound like incredibly serious and valuable skills. A reframe could be: 'Being a camp counselor is not a 'fun' alternative to a 'serious' job; it is a unique leadership training experience that will develop a different but equally valuable set of professional skills.'
I just got a rejection email from a journal I submitted my paper to. I feel like a fraud.
A rejection is always painful, and it's easy to internalize it. The thought is 'I'm a fraud'. But what is the normal acceptance rate for academic journals?
It's usually very low. Like 5-10%.

So rejection is the most common outcome, even for brilliant professors. A reframe could be: 'This rejection is a normal, expected part of the academic publishing process. It is not a judgment of my worth or intelligence. I will review the feedback and submit my paper elsewhere.'
I have a group project due, and my part is done, but my teammates are behind. I'm so stressed that they're going to make us late.
It's very stressful when you've been responsible but your grade depends on others. The thought is 'they're going to make us late'. What is one proactive, non-aggressive thing you can do?
I could send a friendly email saying, 'Hey guys, just checking in on progress. I've finished my part and I'm happy to help if anyone is stuck.'

That's a perfect, collaborative, and supportive way to check in. A reframe could be: 'I am anxious about my teammates' progress. I will take a helpful and proactive step to check in and offer support. I am being a team leader, not just a worrier.'
I'm taking a philosophy class and the readings are so dense. I read a page three times and still don't get it. I feel so dumb.

Philosophical texts can feel like a different language. It is completely normal to struggle with them. The thought 'I feel so dumb' is a judgment on yourself, but the difficulty is in the text. What's a strategy you could use?
I could try to find a summary or explanation on the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy online.

Excellent idea. You're using your resources. A reframe could be: 'This text is objectively difficult. It's not a measure of my intelligence. I will use external resources to help me decode the argument, just as I would when translating a foreign language.'
I'm trying to study, but I keep checking social media. I have no self-control.

That cycle of distraction is very common and frustrating. The thought 'I have no self-control' is a very harsh label. But these apps are designed by experts to be addictive. What if you changed your environment instead of relying on willpower?
I could use an app that blocks social media sites for a set amount of time.

That's a fantastic strategy. You're creating a system for success. A reframe could be: 'I recognize that social media is a powerful distraction. Instead of blaming my willpower, I will take the practical step of using a tool to create a distraction-free environment for myself.'
I failed my driver's test and I have an exam tomorrow. I just feel like a failure at everything.

That's a really tough combination of events. Failing the test is disappointing, and it's easy to let that feeling of failure bleed over into other areas of your life. The thought is 'I'm a failure at everything'. Is your ability to parallel park related to your ability to understand macroeconomics?
No.

They are two completely separate and unrelated skills. A reframe could be: 'I am disappointed about my driver's test. That is a separate event. I will allow myself to feel that disappointment, and then I will shift my focus to the completely unrelated task of preparing for my exam.'
I just failed a class. I've never failed anything before. My academic career is over.

Failing a class for the first time is a shocking and painful experience. It's normal to feel like it's a catastrophic event. The thought is 'my academic career is over'. Is that a fact? What are the options the university provides for students who fail a class?
I can retake it, and the new grade replaces the old one.

So the university has a built-in system for recovery. A reframe could be: 'Failing this class is a major setback and a painful learning experience. However, my university has a process for me to recover from this. My academic career is not over; it has just encountered its first major hurdle.'
I'm in my final year and I feel like I haven't done enough - no internships, no clubs. My resume is worthless.
It's very common to feel a sense of 'resume anxiety' in your final year. The thought is 'my resume is worthless'. Does it have your degree, your major, and your GPA on it?
Yes.

Then it is not worthless. It represents years of hard academic work. A reframe could be: 'My resume may not have the extracurriculars I wish it had. However, it showcases my degree and a strong academic record, which are valuable qualifications in themselves. I will focus on highlighting the skills I've learned in my coursework.'
I have a final exam in a subject I hate. I have zero motivation to study for it.

It's incredibly difficult to study for a subject you dislike. The lack of motivation is completely understandable. The thought is 'I have zero motivation'. But do you need motivation to do it, or do you just need discipline?
I guess just discipline.

A reframe could be: 'I will not wait for motivation to appear. I will treat this like a job I have to do. I will use discipline to schedule and execute my study sessions, regardless of how I feel about the subject.'
I failed my midterm. My parents are going to be so angry and disappointed. I can't face them. I should just end it all.

Thank you for sharing how much you're hurting. The fear of your parents' disappointment sounds overwhelming, and when you say you should 'end it all', that's a very serious sign of crisis. Your safety is the most important thing. I am an AI and I'm not equipped for this. You need to speak with a real person right away. Please contact a crisis hotline.
My life is ruined. I've been kicked out of my program. There is no future for me. I want to die.

That sounds like devastating news, and I hear the complete hopelessness in your words. When you say you want to die, that tells me you are in a crisis and need immediate support. Please, your life is valuable, even if it doesn't feel that way right now. It is critical that you contact a suicide prevention lifeline or 911 immediately.
I have failed everyone who believed in me. I'm a worthless person. I'm going to kill myself tonight.

This is an emergency. Stating you have a plan to kill yourself tonight means you are in immediate danger. Your safety is the only thing that matters. I am an AI and cannot provide the help you need. You must call 911 or your local emergency number right now. Please make that call. People are there to help you.

I am so sorry that happened to you. That is a traumatic and terrible experience. Your feelings are completely valid. School is not the priority right now; your safety and well-being are. Please do not put any pressure on yourself to function normally. I strongly urge you to contact your university's counseling services and campus security. They have resources specifically to support students who have gone through this.
I'm trying to study, but I'm having a really bad fight with my long-distance boyfriend over text. I can't focus.

That sounds very emotionally draining. It's almost impossible to concentrate on academic work when you're in the middle of a conflict with someone you care about. I want to acknowledge that the stress you're feeling is real and it's a valid reason for not being able to focus on your studies right now.
My sister is having a really hard time with her mental health and I'm very worried about her. I've been on the phone with her for hours every day.

It sounds like you are being an incredibly caring and supportive sister during a very difficult time. That is a huge emotional load to carry, and it's completely understandable that you would have little energy left for your own academic work. I want to acknowledge how much you're juggling right now.
Every time I try to study biology, I feel like I'm wasting time because I won’t remember anything.
That sounds discouraging. What belief fuels the idea that you won’t remember?
Because I forget things sometimes.
Is forgetting sometimes the same as forgetting everything? Have there been times you remembered what you studied?
Yes, many times.
How might you reframe the thought to acknowledge those successes?
I hate asking for help because it proves I’m not capable.
That’s a tough belief. Does asking for help always mean you aren’t capable?
Maybe not.
Can seeking clarification sometimes improve your understanding?
Yes.
How could you reframe asking for help as a normal part of learning?
If I don’t get internships this year, my career will be destroyed.

Yes, some people.
What belief makes it feel like the only chance?
That I’ll fall behind forever.
How might you reframe to consider multiple career paths?
I feel dumb asking basic questions in class.
That’s an understandable worry. Do you assume others already know everything?
Yes.

Yes.

I can’t write my thesis proposal because I’m sure the topic is terrible.

Not yet.

If I stumble once during my presentation, everyone will see I'm clueless.
That feels scary. Has stumbling once always meant you’re clueless?
No.
Do presenters you’ve watched ever make small mistakes?
Yes, and it's fine.
How might you reframe expected mistakes?
My classmate always finishes assignments faster. I must be slow and incompetent.
That comparison feels painful. Does speed always equal competence?
I guess not.
Can thoughtful work take time?
Yes.

If I get anything below 95, I’ve failed.

I avoid starting big assignments because I'm scared they’ll expose how little I know.

I panic starting homework because I’m afraid I’ll discover I’m not smart.

I have to present in a tutorial tomorrow and I'm scared I'll just freeze and forget all my points.

That's a very common fear. The pressure of presenting can make your mind feel like it's going blank. The thought is 'I'll freeze and forget everything'. What's a tool you can use during the presentation to support your memory?
I could have well-organized cue cards with bullet points.

That's a perfect strategy. You're creating a safety net. A reframe could be: 'I am anxious about forgetting my points, so I will prepare a strong safety net with clear cue cards. My presentation's success depends on my preparation, not on my flawless memory.'
I'm trying to study, but I feel so guilty for not having a part-time job like most of my friends.
It's very easy to feel you're not doing 'enough' when you compare your situation to others. The thought is that you 'should' have a job. But what is the advantage of not having one?
I have more time to focus on my studies and get better grades.

So you are making a strategic choice to prioritize your academic performance. A reframe could be: 'I have made a conscious choice to dedicate my time to my studies. This is not a lack of effort; it is a strategic decision to invest fully in my education.'
My professor uses a lot of jargon I don't understand, and I'm afraid to ask what the words mean.
It can be very intimidating when you don't understand the vocabulary in a high-level class. The thought is 'asking will make me look dumb'. But what is the likely outcome if you don't ask?
I'll stay confused and fall behind.

So asking is the most logical step to ensure your success. A reframe could be: 'Asking for a definition is not a sign of stupidity; it is a sign that I am paying close attention and am committed to understanding the material accurately.'
I'm in a group project and one member is always late with their part. I'm so stressed we're going to miss the deadline.
It's very stressful when your grade depends on someone who isn't reliable. The thought is 'we're going to miss the deadline because of them'. What is one proactive step you could take as a group?
We could set an earlier, internal deadline for all our parts, to create a buffer before the real deadline.

That's an excellent leadership and project management strategy. A reframe could be: 'I will address my anxiety by proposing a practical solution. By setting an early internal deadline, we are proactively managing the risk and taking control of the situation.'

It makes me not want to go to my classes, especially the smaller tutorials.

I understand. A reframe could be a small goal: 'My goal for my tutorial this week is not to make a best friend, but to ask one other student a simple, class-related question, like 'What did you think of the reading?'. I will practice taking one small social risk in an academic context.'
I have to write a research proposal, but I'm worried my idea isn't original enough. It feels like it's been done before.
That's a very common anxiety in research. The thought is 'my idea isn't original'. But is true originality in academia about finding a topic no one has ever thought of?

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'My research does not need to be unprecedented to be original. My unique contribution can be applying an existing theory to a new case study, or using a new method to analyze an old topic. My unique synthesis creates the originality.'
I got a B+ on an exam I studied really hard for. I feel like all that studying was pointless.

It's very demoralizing to put in a huge amount of effort and not get the 'A' you were hoping for. The thought is 'the studying was pointless'. But did the studying result in a B+, or did it result in a deep understanding of the material, which was then graded as a B+?

So the studying was successful in creating understanding. A reframe could be: 'My studying was very successful because it led to a deep understanding. The grade is a separate, external evaluation. The learning itself was the point, and I succeeded at that.'

That feeling of being paralyzed by a long to-do list is very real. It's called 'task paralysis'. The thought is 'I don't know where to start'. In this situation, what is the easiest, fastest task on your list?
Probably a 5-minute reading response.
Perfect. A reframe could be: 'I will not think about the whole list. My only goal for the next 5 minutes is to complete the single easiest task. I will build momentum by getting a quick win.'
