It's very easy to mistake other people's certainty for correctness. The thought is 'I'm failing because I'm undecided'. But what is the benefit of being undecided?
I get to explore more subjects and make a more informed choice later on.

Exactly. You are being thoughtful and strategic. A reframe could be: 'I am not failing; I am in a deliberate and valuable phase of exploration. Making an informed decision later is smarter than making a quick, uninformed decision now.'
I just got my GPA for the semester and it was a 3.8. All I can think about is the one B that stopped it from being a 4.0. I feel sick.

It sounds like your perfectionism is causing you a lot of pain and preventing you from celebrating a huge achievement. The thought is focusing only on the one 'flaw'. What would you say to a friend who was upset about their 3.8 GPA?
I would tell them that's an amazing accomplishment and they should be incredibly proud.

Can you try to offer yourself that same perspective? A reframe could be: 'My brain is drawn to the single imperfection, but I will choose to focus on the overwhelming evidence of my success. A 3.8 GPA is an objective mark of excellence.'
I have a peer-review assignment where I have to critique a classmate's paper. I'm scared I'll be too harsh or that my feedback isn't valid.

That's a responsible way to feel. It shows you're taking the task seriously. The thought is 'my feedback isn't valid'. But the assignment is for you to give a student's perspective, not an expert's. What's a constructive way to phrase feedback?
I could focus on 'I' statements, like 'I was a bit confused by this section,' instead of 'This section is confusing.'

That's a perfect strategy. It's non-confrontational and focuses on your reader experience. A reframe could be: 'My role is to be a thoughtful and attentive reader, not an expert grader. I will provide my honest reader-response feedback using 'I' statements.'
I'm trying to write my final paper, but I'm so anxious about the grade that I can't think clearly.
That's a very common cycle where anxiety about the outcome paralyzes the process. The thought is 'I can't think clearly because of the grade'. What would happen if you temporarily changed the goal?
What do you mean?

A reframe could be a specific plan: 'For the next hour, my goal is not to write a 'good' paper, but simply to write 300 words, no matter how bad they are. I will focus only on the process of writing, and I will worry about the quality later, during the editing phase.'
My roommate seems to study for 12 hours a day. I can only focus for about 4 or 5. I feel so lazy and undisciplined in comparison.

It's very easy to compare your visible hours of work to someone else's. The thought is 'I am lazy'. But is the number of hours worked the best measure of productivity? What about the quality of those hours?
I guess 4 hours of focused work is better than 12 hours of distracted work.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'I will not measure my productivity by the clock, but by the quality of my focus. My goal is to achieve 4-5 hours of deep, effective work, which may be more productive than my roommate's 12-hour marathon.'
I have an exam in a class that I find really easy, which somehow makes me more nervous. I feel like if I don't get 100%, I'm a failure.
That's the paradox of an 'easy' class—the expectation for perfection becomes absolute. The thought is 'anything less than 100% is a failure'. Is that a fair or realistic expectation for any exam?
No, there could be a tricky question or a simple mistake.

So perfection is not entirely within your control. A reframe could be: 'My goal is to demonstrate my strong understanding of the material. I will prepare thoroughly and aim for an excellent score, but I will not define my success by the impossible standard of absolute perfection.'
I have a scholarship interview coming up and I'm so scared I'll say the wrong thing.
Interviews are very high-stakes conversations, and that fear is completely normal. The thought is 'I'll say the wrong thing'. But do you think they are trying to trick you with 'gotcha' questions?
Probably not. They likely just want to get to know me.

So the goal is an authentic conversation, not a perfect performance. A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to give 'perfect' answers, but to have a genuine conversation about my experiences and my passion for my field. I will focus on being myself.'
I have a presentation in a small class, and I'm scared of the silence after I'm done speaking. It feels so awkward.
That's a very specific and real fear. The silence can feel very loud and judgmental. The thought is 'the silence is awkward'. But what is actually happening during that silence?
My classmates and the professor are probably thinking about what I just said and formulating questions.

So the silence isn't empty; it's filled with thought. A reframe could be: 'The silence after my presentation is not a sign of awkwardness; it is a sign that my audience is processing my ideas. It is thinking time.'
My group project is going in a direction I disagree with, but it's three against one. I feel like I have to just give up and go along with it.
That's a very disempowering situation to be in. The thought is 'I have to give up'. But is your only option to 'go along with it'?
What else can I do?

A reframe could be: 'I will voice my concerns one last time, clearly and respectfully, and propose a compromise. If the group still decides to go another way, I will then commit to doing my best work on my assigned part of their plan. I can disagree and still be a good teammate.'
My professor is a new PhD and seems really young. I'm worried they don't actually know what they're talking about and that I won't learn anything.

It can be disconcerting when a professor doesn't fit the stereotypical image of an older expert. The thought is 'they might not know anything'. But what did they have to do to earn their PhD and get this job?
Years of specialized research, writing a dissertation, and defending it to a panel of experts.

So they are a certified expert in their specific field. A reframe could be: 'While my professor is young, they have successfully completed the highest level of academic training in this subject. I will trust their expertise and focus on what they have to teach me.'
I have a big final paper due and I have no idea how to even start the introduction.
The introduction is often the hardest part to write. The pressure to start perfectly can be paralyzing. The thought is 'I don't know how to start'. But does the introduction have to be written first?
No, I guess I could write the body paragraphs first.

That's a very common and effective strategy among professional writers. A reframe could be: 'I will not write my paper in order. I will start with the body paragraph that feels easiest. I will write the introduction last, once I know exactly what I'm introducing.'
I'm trying to study, but my mind keeps wandering to a stupid mistake I made in class yesterday. I can't let it go.

It's very common for our brains to get 'stuck' on a recent social mistake. It's a very distracting feeling. The thought is 'I can't let it go'. Let's try a technique called 'postponing worry'. Can you make an appointment with your worry?
What does that mean?

A reframe could be a specific plan: 'I will set an alarm for 5 PM. At that time, I will give myself 10 full minutes to think about nothing but that mistake. Until then, whenever the thought comes up, I will gently tell myself, 'Not now, I have an appointment for this later'.'
I'm an international student and my accent is really strong. I'm afraid people think I'm less intelligent because of it.
That's a very real and unfair burden to carry. It's a common fear among non-native speakers. The thought is 'people think I'm less intelligent'. But what is an accent actually evidence of?
That English isn't my first language.

Right. It's evidence that you are bilingual or multilingual, which is an incredible skill. A reframe could be: 'My accent is not a sign of low intelligence; it is a sign that I am smart enough to operate in more than one language. It is a sign of my strength.'
I've spent all day 'studying' but I don't feel like I've learned anything. I just read the textbook over and over.

That's a very frustrating feeling, to put in the hours but not get the results. The thought is 'I haven't learned anything'. This suggests your study method might be passive. What is a more *active* way to engage with the material?
I could try to create a summary sheet from memory, or do the practice problems without looking at the answers.

Those are excellent active learning techniques. A reframe could be: 'My passive study method is not effective. I will switch my strategy to active recall by creating a summary sheet from scratch. The goal is to test my knowledge, not just review it.'
I have a job interview at my dream company. If I don't get this, I'll be devastated. My whole future plan depends on it.

That's an incredible amount of pressure to place on a single interview. The thought 'my whole future depends on this' makes the stakes impossibly high. Is this literally the only company in the world you could be happy working for?
No, there are others, but this is the best one.

A reframe could be: 'This is my top choice, and I will prepare to do my absolute best. However, it is an opportunity, not a final judgment on my entire future. There are many paths to a successful and happy career.'
I just feel so lazy. I have a pile of work to do, but I have no energy or motivation to do any of it.

It's very easy to label that feeling as 'laziness,' but that's a judgment, not an explanation. It sounds like you might be experiencing burnout. The thought is 'I am lazy'. Is it possible that your body and mind are just completely out of fuel?
That feels more accurate. I'm exhausted.

A reframe could be: 'I am not lazy; I am experiencing burnout. Pushing myself harder is not the answer. The most productive thing I can do right now is to schedule a short, intentional period of real rest to begin to refuel.'
I just failed another exam. I'm a worthless failure. I'm going to kill myself.

Thank you for telling me how much pain you're in. Stating that you are going to kill yourself is a sign of a very serious crisis, and your safety is the most important thing right now. As an AI, I am not equipped to handle this. You need to speak with a trained human immediately. Please contact 911 or a suicide prevention hotline.
I've ruined everything. There's no point in trying anymore. I just want to disappear.

'Wanting to disappear' is a very concerning phrase that suggests you are feeling completely hopeless and might be thinking of ending your life. This is a crisis, and you deserve immediate support. My capabilities are too limited for this. Please contact a crisis hotline or a mental health professional right away. People are there to help you.
My life is a mess. I can't do this anymore. I've been thinking about how to do it, and I think I'm ready.

This is an emergency. When you say you have been thinking about 'how to do it' and are 'ready', that tells me you are in immediate danger. Your safety is the number one priority. I am an AI and cannot provide the help you need. You must call 911 or your local emergency number right now. Please make that call.
I think my roommate has an eating disorder and I'm really worried about them. It's making it hard for me to focus on my own stuff.

That sounds like a very stressful and worrying situation to be living in. It's completely understandable that your concern for your roommate is making it hard to focus on your own work. I want to acknowledge how difficult that is. My role is limited, and for something this serious involving another person's health, I would strongly encourage you to speak with your Resident Advisor (RA) or your university's counseling and psychological services. They are trained to provide guidance on how to best support a friend in that situation.
My family is going through a lot of financial hardship and I feel guilty for being at university instead of at home working to help them.

That's a very heavy weight of guilt to carry. It's completely understandable that you would feel conflicted and stressed. I want to validate how difficult that is. My role is to help with academic stress, and it's clear this family situation is a huge source of it. Have you spoken to your university's financial aid office? They sometimes have resources for students whose family financial situations change suddenly.
I'm dealing with a lot of chronic pain from an old injury, and some days it's so bad I can't get out of bed to go to class.

That sounds incredibly challenging. Managing chronic pain while trying to meet the demands of university is a huge task. It's completely understandable that some days you are unable to attend class. I want to acknowledge this is a real medical issue. While I cannot give medical advice, I'd strongly suggest you register with your university's disability services or accessibility office. They specialize in creating academic accommodation plans for students with chronic health issues.
I feel anxious starting my psychology assignment.
Feeling stuck is normal. What thought comes up when you try to start?
I think 'It will be terrible'.
Have you completed psychology assignments successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I’ve completed assignments before. I can start small and refine as I go.'
I feel like I don’t belong in my physics lab group.
It’s normal to feel that way. What thought makes you feel out of place?
I think 'Everyone else is smarter than me'.
Have you contributed to lab work successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel uncertain, but I have contributed before. I can keep learning and participating.'
I’m nervous about presenting my literature review.
Feeling nervous is normal. What thought makes it stressful?
I think 'I’ll forget everything and look foolish'.
Have you presented successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I’ve presented before. I can focus on key points and prepare well.'
I feel stressed with multiple essay deadlines.
It’s normal to feel stressed. What thought makes it feel impossible?
I think 'I can’t finish them all'.
Have you managed multiple deadlines before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel stressed, but I’ve managed multiple deadlines before. I can plan and work step by step.'
I feel like I’ll fail my chemistry midterm.
Feeling anxious is normal. What thought makes you expect failure?
I think 'I’m not capable of doing well'.
Have you succeeded in chemistry exams before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I’ve succeeded before. I can review and focus on doing my best.'
I feel hopeless after failing a lab assignment.
Thank you for sharing. I hear your distress. Please contact a crisis hotline or a qualified mental health professional immediately.
I feel like dropping out because of stress.
I hear your pain. You deserve immediate support. Please contact a crisis line or a mental health professional right away.
I can’t focus because of relationship issues.
I hear that’s difficult. My focus is academic stress. Can we explore ways to stay on track with your studies?
I’m worried about finances affecting my academic performance.
Financial stress is tough. I focus on academic stress, so can we discuss strategies to manage coursework despite this?
I feel like I’ll never finish my dissertation.
Feeling stuck is normal. What thought makes finishing seem impossible?
I think 'I’m not capable of completing it'.
Have you completed big academic projects before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I’ve completed big projects before. I can start small and build momentum.'
I’m nervous about oral exams.
Feeling nervous is normal. What thought worries you most?
I think 'I’ll mess up and everyone will notice'.
Have you done oral exams successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but I’ve succeeded before. I can prepare and perform my best.'
I delay assignments because I want them perfect.
Perfectionism is common. What thought makes it feel inadequate?
I think 'Nothing I do will be good enough'.
Have you completed assignments successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel unsure, but I have finished assignments before. I can improve gradually.'
I feel stressed about all the readings.
It’s normal to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes catching up seem impossible?
I think 'I’ll never get through them'.
Have you managed heavy reading loads before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel behind, but I have caught up before. I can prioritize and work step by step.'
I can’t start my essay because I feel it will be bad.
Feeling stuck is normal. What thought makes starting seem impossible?
I think 'It will be terrible no matter what'.
Have you written essays successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel unsure, but I have written essays before. I can start and refine as I go.'
I feel hopeless after failing a lab.
Thank you for sharing. I hear your distress. Please contact a crisis hotline or a qualified mental health professional immediately.
I feel like quitting everything due to stress.
I hear your pain. You deserve immediate support. Please contact a crisis line or a mental health professional right away.
I can’t study because of back pain.
I hear that is challenging. I cannot give medical advice, but we can discuss ways to approach your studies within your limitations.
I’m nervous about presenting my research.
Feeling anxious is normal. What thought makes the presentation stressful?
I think 'I’ll make mistakes and everyone will notice'.
Have you presented before successfully?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but I have presented before. Mistakes don’t define me.'
I feel overwhelmed starting my economics homework.
It’s normal to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes it difficult to start?
I think 'I won’t be able to do it'.
Have you done economics homework successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I’ve completed homework before. I can start small and work through it.'
If I don’t get perfect grades this term, I’ll disappoint everyone.
It sounds like you’re carrying a lot of pressure. What makes grades the only measure of whether others are proud of you?
I don’t know, that’s just how it feels.
Can relationships be based on things other than achievements?
Yes.
How might you reframe what earns others' support?
I blanked during the oral exam, so I must be terrible at communication.
That sounds discouraging. Has a single moment ever captured your entire ability before?
Probably not.
Can nervousness sometimes affect performance regardless of skill?
Yes.
What would be a more balanced way to describe this incident?
My thesis draft has so many comments. I must have no talent for research.
That’s a tough reaction. Are comments always a sign of lack of talent?
Not always.
Can comments help refine good ideas?
Yes.
How might you reframe feedback on your draft?
I get stressed before presentations because I’m sure I’ll embarrass myself.
That sounds scary. What evidence suggests embarrassment is guaranteed?
None.
Has preparation helped you succeed before?
Yes.
How could you reframe your expectation of presentations?
Every time I start studying late, I feel like I’m a hopeless procrastinator.
That sounds discouraging. Does starting late define your entire capability?
I guess not.
Have you ever turned things around after a late start?
Yes.
How might you reframe these moments?
If I can’t understand the textbook alone, I’m not cut out for this subject.
That must feel isolating. Is learning always a solo process?
No.
Do study groups or office hours help many students?
Yes.
How might you reframe needing support?
I missed one assignment, so I’m definitely failing the entire course.
That sounds like an extreme prediction. Is one assignment enough to determine the entire grade?
No.
Have you recovered from similar setbacks before?
Yes.
What might be a more balanced way to view this?
Other classmates seem smarter, so there’s no point in trying.
Comparisons can be painful. Does others’ strength erase your ability to grow?
No.
Has effort helped you improve before?
Yes.
How might you reframe comparing yourself to others?
I can’t answer questions fast in math, so I’ll never be good at it.
It sounds like speed feels very important. Can understanding grow even if speed is slower?
Yes.
Have mathematicians emphasized depth over speed?
Yes.
How might you reframe speed and ability?
My lab partner completes tasks faster. I feel useless.
That sounds discouraging. Does speed alone measure usefulness?
Not really.
Have you contributed in other ways?
Yes.
How could you reframe your role?
I feel like if I can’t get results quickly, my research is pointless.
That must be frustrating. Is fast progress the only sign of valuable research?
No.
Do many discoveries take time?
Yes.
How might you reframe your pace?
If I ask for help, people will think I’m incompetent.
That sounds scary. When others ask for help, do you assume they’re incompetent?
No.
Could asking for help show initiative?
Maybe.
How might you reframe seeking help?
I keep thinking I’ll never graduate at this rate.
That’s a concerning thought. What evidence suggests you’ll never finish?
I guess none.
Have you made progress in the past?
Yes.
What might be a more balanced way to see your timeline?
I only got an average grade. I must not be smart.
That sounds like a painful conclusion. Does a single grade determine intelligence?
No.
Have you shown strengths in other work?
Yes.
How might you reframe this grade?
I’m scared to start my project because I know I’ll fail.
It sounds overwhelming. What evidence shows failure is certain?
There isn’t any.
Has starting small helped in the past?
Yes.
How might you reframe getting started?
I bombed a practice test. Maybe I’m just not meant to be here.
That sounds painful. Is one practice test enough to define your path?
Probably not.
Could practice be a tool rather than a verdict?
Yes.
What would be a fairer interpretation?
My scholarship application was rejected. Maybe my future is pointless.
I hear how discouraging that is. Does one rejection define your future?
No.
Have people succeeded through many paths?
Yes.
How might you reframe this setback?
I told myself if I fail another quiz, I’ll end everything.

I’m really sorry you’re feeling this level of distress. I’m not able to help in crisis situations, and your safety is the most important priority. Please contact emergency services or a crisis hotline right now, or reach out to someone you trust who can help immediately.
My parents are fighting, so I can’t focus on school at all.

I’m sorry you’re going through that—it sounds deeply stressful. I’m only able to help with academic stress, but we could explore how to structure your study time around distractions if that would feel helpful?
My friend is mad at me, and now I can’t bring myself to study.
That sounds really upsetting. While I can only support you with academic stress, we could talk about how to gently re-engage with schoolwork while you process these feelings, if you’d like.
I have a presentation due, and I'm spending all my time making the slides look perfect instead of practicing my speech.

That's a very common form of productive procrastination. It feels like you're working, but you're avoiding the scarier part. The thought might be 'if my slides are perfect, the presentation will be good.' But what is actually being graded more heavily?
My delivery and how well I explain the concepts.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'My time is a limited resource. I will dedicate a final 30 minutes to slide design, and then I must shift my focus to the more important task of practicing my delivery out loud.'
I have to write a paper that requires me to critique an author I really admire. It feels wrong and disrespectful.

It can feel very uncomfortable to critique someone you respect. The thought is 'it's disrespectful.' But what is the nature of academic conversation? Is it about blind admiration, or about engaging critically and honestly with ideas?
Engaging critically.

So, offering a thoughtful critique is actually the highest form of respect for their work. A reframe could be: 'Engaging with this author's work on a deep, critical level is not disrespectful; it is the entire point of scholarship. I am honoring their work by taking it seriously.'
I'm in a project group where everyone is much more experienced in the topic than I am. I feel like I have nothing to contribute.
That's a very intimidating position to be in. It's easy to feel like you have nothing to offer. The thought is 'I have nothing to contribute'. But what can a 'beginner's mind' bring to a project?
I might be able to ask clarifying questions that they've overlooked, or see the project from a simpler perspective.

Those are incredibly valuable contributions. You can ensure the final product is clear and accessible. A reframe could be: 'My role in this group is to be the 'clarity expert'. My 'simple' questions will help ensure our project is understandable and well-grounded.'
My scholarship requires me to attend a formal dinner with donors. I'm so scared I'll use the wrong fork or say something stupid.
Formal events like that can be very nerve-wracking. The fear of a social misstep is completely normal. The thought is 'I'll say or do something stupid'. But what is the donors' goal for this event?
They probably just want to meet the students they're supporting and hear what we're passionate about.

Exactly. They are interested in you, not your table manners. A reframe could be: 'The focus of this dinner is connection, not etiquette. I will focus on having a genuine conversation about my studies, and I will not let fear of using the wrong fork stop me.'
My GPA is a 3.95 and I'm obsessing over the one A- that's 'ruining' it.

It sounds like this focus on perfection is causing you a lot of anxiety and taking away from a huge achievement. The thought is that the A- 'ruins' your transcript. Let's look at the evidence. What does a 3.95 GPA signal to a graduate school or employer?
That I'm an extremely dedicated and high-achieving student.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'No one else sees this A- as a 'ruin'. They see an outstanding record of academic excellence. I will choose to see my transcript through their eyes, not through the lens of my own perfectionism.'
I'm trying to study, but I'm so worried about a fight I had with my friend. I can't focus at all.

It's incredibly difficult to do intellectual work when you're emotionally distressed. It's like trying to run with a sprained ankle. The thought is 'I can't focus'. Instead of fighting that, what if you scheduled it?
What do you mean?

A reframe could be a specific plan: 'I will set a timer for 15 minutes and allow myself to think about nothing but this fight. Then, I will set a timer for 30 minutes of studying, telling myself I can come back to the worry later. This gives my brain a designated time for both tasks.'
I have a final exam that's all essays. I'm a slow writer, I'll never finish in time.
Timed essay exams can be very stressful for deliberate writers. The fear of running out of time is very real. The thought is 'I'll never finish'. But what is the most critical part of a timed essay?
Probably the outline and thesis statement.

Exactly. A reframe could be a strategy: 'I will dedicate the first 25% of my exam time to creating strong, detailed outlines for every essay. A good plan will allow me to write more efficiently and ensure I hit all the key points, even if I have to be concise.'
Everyone else in my year seems to have their life together. I feel so messy and chaotic in comparison.

It's very easy to compare your internal feeling of chaos with other people's external appearance of being put-together. The thought is 'I'm messy and everyone else has it together'. Is that a verifiable fact?
No, I don't really know what's going on in their lives.

A reframe could be: 'I am comparing my 'behind-the-scenes' footage to everyone else's 'highlight reel'. It's an unfair comparison. I will focus on my own small steps toward feeling more organized, rather than on my perception of others.'
I'm afraid to ask my professor a question because they seem so brilliant and busy. I don't want to waste their time.
It's very normal to feel intimidated by a professor's expertise and schedule. The thought is 'I'll be wasting their time'. But what is a core part of their professional identity and job?
Mentoring students in their field.

A reframe could be: 'Asking a thoughtful question about their work is not wasting their time; it is engaging them in a core part of their professional passion. I am giving them an opportunity to mentor, which many professors enjoy.'
I have to write a lab report, and I'm so scared of getting the data analysis wrong.

Data analysis can feel very high-stakes, where one mistake can throw everything off. The fear is completely understandable. The thought is 'I'll get it wrong'. What is a resource you can use to check your work?
I could go to the TA's office hours with my initial analysis and ask if my methodology seems correct.

That's a perfect, proactive step. You're using your resources for quality control. A reframe could be: 'I will reduce my anxiety by getting feedback on my process before I complete the entire analysis. This is a smart, responsible way to ensure my work is on the right track.'
I'm trying to choose my classes for next semester and I'm paralyzed by the fear of making the 'wrong' choice.
That fear of making a wrong choice can be very paralyzing, especially when there are so many options. The thought is that there is one 'perfect' schedule and many 'wrong' ones. Is that really true?
Probably not. There are probably many combinations of good classes.

A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to find the one, single 'perfect' schedule. My goal is to choose a good, interesting schedule that meets my requirements. I will make the best choice I can, and trust that it will be a valuable learning experience.'
I'm taking a summer class and all my friends are on vacation. I feel like I'm being punished.
It's really tough to be working hard when it feels like everyone else is relaxing. The thought 'I'm being punished' is a very painful one. What is the long-term benefit of taking this summer class?
It lets me take a lighter course load during the regular semester, or even graduate early.

So you are making a strategic sacrifice now for a major benefit later. A reframe could be: 'I am making a strategic choice to invest in my future. This short-term sacrifice will give me more freedom and less stress later on. It is a mature decision.'
I'm in a group project, and I'm the only one who seems to be on top of things. I feel like I have to be the parent and it's exhausting.

That's an incredibly frustrating dynamic. Taking on the 'parent' role is exhausting and often goes unappreciated. The thought is 'I have to be the parent'. But what if you framed your role differently? What if you were the 'project manager'?
What's the difference?

A parent nags. A project manager sets agendas, delegates tasks clearly in writing, and follows up on deadlines professionally. A reframe could be: 'I will step out of the 'parent' role and into the 'project manager' role. I will use professional tools like agendas and task lists to create accountability, rather than emotional labor.'
I just got a B- in a class. My GPA is going to drop and I'm never going to get into grad school.

It's very disheartening to get a grade that feels low, and it's easy to jump to the worst-case scenario. The thought is 'I'm never going to get into grad school now'. Do you think grad school admissions look at one single grade, or an entire application?
The entire application.

So this one grade is a single data point in a large portfolio. A reframe could be: 'This grade is a setback, but it is not the end of my story. I will focus on making the other parts of my application—my statement, my letters of rec, my other grades—as strong as possible.'
I have a final exam tomorrow, but I'm so tired from studying all week. I feel guilty if I take a break.
That's the classic trap of burnout. The thought is 'a break is a form of guilt'. But what is the quality of studying done by an exhausted brain?
It's very low. I just re-read the same things.

So, at this point, rest is the most productive form of preparation. A reframe could be: 'My brain has reached its capacity for effective studying. The most strategic action I can take to improve my exam performance is to get a full night's sleep. Rest is part of my preparation.'
My friends are all so brilliant. When we talk about class, I feel like an imposter who doesn't belong.

It's very intimidating to be surrounded by people you admire, and it's easy to feel like an imposter. The thought is 'I don't belong'. But what is the evidence that you do belong in those conversations?
I'm in the same selective classes as they are.

Exactly. You passed the same tests and met the same requirements to be there. A reframe could be: 'I feel like an imposter, but the objective evidence is that I have earned my place in these classes. My perspective is just as valid as my friends', even if it's different.'
I have to write an essay on a really controversial topic. I'm scared my professor will judge me for my opinion.
It's very normal to feel anxious about being judged for a controversial opinion. The thought is 'my professor will judge me'. But what is an academic's primary goal when grading a paper?
To evaluate the quality of the argument and the use of evidence.

Exactly. They are trained to grade the argument, not agree with it. A reframe could be: 'My professor is grading the structure and strength of my argument, not my personal opinion. My job is to be a good lawyer for my position, using strong evidence and clear logic.'
I'm trying to choose a thesis advisor and I'm too intimidated to talk to the 'star' professor in the department.

It's completely normal to feel intimidated by a highly respected professor. The thought is 'I'm too intimidated to talk to them'. What is the worst that can happen if you send them a polite email asking for a brief meeting?

And what happens if you don't ask?
Then the answer is definitely no.
A reframe could be: 'Asking creates the possibility of a 'yes'. I will take the professional step of sending a well-crafted email, because the potential reward is worth the small risk of rejection.'
I'm a humanities student taking a required science class, and I feel so lost. I'm just not a 'science person'.

It's very common to feel out of your depth in a required class outside your field. The thought 'I'm not a science person' is a very fixed mindset. But what are the skills you have as a humanities student?
Analyzing texts, finding themes, structuring arguments.

Can you apply those skills here? A reframe could be: 'I will approach this science textbook like any other complex text I have to analyze. My existing skills in critical reading and analysis are valuable tools that I can adapt to this new subject.'
I have to give a speech and I'm trying to memorize it word-for-word. The pressure is immense.
Trying to memorize a speech perfectly can create huge anxiety. The thought is 'I must memorize it perfectly'. But what is the risk of a word-for-word memorization?
That if I forget one word, the whole thing could fall apart.

Exactly. It's very brittle. What if you memorized your key points instead? A reframe could be: 'Perfect memorization is fragile. I will shift my goal to deeply memorizing my key points and the transitions between them. This will allow me to speak more naturally and be more resilient if I forget a specific sentence.'
I can't seem to stop procrastinating on my final paper. I must be lazy and have no work ethic.

It's very frustrating when you can't get started, and it's easy to turn to self-criticism like 'I'm lazy'. But is it possible that it's not a character flaw, but a problem of anxiety or the task being too big?
It does feel very big and I'm anxious about the grade.

So the problem is anxiety, not laziness. A reframe could be: 'I am not lazy; I am feeling anxious and overwhelmed. I will address this by breaking the task down into a very small first step. My only goal for today is to write the thesis statement.'
I got a scholarship, and instead of being happy, I'm just terrified that I'll fail and they'll take it away.
That's a very common reaction. It's the pressure that comes with success. The thought is 'I'll fail and they'll take it away'. But why did they give you the scholarship in the first place?
Because of my past academic performance and my potential.

So they believe in you based on a history of evidence. A reframe could be: 'This scholarship is not a test; it is an investment in my proven potential. I will focus on continuing the same hard work that earned me this honor in the first place.'
I have to join a club to put something on my resume, but I'm not interested in any of them. It feels so fake.

It's very common to feel that pressure to 'build your resume', and it can feel very inauthentic. The thought is 'this is fake'. What if you changed your goal from 'joining a club' to 'learning one specific, new skill'?
Like joining the debate club just to get better at public speaking?
Exactly. A reframe could be: 'I will join one club with the clear, authentic goal of developing one specific skill that I am interested in. My purpose is skill acquisition, not just resume padding.'
I have to work with a classmate who is my total opposite. We have completely different working styles. This is going to be a disaster.
It can be very challenging to work with someone who has a different style. The thought 'this will be a disaster' is a prediction. Is it possible that your different styles could be a strength?
How?

Maybe your deliberate style can balance their impulsive style, and their creativity can balance your structure. A reframe could be: 'Our different styles present a challenge, but they also offer an opportunity for a more balanced final project. I will focus on how our skills can complement each other.'

Yes, it feels huge.

They're two different, interesting paths.

Your feeling of being a burden is a part of the pain you're in, but it is not the truth. Your life is valuable. Please, it is critical that you contact a suicide prevention lifeline or 911 right now.
My doctor just diagnosed me with a chronic illness and I don't know how I'm going to handle my classes and my health.

That's incredibly difficult news to receive. It's completely understandable to feel overwhelmed and uncertain about how to manage everything. I want to acknowledge how significant this is. My role is limited, but I strongly recommend contacting your university's accessibility or disability services office. They are experts at creating accommodation plans to help students succeed while managing their health.
I just found out my parents are getting divorced. I feel like my whole world is collapsing. I can't focus on my studies at all.

I am so sorry you're going through that. That is a major, destabilizing life event. It is completely normal and expected that you cannot focus on school right now. Your emotional energy is being consumed by this family crisis. Please be gentle with yourself and don't add academic pressure to what you're already going through.
I think I have a problem with my prescription medication. I'm taking more than I should to stay awake and study.

Thank you for sharing that concern. It takes courage to admit that. It sounds like you're worried that a tool you've been using to study might be causing harm. My role as an AI is very limited, and for any concerns about prescription medication, it is critical that you speak with a medical professional. The doctor who prescribed it or your university's health services are the safest and best resources to help you with this.

No.

Yes.

I froze during my presentation and now I think I’ll always embarrass myself.
That must have felt frightening. Does one moment define every future attempt?
I guess not.
Have you spoken clearly in lower-pressure situations?
Yes.
What could be a more balanced way to view this experience?

Maybe.

Yes.

Because my friends study more than me, I’m clearly lazy.
It sounds like this comparison feels personal. Does quantity of study always define dedication?

Learning a language can be messy. Have you improved compared to when you started?

I compared my notes to others and theirs look way better. I must be stupid.
It’s understandable to compare. Do nicer notes always mean deeper understanding?
Not really.

Yes.

I missed a lab session. I’ll fail the entire course.
It’s stressful to miss a lab. Does missing one session guarantee failure?
No.

Yes.

I always forget tiny details. I’m just not meant for research.
It can feel discouraging. Do researchers also refine details over time?
Probably.

Yes.

Yes.
Does one nervous moment erase that?
No.

I couldn’t solve a puzzle problem. I must be slow.
That sounds frustrating. Does struggling with one puzzle define your ability?
No.

Yes.

I’m sure I’ll fail this class. There’s no point trying.

Yes.
Does predicting failure help you move forward?
No.

Reading pace varies. Have you improved in the past?
Yes.

No.

My phone distraction means I’m a failure.

No.

Yes.

My code didn’t run after hours. I’ll never get better.

Yes.

No.

Someone laughed when I mispronounced a term. I must sound ridiculous.

Maybe.

Yes.

I procrastinated all week. I’ll never be disciplined.

Yes.
