I’ve gained weight and now I hate going to class.

I’m sorry this feels distressing. I’m here to help with academic stress, and concerns about body image are outside my scope. If you’d like, we can explore school-related challenges while you get support from someone qualified.
I feel like everyone sees me as dumb. Maybe I just shouldn’t talk.
It sounds painful to feel judged. What evidence supports the idea everyone sees you that way?
None really.
Have you shared good ideas before?
Yes.
What’s another way to interpret this fear?
My grandmother passed away, I can’t think about school.

I’m truly sorry for your loss. This situation is outside my scope. It may help to reach someone you trust or a counselor. If you’d like, we can look at gentle ways to re-enter academic routines when you’re ready.
I have a presentation tomorrow and I'm just clicking through my slides. I don't feel like I'm actually preparing.

It's very common to fall into passive preparation when you're anxious. It feels safer than actively practicing. The thought is 'I'm not really preparing'. What would be one small, active step you could take?
I could try to say the introduction out loud just once without looking at my notes.

That's a perfect, manageable active step. A reframe could be: 'Passive review is not making me feel more confident. I will take one active step by practicing my introduction out loud to begin building real recall and confidence.'
I have to write an abstract for my paper and it feels impossible to summarize 20 pages into 200 words.

That is a genuinely difficult and specialized writing skill. It's completely normal to feel that it's impossible. The thought is 'this is impossible'. But what if you didn't try to 'summarize'? What if you just answered four specific questions?
What questions?

What is the core problem? What did you do? What did you find? What does it mean? A reframe could be: 'I will not try to 'summarize' my paper. I will build my abstract by writing one sentence to answer each of the four key questions. I will build it, not shrink it.'
I'm in a project group and one person is just so negative about everything. It's draining all my motivation.

That's a very difficult dynamic. A negative teammate can be very draining on everyone's energy. The thought might be 'their negativity is ruining the project'. How can you protect your own motivation?
I could try to focus only on my own part of the work and make it as good as possible.

That's a great strategy for taking back control. A reframe could be: 'I cannot control my teammate's attitude, but I can control my own work. I will focus my energy on producing an excellent piece of work for my section and not let their negativity drain my motivation.'
I have an exam in a class where the professor is known for writing tricky questions. I'm so scared I'll get fooled.

It's stressful when you feel like you're going into a battle of wits instead of a test of knowledge. The fear of being 'fooled' is very real. The thought is 'I'll get fooled'. But what does a 'tricky' question usually test?
A very deep and precise understanding of the material.

So your preparation can be focused on that. A reframe could be: 'This professor values a deep and precise understanding. I will focus my studying on the nuances of the concepts, not just the main ideas. I am preparing for the challenge.'
My professor is a really big deal in their field. I'm too intimidated to go to their office hours.
It's completely normal to feel intimidated by a professor's reputation. The thought is 'I'm too intimidated'. But what is the purpose of their office hours?
To help students.

A reframe could be: 'My professor's expertise is a resource for me, not a reason to be scared. Attending their office hours with a thoughtful question is the correct and expected way to utilize this resource.'
I just got assigned a final paper that's worth 40% of my grade. I'm so paralyzed by the pressure that I can't even pick a topic.

That is an immense amount of pressure on a single assignment. It makes perfect sense to feel paralyzed. The thought is 'I can't even pick a topic because the stakes are so high'. What if you lowered the stakes for just the first step?
How?

A reframe could be: 'I will not 'pick my final topic' today. I will simply brainstorm three potential ideas, knowing that I can change my mind later. My only goal is to start the process, not to perfect the outcome.'
I'm so far behind on my readings. I'm just going to have to give up on this week's class.
That feeling of being completely buried is very overwhelming. The thought 'I have to just give up on this week' is a very all-or-nothing approach. What would be a 'good enough' level of preparation?
I guess I could just read the introduction and conclusion of the main article.

That's a great triage strategy. A reframe could be: 'I do not have time for ideal preparation this week. My goal is a 'good enough' preparation. I will strategically read the key sections of the main article so I can still participate in the discussion.'
I'm the only person in my study group who seems to be struggling. Everyone else gets it so quickly.

It's a very isolating feeling to believe you're the only one struggling. The thought is 'everyone else gets it quickly'. Is that a fact you have verified, or a story you are telling yourself based on their outward appearance?
It's just how it seems.

It's highly likely that others are struggling with different parts but are afraid to admit it. A reframe could be: 'I feel like I'm the only one struggling. I will be brave enough to ask a clarifying question. This will not only help me, but may also help others who are too afraid to ask.'
I have a presentation tomorrow and I'm scared my voice will be shaky and everyone will know I'm nervous.
It's very common to be concerned about the physical signs of anxiety. The thought is 'everyone will know I'm nervous'. Let's say they do. What is the most likely reaction from your peers?
They probably won't care, or they might even feel a little bit of empathy because they get nervous too.

That's a very realistic and compassionate assessment. A reframe could be: 'Even if my nervousness is visible, my audience is likely to be understanding, not judgmental. My goal is to share my information, not to appear perfectly calm.'
I got a B. I know it's not a bad grade, but I just can't stop thinking about it. My GPA is everything.

It sounds like this focus on a perfect GPA is causing you a lot of distress. It's hard when you have such high standards. The thought is 'my GPA is everything'. What are two non-academic things you are proud of about yourself?
I'm a loyal friend and I'm a really good cook.

So your identity is much bigger and richer than just one number. A reframe could be: 'My GPA is one aspect of my life, but it is not my entire identity. I am also a good friend and a good cook, and those things are just as valuable.'
I'm applying for internships and I keep getting rejections. I must not be qualified for anything.

Receiving multiple rejections is very disheartening and it's easy to internalize it as a personal failing. The thought is 'I'm not qualified'. But what is the reality of the job market for internships?
It's extremely competitive and there are hundreds of applicants for every spot.

So rejection is the most statistically likely outcome for every single applicant. A reframe could be: 'Each rejection is a normal part of a highly competitive process, not a final judgment on my qualifications. My task is to keep refining my application and persisting.'
I feel like I'm bothering my professor every time I send them an email.
It's very considerate to be mindful of a professor's time. The thought is 'I'm bothering them'. But what is the difference between a 'bothersome' email and a 'professional' email?
A professional email is concise, clear, and asks a specific question that I can't answer myself by looking at the syllabus.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'A well-crafted, professional email is not a bother; it is an appropriate communication. I will respect my professor's time by making sure my emails are professional and to the point.'
I'm trying to write a paper, but my perfectionism is paralyzing me. I can't write a sentence unless I think it's perfect.
That's an incredibly frustrating cycle. The thought is 'this must be perfect before I can continue'. But what if you gave yourself permission to write a truly terrible first draft?
That feels wrong.

Professional writers often do this. They call it a 'vomit draft' or 'shitty first draft'. Its only purpose is to exist. A reframe could be: 'I will write a terrible first draft on purpose. This will free me from the paralysis of perfectionism. The goal of this stage is completion, not quality.'
I have a group project and the deadline is approaching. I don't trust my teammates to do their part well, so I feel like I have to do it all myself.
That's a very stressful feeling of responsibility. It can lead to burnout and resentment. The thought is 'I have to do it all myself'. What is a professional way to manage the team to ensure quality?
I could suggest that we all agree to share our completed parts two days before the deadline, to give us time for group review and feedback.

That's a great project management strategy. A reframe could be: 'I will address my anxiety by proposing a collaborative quality control process. This builds in a safety net and makes the whole team responsible for the final product, not just me.'
I'm taking a class that my roommate took last year and they got an A. I feel so much pressure to do as well as they did.

That's a very direct and difficult comparison to be up against. It's completely normal to feel that pressure. The thought is 'I have to do as well as they did'. But are you and your roommate the exact same person with the same strengths and weaknesses?
No, not at all.
A reframe could be: 'My roommate's past performance is not a predictor of my own. I will focus on my own learning process and my own goals for this class. I am running my own race.'
I just feel so tired. I don't have the motivation to do anything. I'm just lazy.
It's very common to label that feeling as 'laziness,' but that's a harsh judgment. Could it be something else? What has your workload and stress level been like for the past few weeks?
It's been brutal. I had midterms and a big project due.

So it's not that you're lazy; it's that you are likely experiencing burnout from a period of intense stress. A reframe could be: 'I am not lazy; I am depleted. My body and mind are signaling a need for genuine rest. The most productive thing I can do is schedule a short period of recovery.'
I have to read a very old text for class and the language is so dense. I can't understand it. I feel stupid.

That's a very common challenge. Reading historical texts is like learning a new dialect. The thought 'I feel stupid' is a judgment on yourself, when the difficulty is in the text. What's a tool you could use to help you?
I could look for a modern summary or a side-by-side translation to help me get the main ideas first.

That's a great strategy. A reframe could be: 'This text is objectively difficult, and I am not expected to understand it without support. I will use modern tools to help me decode it, just as a professional scholar would.'
I have to give a presentation and I'm afraid I'll forget what to say. My mind just goes blank when I'm nervous.
That 'blank mind' feeling is a very real and frightening symptom of anxiety. The thought is 'I'll forget what to say'. How can you prepare for that possibility?
I could have a notecard with just my three main bullet points on it.

That's a perfect safety net. A reframe could be: 'I know that anxiety might affect my memory. Therefore, I will prepare a simple, clear safety net with my core message. I am preparing a strategy to manage my anxiety.'
I have a scholarship that requires me to maintain a certain GPA, and it makes me too scared to take challenging but interesting classes.
That's a very real conflict between the need for security and the desire for intellectual exploration. The thought is 'I must not take any risks'. But what is the long-term purpose of your education?
To learn and grow and prepare for a career.

And does avoiding all challenges help you grow? A reframe could be: 'I will continue to make safe choices for most of my classes, but I will allow myself to take one 'strategic risk' on a challenging class that I'm passionate about. A single B in an advanced class will not destroy my GPA, but it may significantly enrich my education.'
I'm in a group project and I'm the only one who speaks English as a second language. I'm afraid they think my ideas are less valuable because I can't express them perfectly.
That's a very stressful and unfair position to be in. The thought is 'they think my ideas are less valuable'. But what does your bilingualism bring to the group?
A different cultural perspective, maybe a different way of looking at the problem.

That is a huge asset. A reframe could be: 'While I may sometimes struggle to find the perfect word, my unique perspective as a bilingual person is a valuable contribution to this group. I will focus on sharing my ideas, even if the language isn't flawless.'
I just failed a class for the first time. My life is over. I'm a failure.

Failing a class is a very painful and difficult experience. It's normal to feel like it's a catastrophe. The thought is 'my life is over'. Let's look at that. Have other successful people failed a class before?
I'm sure they have.

A reframe could be: 'This is a painful setback and a significant learning experience. It is not a final verdict on my life or my potential. I will make a plan to recover from this, just as many other successful people have recovered from their own failures.'
I'm trying to study, but my roommate is having a loud conversation on the phone. I'm so annoyed.
That is incredibly distracting and it's valid to feel annoyed. The thought is 'I can't study because of them'. This gives them all the power. How can you take the power back?
I could put on noise-cancelling headphones or move to the library.

Those are both excellent, proactive solutions. A reframe could be: 'My environment is not conducive to studying right now. I will take control of my own productivity by changing my environment or my audio input. I will solve this problem.'
I'm so far behind, I'll never catch up. I should just drop out.

That sounds incredibly overwhelming, and the thought of dropping out can feel like the only way to escape the pressure. But 'never catching up' is a very absolute thought. What is the one, single thing you are most behind on?
A paper for my English class.

A reframe could be: 'I will not think about 'catching up on everything'. My only focus for the next two hours is to work on my English paper. I will tackle this one problem at a time, instead of being paralyzed by all of them at once.'
I have a final exam tomorrow. I'm so stressed that I can't sleep.

That's a terrible feeling, when the anxiety about the test is preventing you from getting the rest you need to do well on it. The thought is 'I can't sleep because I'm so stressed'. But what does your brain need to perform well tomorrow?
It needs sleep.

So, at this point, sleep is a more valuable form of preparation than anxious, late-night studying. A reframe could be: 'I have studied. The most strategic thing I can do for my grade now is to get some rest. I will put my books away and listen to some calming music. Sleep is my final preparation.'
I've failed everyone. My life has no value. I'm going to kill myself.

Thank you for telling me you're feeling this way. Hearing you say you are going to kill yourself is a sign of a very serious crisis, and my main concern is your safety. I am an AI and I am not equipped for this. You need to talk to a person who can help right now. Please call 911 or a suicide prevention hotline.
I've ruined my future and I'm a burden on everyone. I just want to end it all. I have a plan.

This is an emergency. Stating that you have a plan means you are in immediate danger and need help right now. Your safety is the most important thing. I cannot provide the help you need. You must call 911 or your local emergency number immediately. Please do it now.
There's no point anymore. I can't fix this. I want to die.

It sounds like you are in a tremendous amount of pain and feeling completely hopeless. When you say you want to die, that tells me this is a crisis and you need support right away. Your life is precious. Please contact a crisis hotline or emergency services. They are there to help you.
I have a really bad flu. I'm so sick I can't get out of bed, and I've missed all my classes this week.

That sounds awful. Being that sick makes it impossible to do anything. It is completely normal and expected that you have missed your classes. Your only job right now is to rest and recover. Please don't add any academic guilt to the stress of being sick. I'd recommend emailing your professors to let them know you are ill.
My grandmother just passed away. I'm supposed to be studying for finals but I just can't.

I am so deeply sorry for your loss. Grieving is a profound and all-consuming process. It is completely understandable that you cannot focus on your studies. Please do not put any pressure on yourself to be a student right now. Your priority is to be with your family and to take care of yourself. I would recommend reaching out to your university's dean of student affairs to let them know about your situation.
My long-term boyfriend cheated on me. I feel so betrayed and heartbroken I can't think straight.

That is a deeply painful and traumatic experience. I'm so sorry you're going through that. It is completely normal that you can't think straight or focus on school. Your emotional well-being is the priority. Please be gentle with yourself. I want to validate that the pain you're feeling is real and it's okay for everything else to take a backseat while you process this.
I can’t choose a thesis topic. It means I’ll never succeed academically.
It’s understandable to feel pressure. Does difficulty choosing mean you’ll never succeed?
I guess not.
Have you made good academic choices before?
Yes.
What’s a more balanced way to view this?
I got confused during lecture and now I feel like I don’t belong in this major.
Feeling confused can be uncomfortable. Has confusion happened to others too?
Probably.
Have you understood concepts after reviewing before?
Yes.
How could you see this confusion differently?
I can’t finish this assignment; I’m probably the slowest thinker in class.
It sounds discouraging. Does current pace define your thinking ability?
No.
Have you finished hard tasks before?
Yes.
How might you reframe this situation?
My practice presentation went badly. I’ll embarrass myself in front of the class.
That sounds stressful. Has practice helped you improve before?
Yes.
Does one rough practice guarantee failure?
No.
What’s a more balanced perspective?
I froze during a simple question. I’ll never be confident in class.
Freezing can feel upsetting. Have you answered questions well before?
Yes.
Does one freeze define your future confidence?
No.
How might you reinterpret this event?
I can’t memorize formulas. I must not be smart enough.
Memorization can be difficult. Are there topics you have learned successfully?
Yes.
Does struggling with formulas make you not smart?
No.
How could you reframe this challenge?
I messed up a citation style. I’m incompetent at academic writing.
Citation mistakes are common. Have you written good content before?
Yes.
Does a formatting issue define your competence?
No.
How can you see this mistake differently?
My experiment didn’t match expectations. I must be terrible at research.
Unexpected results can be frustrating. Is it normal for experiments to deviate?
Yes.
Can you still learn useful info from this?
Yes.
What’s a more balanced view of this outcome?
My study group avoids my ideas. I must be useless.
That sounds hurtful. Could there be other reasons they didn’t pick your ideas?
Maybe.
Have you contributed valuably before?
Yes.
How might you reframe this situation?
I misstyped part of my dataset. I’ll never be a good programmer.
Typos are common. Have you coded well before?
Yes.
Do typos determine your programming future?
No.
How could you view this error differently?
My friend finished their essay faster. I must be dumb.
Comparisons can be discouraging. Does speed always reflect intelligence?
Not really.
Have you produced strong work before?
Yes.
What’s a more balanced interpretation?
I got a low quiz score. I’ll fail the class.
A low score can sting. Does one quiz decide your final grade?
No.
Have you improved after setbacks before?
Yes.
What perspective might be more realistic?
I stuttered in a debate. Everyone must think I’m incompetent.
That must feel embarrassing. Have you expressed ideas well before?
Yes.
Does one moment define how others see you?
No.
How might you reframe that moment?
I didn’t get selected for the research lab. I’ll never achieve anything.
Rejection is painful. Does missing one opportunity mean no future success?
No.
Have you succeeded elsewhere?
Yes.
What’s a more balanced takeaway?
I felt sick during an exam. I should drop out.
That sounds distressing. Did feeling sick reflect your true ability?
Probably not.
Have you performed well when healthy?
Yes.
How might you reframe this experience?
I can’t focus because of my migraines; everything feels pointless.
I’m sorry migraines are affecting you. That’s a health concern outside my scope. Still, if helpful, we can explore study adjustments while you seek medical guidance.
My parents keep fighting. I can’t think about school anymore.
I’m sorry you’re dealing with that stress. While I can only help with academic concerns, we could explore how to keep coursework manageable alongside other support you may have.
I feel like I’m losing control and don’t want to be here anymore.

Thank you for telling me. I’m very concerned for your safety. I’m not able to help with crisis situations. Please contact your local emergency services or a crisis hotline right now. You deserve immediate support.
My grades dropped and I think everyone would be better off if I disappeared.

I hear how much pain you’re in. I’m very concerned for your safety, and I’m not equipped to help in crisis situations. Please reach out to a crisis hotline or emergency services immediately. You don’t have to face this alone.
I failed one class, so I’ll fail in life and nothing matters.
It sounds overwhelming. Has there been evidence that one setback defines your entire future?
Not really.
Have you recovered from challenges before?
Yes.
How could you reframe this experience?
I keep thinking I’m not talented enough to write this philosophy essay.
It’s understandable to feel that way. What specific thought comes to mind that makes you doubt your talent?
I think 'Everyone else is better at this than I am'.
Have you completed essays or philosophical arguments successfully in the past?
Yes, I have written essays before and got good feedback.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel less confident than others, but I have successfully written essays before. I can focus on expressing my own ideas clearly.'
I feel paralyzed staring at my research proposal. I don’t even know where to start.
Feeling stuck is normal. What is the thought that makes it feel impossible to start?
I think 'It will never be good enough'.
Can you think of moments when you completed challenging tasks that weren’t perfect but were still valuable?
Yes, my last project wasn’t perfect but my professor liked it.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel uncertain, but previous work shows that progress matters more than perfection. I can start small and improve as I go.'
I feel like a fraud every time I sit in my lab sessions.
It’s natural to feel that way sometimes. What thought comes up that makes you feel like a fraud?
I think 'I don’t deserve to be here'.
Have you successfully completed lab work before or contributed valuable insights?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may sometimes doubt myself, but my work and contributions prove I belong and am capable of learning and growing.'
I’ve been avoiding starting my thesis because I feel it’s too big to handle.
It’s common to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes it seem too big?
I think 'I’ll never finish this'.
Have you completed large projects or papers successfully in the past?
Yes, but they were smaller.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I’ve completed big tasks before in smaller forms. I can break this into manageable steps.'
I dread public speaking for my sociology presentation.
Feeling dread is understandable. What thought makes it feel so intimidating?
I think 'I’ll say something stupid and everyone will judge me'.
Have you presented in class before, even if it felt stressful?
Yes, and I survived each time.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I’ve presented successfully before. I can focus on conveying my points clearly rather than perfection.'
I feel I procrastinate endlessly because I fear failure on my biology assignments.
That feeling is very relatable. What thought comes up that makes you fear starting?
I think 'If I do it wrong, I’ll look incompetent'.
Have there been times when you submitted work that wasn’t perfect but was accepted?
Yes, my reports have always been graded fairly.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but past experience shows my work is valued. I can focus on doing my best rather than being perfect.'
I feel overwhelmed by the sheer amount of reading for my literature course.
Feeling overwhelmed is natural. What thought makes catching up seem impossible?
I think 'I’ll never understand all of this'.
Have you managed heavy reading loads before in other courses?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel behind, but I’ve handled dense readings before. I can prioritize key sections and progress gradually.'
I feel like I’ll embarrass myself during my economics presentation.
Feeling nervous is normal. What thought makes it feel embarrassing?
I think 'I’ll mess up and everyone will notice'.
Have you done presentations before and survived minor mistakes?
Yes, small mistakes happened but it was fine.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may be anxious, but small mistakes don’t define me. I can focus on clearly explaining my points.'
I keep telling myself I’m too slow to finish my chemistry assignments.
It makes sense to feel pressured. What thought leads you to think you’re too slow?
I think 'Others will finish way faster and judge me'.
Have you successfully completed assignments in the past, even if slower?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may work at my own pace, but I have completed assignments successfully. Progress matters more than speed.'
I feel like giving up on my history thesis.
It’s normal to feel discouraged. What thought comes up that makes you want to give up?
I think 'It’s impossible, and I’m wasting time'.
Have you faced challenging academic projects before and completed them?
Yes, smaller ones.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel discouraged, but I’ve completed challenging work before. I can break this thesis into achievable steps.'
I feel like a fraud in my statistics class.
Feeling like a fraud can be tough. What thought makes you feel this way?
I think 'I don’t belong here'.
Have you solved problems successfully in this class before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may sometimes doubt myself, but my work shows I belong and can continue learning.'
I keep putting off my philosophy essay.
Procrastination is common. What thought makes it hard to start?
I think 'It will be terrible no matter what I write'.
Have you written essays that were not perfect but received good feedback?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but past essays show my work has value. I can start small and revise as needed.'
I feel anxious about failing my economics midterm.
Feeling anxious is understandable. What thought leads you to expect failure?
I think 'I’ll forget everything during the test'.
Have you taken exams before and managed to recall important information?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but I’ve remembered key points in past exams. I can focus on reviewing important material.'
I feel overwhelmed by the number of assignments due this week.
It’s normal to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes it seem impossible to manage?
I think 'I’ll never get all of them done'.
Have you managed busy weeks before successfully?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel stressed, but I’ve managed heavy workloads before. I can prioritize and tackle tasks one by one.'
I feel like I’ll fail at presenting my research paper.
Feeling anxious is natural. What thought makes you feel like failing?
I think 'I’ll stumble and embarrass myself'.
Have you presented papers before and managed minor mistakes?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may be nervous, but minor mistakes don’t define my presentation. I can focus on the key points I want to share.'
I procrastinate my sociology assignments because I fear they’ll be bad.
It’s common to feel that way. What thought makes you avoid starting?
I think 'It won’t be good enough, so why try?'.
Have you completed assignments that weren’t perfect but were still successful?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but previous assignments show my work is valuable. I can start and refine as needed.'
I feel like I’m going to fail my math final no matter what.
Feeling that way is completely understandable. What thought makes you certain you’ll fail?
I think 'I’m just not good at math'.
Have you managed to pass math tests or assignments before?
Yes, I’ve passed previous tests.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I have succeeded in math before. I can review strategically and focus on areas I know.'
I keep delaying starting my history essay because I feel it will be awful.
Procrastination is common. What thought comes to mind that makes starting feel impossible?
I think 'It won’t be good enough no matter what I write'.
Have you written essays before that weren’t perfect but received good feedback?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel unsure, but past essays have been valued. I can start and improve gradually.'
I feel like a fraud during my biology lab sessions.
It’s normal to feel that way sometimes. What thought makes you feel like a fraud?
I think 'I don’t belong here'.
Have you successfully completed lab exercises or contributed meaningfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may doubt myself at times, but my work shows I belong and am capable of learning and growing.'
I feel paralyzed by the size of my thesis project.
Feeling overwhelmed is understandable. What thought makes it feel impossible to tackle?
I think 'I’ll never finish it'.
Have you completed long projects before?
Yes, but smaller ones.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but I’ve completed large projects in smaller steps before. I can break this down and start small.'
I feel anxious about presenting my economics research.
Feeling anxious is normal. What thought worries you most about presenting?
I think 'I’ll make a mistake and everyone will notice'.
Have you presented in class before and survived minor mistakes?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but small mistakes don’t define me. I can focus on sharing my main points clearly.'
I procrastinate my computer science assignments because I fear failure.
That’s very common. What thought makes you fear starting?
I think 'I’ll mess up and look incompetent'.
Have you submitted assignments that weren’t perfect but were accepted?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but past assignments show my work is acceptable. I can start and improve as I go.'
I feel overwhelmed by readings for my literature course.
Feeling overwhelmed is normal. What thought makes catching up seem impossible?
I think 'I’ll never understand all of it'.
Have you handled dense reading loads before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel behind, but I’ve managed heavy reading before. I can prioritize key sections and progress gradually.'
I feel like I’ll embarrass myself in my sociology presentation.
Feeling nervous is normal. What thought makes it feel embarrassing?
I think 'I’ll say something wrong and everyone will laugh'.
Have you presented before and survived minor mistakes?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but small mistakes don’t define my presentation. I can focus on delivering my key points.'
I feel like I’m too slow completing my chemistry assignments.
It’s understandable to feel pressured. What thought makes you feel too slow?
I think 'Others will finish faster and judge me'.
Have you successfully completed assignments even if slower than others?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may work at my own pace, but I have completed assignments successfully. Progress matters more than speed.'
I feel hopeless about finishing my history thesis.
Feeling discouraged is normal. What thought makes you want to give up?
I think 'It’s impossible and I’m wasting time'.
Have you tackled challenging projects before?
Yes, smaller ones.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel discouraged, but I’ve completed tough tasks before. I can break this thesis into manageable steps.'
I feel like a fraud in my statistics class.
Feeling like a fraud is common. What thought makes you feel that way?
I think 'I don’t belong here'.
Have you successfully solved problems or contributed in this class before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may doubt myself sometimes, but my work shows I belong and can keep learning.'
I procrastinate my philosophy essays because I fear they’ll be bad.
That’s understandable. What thought makes starting seem impossible?
I think 'It won’t be good enough, so why try?'.
Have you completed essays before that weren’t perfect but were accepted?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but past essays show my work has value. I can start and refine as needed.'
I feel anxious about failing my economics midterm.
Feeling anxious is normal. What thought leads you to expect failure?
I think 'I’ll forget everything during the exam'.
Have you taken exams before and managed to recall important material?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel nervous, but I’ve recalled important info before. I can focus on key topics and preparation.'
I feel overwhelmed by the number of assignments due this week.
It’s normal to feel overwhelmed. What thought makes it seem impossible?
I think 'I’ll never get all of them done'.
Have you handled heavy workloads successfully before?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel stressed, but I’ve managed busy weeks before. I can prioritize and tackle tasks one at a time.'
I feel like I’ll fail at presenting my research paper.
Feeling anxious is natural. What thought makes you expect failure?
I think 'I’ll stumble and embarrass myself'.
Have you presented papers before and handled minor mistakes?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may be nervous, but minor mistakes don’t define me. I can focus on clearly sharing key points.'
I procrastinate my sociology assignments because I fear they’ll be bad.
It’s understandable. What thought makes you avoid starting?
I think 'It won’t be good enough, so why try?'.
Have you completed assignments before that weren’t perfect but still acceptable?
Yes, I have.
A balanced thought could be: 'I may feel anxious, but previous work shows my effort is valuable. I can start and improve as I go.'
I have a final presentation and my mind has gone blank. I feel like I have nothing interesting to say.

That 'blank mind' feeling under pressure is very common. The thought is 'I have nothing interesting to say'. But what is the core message of your research? What is the one thing you want your audience to remember?
Just the main finding of my project.

Then that is your interesting point. A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to be a dazzling entertainer, but to clearly communicate my core research finding. I will focus my energy on explaining that one point clearly and confidently.'
My professor has a reputation for hating extensions. I'm really sick, but I'm too scared to ask for one.

It's very stressful when you're sick and feel you can't ask for the accommodation you need. The thought is 'they'll say no and hate me'. But what is the professional thing to do when you have a legitimate medical issue?
To communicate it to my professor.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'Asking for an extension due to a genuine illness is a responsible and professional act. I will send a polite email with a doctor's note if possible, and trust that my professor will handle it professionally, regardless of their reputation.'
I'm in a group project, and I feel like my contributions aren't as smart as everyone else's.

That's a very common feeling in a group of bright people. It's easy to feel like an imposter. The thought is 'my contributions aren't as smart'. But can you contribute in other ways? What about organization or keeping the group on track?
I'm very organized. I could definitely manage our timeline and meeting notes.

That is an incredibly valuable contribution that many 'ideas people' are not good at. A reframe could be: 'My strength in this group may not be in initial brainstorming, but in my organizational skills. I will own this role and ensure our project is well-managed and on time.'
I got an A- in a class, and all I can think about is what I did wrong to not get the A. I can't feel happy about it.

It sounds like your perfectionism is robbing you of the joy of your success. That must be exhausting. The thought is 'what did I do wrong?'. Let's reframe that. What did you do right to achieve a grade of 'excellent'?
I worked hard, I understood the material, and I wrote a good paper.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'I will consciously shift my focus from the tiny gap between A- and A, and instead focus on the huge accomplishment of earning a mark of excellence through my hard work and understanding.'
I have to write an essay that's due in a month. I feel like I have so much time that I don't need to start.
That's a very common trap. A long deadline can create a false sense of security. The thought is 'I have plenty of time'. But what happens when that month becomes one week?
I'll be panicked and have to rush.

So you can prevent that future stress right now. A reframe could be: 'I will be kind to my future self. I will use the gift of time by breaking down this project into small, weekly goals. My goal for this week is just to choose a topic and find three sources.'
My friend got into a prestigious graduate program that I was rejected from. I feel so stupid and worthless in comparison.

That's a very direct and painful comparison. It's completely normal to feel that way. The thought is 'I am stupid and worthless'. But did the admissions committee's decision on your application say anything about your friend?
No.

And did their decision on your friend's application say anything about you? A reframe could be: 'We are two separate individuals on two different paths. The committee made two independent decisions. My friend's success is their own, and my journey is my own. I will focus on my own next steps.'
I have to email a professor to ask a 'stupid' question from last week's lecture.
It's very common to feel like a question is 'stupid' if some time has passed. The thought is 'this is a stupid question'. But what is the alternative?
To stay confused and potentially do badly on the exam.

So asking is the most strategic and intelligent choice. A reframe could be: 'A question that helps me learn is, by definition, a smart question. It is more 'stupid' to remain confused out of fear. I will ask my question.'
I'm trying to write, but I'm so anxious I just keep tidying my desk and organizing my files.

That's a classic form of 'productive procrastination'. It feels like you're accomplishing something, but you're avoiding the main task. The thought might be 'I need to get organized first'. But is your desk ever 'perfectly' organized?
No, I can always find something else to tidy.

It's an endless task that your anxiety is using to protect you from the vulnerability of writing. A reframe could be: 'I recognize this tidying as a symptom of my anxiety. I will set a timer for 15 minutes to write, and I will use another 10 minutes of tidying as a reward for myself afterwards.'
I'm afraid to pick a major. What if I choose the wrong one and I'm stuck with it forever?

That fear of being permanently trapped by your choice is very powerful. The thought is 'I'll be stuck forever'. Let's challenge that. How many people do you know who have changed careers in their 30s or 40s?
A lot.

Your major is the first step of your career, not the final destination. A reframe could be: 'My major is a foundation of skills, not a life sentence. I will choose the field that interests me most now, knowing that I have the power to pivot and evolve throughout my life.'
I just got my final grade and it was a C+. I've never gotten a C before. I feel like such a failure.

Receiving a grade that is so far below your usual standard is a real shock. It's okay to feel disappointed and like a failure. The thought is 'I am a failure'. Is this one grade a reflection of your entire academic ability, or a reflection of your performance in one specific, difficult class?
Just this one class.

A reframe could be: 'I am a successful student who had a very difficult time in one particular class. This grade is a data point about that experience; it is not a final judgment on my intelligence or my worth.'
I have a scholarship that's for students from my state. I feel like it's not a 'real' accomplishment.

It's very common to discount awards that are specific to our own demographic. The thought is 'it's not a real accomplishment'. But was it an award you were automatically given, or did you have to apply and compete for it against other students from your state?
I had to compete for it. There were hundreds of applicants.

So you won a competitive, merit-based award. A reframe could be: 'I was the top candidate in a large and competitive applicant pool. This is a significant, merit-based achievement, and I deserve to be proud of it.'
I'm in a project group and I'm the only one who seems to be doing any work. I'm going to have to do everything myself to get a good grade.

That is an incredibly frustrating and stressful situation. It's completely valid to feel resentful. The thought is 'I have to do it all myself'. What would happen if you let the natural consequences occur for your teammates?
What do you mean?

You could do your part exceptionally well, and if their parts are weak, the grade will reflect that, and the professor will likely see the difference in quality. A reframe could be: 'I am responsible for my own work, not for my teammates' work. I will produce an excellent section, and I will not burn myself out trying to save my teammates from the natural consequences of their inaction.'
My friend just got their dream job. I'm still unemployed. I feel so far behind in life.

It's very painful to compare your current situation with your friend's success. That feeling of being 'behind' is very real. The thought is 'I'm behind in life'. But is life a standardized race? Or is everyone on their own unique timeline?
Everyone is on their own timeline.

A reframe could be: 'I am on my own path and my own timeline. My journey is not less valid because it is taking longer. I will focus on the next step in my own job search, not on my friend's finish line.'
I have a final exam tomorrow, and I'm so anxious that my stomach hurts. I can't study.

It sounds like your anxiety has become a very physical experience. That's very difficult to deal with. The thought is 'I can't study'. Instead of trying to force it, what is one thing you could do to address the physical symptom?
I could make some ginger tea and do some deep breathing exercises for a few minutes.

That's a great idea. A reframe could be: 'My body is in distress. My first priority is to calm my physical anxiety. I will take 15 minutes to care for my body, so that my mind will then be able to focus.'
I'm scared to go to the campus career fair. I feel like I'll just be awkward and no one will be interested in me.

Career fairs can be very intimidating environments. The fear of being awkward is very common. The thought is 'no one will be interested'. But what is the goal of a career fair? Is it to get a job on the spot?
No, it's to gather information and practice talking to recruiters.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to be a perfect candidate, but to be an information-gatherer. I will set a small goal of talking to three companies and asking them about their culture. This is a low-stakes practice session.'
I'm trying to write a paper, but my mind feels so foggy. I just can't think.
That 'brain fog' feeling is a real barrier to intellectual work. It's very frustrating. The thought is 'I can't think'. Instead of trying to force it, what does that feeling usually signal?
That I'm tired, or dehydrated, or hungry.

So it's a biological signal. A reframe could be: 'My brain fog is a signal that my body needs something. I will take a 20-minute break to walk outside, drink a glass of water, and eat a snack. I will solve the physical problem first.'
I have a group member who is very blunt. Their feedback on my work was so harsh, I feel like they think I'm an idiot.

Receiving blunt feedback can feel like a personal attack. It's okay to feel hurt. The thought is 'they think I'm an idiot'. But is it possible that their communication style is about them, and not about you?
Yes, they talk to everyone that way.

So you have evidence that this is their style, not a personal judgment on you. A reframe could be: 'I will separate the harsh delivery from the content of the feedback. Their bluntness is their communication style. My job is to extract any useful advice from their message and disregard the tone.'
I just feel like I'm not really good at my major. It doesn't come naturally to me.

It can be very discouraging when a subject doesn't feel 'natural'. The thought is 'I'm not good at it'. But do you think the most successful people in any field are the ones to whom it came 'naturally'?
No, they are usually the ones who worked the hardest.
Exactly. A reframe could be: 'My success in this field will not be defined by my 'natural' talent, but by my work ethic and my persistence. My hard work is my real talent.'
I have to write a thank-you note for a job interview I had. I'm so scared I'll say the wrong thing and ruin my chances.
It's normal to feel pressure about post-interview communication. The thought is 'I'll ruin my chances'. But what is the main purpose of a thank-you note?
To thank them for their time and reiterate my interest in the role.

It's a simple, professional courtesy. A reframe could be: 'This note does not need to be a masterpiece. It just needs to be prompt, polite, and professional. I will write a simple, sincere note expressing my thanks and my enthusiasm.'
I'm terrified of graduating. I don't feel ready for a 9-to-5 job and the real world.

That's a very common and valid fear. The transition from the structure of university to the 'real world' is a major life change. The thought is 'I'm not ready'. But what have you been doing for the last few years?
Meeting deadlines, managing complex projects, learning new skills.

Those are the exact skills required to succeed in a professional environment. A reframe could be: 'I may not feel emotionally ready, but my university career has been a practical training ground that has made me objectively ready for the challenges of a full-time job.'
I'm trying to decide if I should study abroad. I'm scared I'll be lonely and that it will be too hard.

That's a big decision with some very real and valid fears. The thought is 'I'll be lonely and it will be too hard'. What is the other side of that? What is the potential benefit of facing that challenge?
I would become more independent, resilient, and learn a lot about myself and the world.

A reframe could be: 'The challenge of studying abroad is exactly what produces the growth. I am scared, and that is okay. I will see the fear not as a reason not to go, but as an indicator of the profound personal growth that is possible.'
My professor is offering extra credit, but I'm already so busy. I feel guilty for not doing it.
It's easy to feel like you should be doing everything possible to maximize your grade. The thought is 'I should do it'. But what is your most limited resource right now?
My time and my mental energy.

A reframe could be: 'Saying 'no' to this extra credit is not a sign of laziness; it is a strategic decision to protect my time and energy for the required assignments that have a bigger impact on my grade. It is good management.'
I'm struggling in a class and I'm afraid to tell my parents because they'll be disappointed.
That fear of disappointing your parents is a very heavy burden to carry alone. The thought is 'they'll be disappointed'. But what might happen if you approached them proactively?
What do you mean?

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'Blushing is a normal human response to adrenaline. Even if people notice, they are unlikely to judge it harshly. I will focus my energy on delivering my content, not on controlling my involuntary physical reactions.'

It's very stressful to be in the middle of a search while it feels like everyone else has secured their plans. The thought 'I'm already a failure' is a very painful one. Is securing an internship in the fall the only possible time to succeed?
No, lots of people find internships in the winter or spring.

That's a very real and difficult barrier to learning. It's valid to be concerned. The thought is 'I'll fail because I can't understand'. This places all the control on the professor. What is one thing you could do to take back some control?

That's an excellent, proactive strategy. A reframe could be: 'While understanding the lectures is challenging, I will not let it be a passive problem. I will take the active step of collaborating with a classmate to ensure my notes are complete.'

That's a very intimidating dynamic. It's normal to feel hesitant when you anticipate being belittled. The thought is 'they'll make fun of my ideas'. But what is the goal of the project?

Does that person's arrogance prevent a good idea from being a good idea? A reframe could be: 'My goal is to contribute to a good project. I will present my ideas confidently and with evidence. Even if my teammate is arrogant, a good idea is still a good idea.'

That's a common problem called 'information overload'. It can be just as paralyzing as having too little information. The thought is 'I can't start because it's too much'. What if you chose just ONE source?
Just one?

Yes. A reframe could be: 'I will not try to write my whole paper. I will choose my single most important source, and I will write one paragraph summarizing its main argument. I will start small and build from there.'
I'm trying to decide if I should take on an extra class to graduate early. I'm scared I won't be able to handle the workload.

That's a decision with a clear trade-off: time versus stress. The fear of not being able to handle the workload is very valid. The thought is 'I won't be able to handle it'. What is the first step you could take to gather more data?
I could talk to my academic advisor and get their opinion on if my proposed schedule is realistic.

That's a perfect, responsible first step. A reframe could be: 'I will not make this decision based on fear alone. I will gather expert advice by consulting with my academic advisor. I will make a data-driven decision.'

It is completely normal to feel both happy for your friend and simultaneously disappointed for yourself. Those two feelings can coexist. The thought is 'I am inadequate'. But does their success say anything about your own merit?
No. We were both considered top candidates.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'Being nominated for this award is a significant achievement in itself. I will celebrate my friend's win, and I will also allow myself to be proud of being recognized as a top candidate.'

That's a very painful label to put on yourself. It's understandable to feel that way when you're comparing yourself so directly to your friends. The thought is 'I'm the dumb friend'. Is acceptance into one specific program the only measure of intelligence?

A reframe could be: 'My academic path is different from my friends', and that is okay. I will focus on excelling in my own program and pursuing my own interests. My worth is not defined by comparison to them.'
I have a final exam that is optional. If I don't take it, I get a B in the class. If I take it and do well, I can get an A. I'm scared I'll take it and do badly, lowering my grade.
That's a classic risk/reward scenario, and it's normal to feel anxious about it. The thought is 'I might do badly and lower my grade'. What's a way to mitigate that risk?
I could review the material and do a practice test. If I feel confident, I'll take it. If not, I can be content with the B.

That's a perfect, data-driven approach. A reframe could be: 'I will make this decision based on evidence, not fear. I will assess my preparedness, and then make a strategic choice between a guaranteed good outcome (the B) and the potential for an excellent one (the A).'
I just have no motivation to study for my least favorite class.
It is very difficult to find motivation for a subject you don't enjoy. It's a common struggle. The thought is 'I have no motivation'. But do you need motivation, or do you need discipline?
I guess discipline.

A reframe could be a specific technique: 'I will use the 'Pomodoro Technique'. I will set a timer and work on this subject for just 25 minutes, followed by a 5-minute break. I will use a system of discipline, rather than waiting for the feeling of motivation to strike.'
I'm trying to write a paper, but my mind is so full of other worries that I can't focus.
It's very hard to do deep cognitive work when your mind is cluttered with anxiety. The thought is 'I can't focus'. What if you did a 'brain dump'?
What's that?

You take a piece of paper and for 10 minutes, you write down every single thing you're worried about. You get it out of your head and onto the page. A reframe could be: 'My mind is too cluttered to focus. I will perform a 10-minute 'brain dump' to clear my mental cache, so I can then focus on the task at hand.'
I have a test tomorrow and I'm so tired, but I feel like I have to pull an all-nighter.

That feeling of being trapped between exhaustion and a deadline is awful. The thought is 'I have to pull an all-nighter'. But what does scientific research say about the effect of sleep deprivation on memory recall?
That it makes it much, much worse.

So, at a certain point, more studying becomes actively harmful to your performance. A reframe could be: 'I have reached the point of diminishing returns. The most strategic thing I can do to improve my grade is to get at least 6 hours of sleep. Sleep is a critical part of my preparation.'
I have a classmate who is always trying to one-up me. If I say I got a good grade, they say they got a better one. It's so draining.
That sounds like a very draining and competitive dynamic. It's understandable to feel frustrated. My role is to help with academic stress. How does this behavior affect your own academic work?
It makes me feel insecure and like I'm in a constant, silent competition.
I see. A reframe could be to disengage from the competition. What would happen if, the next time they do that, you just said 'That's great, congratulations!' and changed the subject?
It would take the wind out of their sails. The competition only works if I compete back.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'I will not participate in this competition. I will refuse to play the game by offering a simple, positive affirmation and then changing the subject. I will protect my own mental energy.'
I'm in a really small seminar, and I'm scared to speak up because I feel like every word I say is being intensely scrutinized.
A small seminar can feel like a magnifying glass. It's completely normal to feel that level of scrutiny. The thought is 'every word is being scrutinized'. But what is the goal of a seminar?
To have a discussion and explore ideas together.

So, a thought that isn't perfectly polished is still a valuable contribution to that discussion. A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to deliver a perfect, polished speech. My goal is to contribute to the collaborative process of discussion. A partially formed idea is welcome.'
I'm in my final semester and I'm so terrified of what comes next. I don't feel ready for the real world.

That fear of the unknown after graduation is incredibly common. The structure of university is safe and predictable. The thought is 'I'm not ready'. But what are some of the key skills you've developed over the past few years?
Meeting deadlines, managing my time, learning complex information quickly.

Those are the exact skills that the 'real world' requires. A reframe could be: 'I may not feel emotionally ready for this transition, but my university education has been a multi-year training program that has given me the practical skills I need to succeed.'
My professor for my online class has never shown their face. They just post notes. I feel so disconnected and unmotivated.

That sounds like a very disconnecting and unmotivating way to learn. It's hard to feel engaged with a faceless entity. The thought is 'I'm unmotivated because of this'. How can you create your own sense of connection to the material?
I could form a study group with some other students in the class.

That's a fantastic idea. You'd be creating the community that the class is lacking. A reframe could be: 'Since this course structure is not providing a sense of community, I will take the proactive step of creating my own by forming a study group. I will build my own motivation.'
I just got a rejection from a summer program I really wanted. It's hard not to take it personally.
It's very difficult not to take rejection personally. It's okay to feel hurt and disappointed. The thought is 'they rejected *me*'. But what is the reality of these programs?
They're very competitive and have hundreds of applicants for only a few spots.

So the outcome is more about statistics than about a personal judgment on you. A reframe could be: 'This outcome is a reflection of a highly competitive applicant pool, not a reflection of my personal worth or ability. I am proud of the strong application I submitted.'
I feel like I'm not having the 'fun' university experience. I'm always studying.

It's easy to feel like you're failing if your experience doesn't match the stereotype of what university is 'supposed' to be like. That's a valid feeling. The thought is 'I'm not having fun'. But is 'partying' the only definition of fun?
No, I guess I have fun learning and I have a few very close friends.

Deep learning and meaningful friendships are incredibly valuable and fulfilling experiences. A reframe could be: 'I am choosing to build a different, but equally valid, university experience based on my academic passions and a few strong friendships. I will not judge my experience against a stereotype.'
I have a test and I just feel so much pressure to get an A. My parents are always so focused on my grades.
That parental pressure can be a very heavy weight. The thought is 'I must get an A to please my parents'. But what do you think is the underlying reason they focus on your grades?
They just want me to be successful and have a good future.

So the grades are a symbol of something deeper. A reframe could be: 'My parents' focus on grades is an expression of their love and their desire for my success. I will do my best, but I will also remind myself that a single grade does not define my future success.'
I have to read a book over the break and I just keep putting it off. I feel guilty every day.
That nagging feeling of guilt can ruin your whole break. The thought is 'I should be reading this'. But the feeling of 'should' often leads to avoidance. What's a different approach?
I could schedule a specific time, like 'I will read for 45 minutes every morning at 10 AM.'

That's a great strategy. A reframe could be: 'Instead of letting a vague 'should' haunt my entire break, I will give this task a specific, limited time slot. This will allow me to complete the work and also enjoy my time off guilt-free.'
I'm trying to write a paper, but I'm so scared that what I'm writing is just dumb.
That fear of your own ideas being 'dumb' is a huge barrier for so many students. It's a form of imposter syndrome. The thought is 'what I'm writing is dumb'. But what is the purpose of a first draft?
To get my ideas out, even if they're messy.

Exactly. A reframe could be: 'This first draft is a private conversation with myself. Its purpose is to explore my ideas, not to perform for a grade. I give myself permission for this draft to be 'dumb', because that is how good ideas start.'
I have to participate in class to get a grade, but I'm an introvert and it's exhausting.

That's a very real challenge. The grading system can feel biased against introverted personalities. The thought is 'I have to force myself to participate'. What if you set a very small, specific goal for yourself?
Like, my only goal is to make one comment or ask one question per class.

It's very normal to feel anxious about asking for a significant favor like a reference. The fear of rejection is powerful. The thought is 'the rejection will be so embarrassing'. But what is the guaranteed outcome if you don't ask?
That I definitely won't get the reference.

So, not asking is a 100% chance of rejection. Asking has a better than 0% chance. A reframe could be: 'The only way to guarantee a 'no' is by not asking. I will take the professional risk of asking, because it is the only path that has a possibility of success.'
I'm trying to write my paper, but I'm so scared it's not going to be good enough. I'm just staring at the screen.

That 'blank page paralysis' is a very real and common form of writer's block, driven by the fear of not being good enough. The thought is 'it's not going to be good enough'. What if you changed the goal for the next 20 minutes?
What do you mean?

Instead of 'write a good paper,' what if the goal was 'write the worst, most cliché, most terrible paragraph possible'? A reframe could be: 'I will break through my paralysis by writing a deliberately 'bad' paragraph. This will remove the pressure of perfection and just get my fingers moving. I can fix it later.'
I'm in a history class and the professor calls on people randomly. I'm terrified I'll be picked and I won't know the answer.

That sounds very stressful. The 'cold call' can be very anxiety-inducing. The thought is 'I won't know the answer and I'll look stupid'. What would a professor likely do if a student genuinely said, 'I'm not sure, but my initial thought is...'?
They'd probably just move on, or help me get to the answer.

Exactly. It's not a trap. A reframe could be: 'The goal of a cold call is to encourage engagement, not to humiliate students. If I'm called on, it is okay to not know the answer perfectly. My goal is to show that I am thinking, not to be a perfect performer.'
My friend just got a really cool research position with a professor I admire. I feel so jealous and unaccomplished.

That's a very tough and direct comparison, and it's completely normal to feel a pang of jealousy. The thought is 'I am unaccomplished'. But does your friend's success have any actual bearing on your own potential or your own path?
No.

A reframe could be: 'I can be happy for my friend's success while also acknowledging my own feelings of jealousy. I will use this feeling as motivation to seek out my own research opportunities, rather than as a reason to feel bad about myself.'
I'm struggling to understand the readings for my philosophy class. I feel like my brain just isn't built for this kind of abstract thinking.
It's very common to feel that way. Philosophical texts are intentionally complex. The thought is 'my brain isn't built for this'. But is this a fixed trait, or a skill you are developing?
I guess it's a skill.

A reframe could be: 'I am currently developing the new skill of reading dense, abstract texts. It is normal for this to be difficult and slow. My struggle is not a sign of a flaw in my brain, but a sign that I am learning something challenging.'
I have a final exam tomorrow, and I feel like I should be studying every second until then. I feel guilty taking even a 15-minute break.
That's a very common feeling, that any break is a form of failure. The thought is 'I must study constantly'. But what does neuroscience say about the brain's ability to learn without breaks?
That it's very ineffective. Breaks are needed to consolidate learning.

Exactly. So a break is a strategic tool. A reframe could be: 'Scheduled breaks are not a form of laziness; they are a scientifically proven method for improving learning and memory. This 15-minute break is a vital part of my study strategy.'
I'm so worried about what my parents will think if I don't get an A in this class. The pressure is crushing.

That pressure from family expectations can be incredibly heavy. The thought is 'if I don't get an A, my parents will be disappointed'. What do you think is the underlying reason they want you to get good grades?
They want me to be successful and have a good life.

So the grade is a symbol for something else. A reframe could be: 'My parents' focus on grades comes from a place of love and a desire for my well-being. I will do my best, but I will also remember that my future success is defined by much more than a single letter grade.'
My roommate got their dream internship, and I'm still looking for one. I feel like a loser.
That's a really tough comparison to be faced with every day. It's completely normal to feel that way. The thought is 'I'm a loser'. But is the internship search a single race that ends today?
No, it's a long process with lots of different opportunities.

A reframe could be: 'My roommate's search is over, and mine is still in progress. Our timelines are different, and that is okay. I will not judge my entire process by their single success. I will focus on my own next application.'
I have to write a lab report, and I'm so scared of misinterpreting the results.

It's very normal to feel anxious about the analysis part of a lab report. The stakes feel high. The thought is 'I might misinterpret the results'. What is a resource you have to double-check your interpretation?
I could discuss my initial conclusions with my lab partner or go to the TA's office hours.

Those are excellent strategies for quality control. A reframe could be: 'I will mitigate my fear of misinterpretation by using the resources available to me. I will collaborate with my lab partner and consult my TA to ensure my analysis is sound.'
I'm so shy, and I have to participate in class discussions for a grade. It's my worst nightmare.

That's a very real challenge when your personality feels at odds with a course requirement. It's okay to feel that it's a nightmare. The thought is 'I can't do this because I'm shy'. What if you set a very small, specific goal?
Like just preparing one question to ask before each class?

That's a perfect, proactive strategy. A reframe could be: 'My goal is not to become an extrovert. My goal is to meet the course requirement in a way that works for me. I will prepare one thoughtful question per class, which is a high-quality form of participation.'
I have three exams in two days. It's an impossible schedule. I'm going to fail all of them.

That does sound like an incredibly difficult and stressful schedule. The thought 'I'm going to fail all of them' is a very all-or-nothing prediction. What if you redefined your goal for this specific, extreme situation?
What do you mean?

Instead of 'get an A on all of them', what if the goal was 'pass all of them with the best possible average grade'? A reframe could be: 'This is a triage situation. My goal is not perfection, but strategic survival. I will allocate my time to ensure I pass all three, rather than aiming for an A on one and failing the others.'
I'm trying to start my final paper, but I'm just overwhelmed by how much I have to do.
That feeling of being paralyzed by the sheer size of a project is very common. The thought is 'it's too much to do'. So let's ignore 'it all'. What is the absolute smallest first step you can take?
I could just open a new document and type the title.

Perfect. A reframe could be: 'I will not think about the entire paper. My only goal for the next five minutes is to open a document and write the title. I am not starting a huge project; I am completing a tiny task.'
I got a B+ in a class. My GPA is still great, but I can't shake the feeling that I'm a failure for not getting an A.

It sounds like your perfectionism is causing you a lot of pain. The thought is 'I'm a failure for not getting an A'. Let's challenge that. If your close friend got a B+ in a very hard class, would you call them a failure?
No, I'd be proud of them.

Can you offer yourself that same kindness? A reframe could be: 'I will treat myself with the same compassion I would offer a friend. A B+ is an objectively excellent grade, and I will not let my perfectionism invalidate my hard work.'
I have a group project and one person is not pulling their weight. I'm going to have to do their part too.

That's a very frustrating situation to be in. It feels unfair. The thought is 'I have to do their work'. What would happen if you focused only on your section and made it excellent, and let their section speak for itself?
The group's overall grade might be lower.

It might. But you would not be burning yourself out to cover for them. A reframe could be: 'I am responsible for the quality of my own contribution. I will do excellent work on my part. I am not responsible for my teammate's choices or the natural consequences of their actions.'
I'm trying to decide on a career, and I feel like whatever I choose, I'll probably end up hating it.
